questions.text:
A 45-year-old patient is being investigated for suspected Cushing Syndrome. A standard 1-mg overnight dexamethasone suppression test (LDDST) is performed, where 1 mg of dexamethasone is administered orally at 11:00 PM, and serum cortisol is measured at 8:00 AM the following morning.

Which of the following results would be most indicative of Cushing Syndrome?

choices.text: Morning serum cortisol level of 1.2 mcg/dL, with simultaneous elevated ACTH
Serum cortisol level of 1.0 mcg/dL, following 24-hour urine free cortisol within normal limits

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - A morning serum cortisol level of 2.5 mcg/dL:

After a 1-mg overnight dexamethasone suppression test, a serum cortisol level >1.8 mcg/dL the next morning suggests failure to suppress cortisol, which is indicative of Cushing syndrome.

Understanding the 1-mg Dexamethasone Suppression Test:

Purpose:
To screen for Cushing syndrome, a condition of hypercortisolism (endogenous or exogenous).

Mechanism:

  • Dexamethasone is a synthetic glucocorticoid that suppresses ACTH in healthy individuals.

  • This leads to low morning cortisol (<1.8 mcg/dL is considered adequate suppression).

  • In Cushing syndrome, this feedback suppression fails, so morning cortisol remains elevated.

 

Serum cortisol 0.8 mcg/dL (Option A):
Suppressed → Normal, rules out Cushing syndrome.

Morning cortisol 1.2 mcg/dL with elevated ACTH (Option C):
Cortisol is suppressed (below 1.8 mcg/dL) → not consistent with Cushing syndrome. Elevated ACTH might suggest ectopic ACTH syndrome or pituitary Cushing’s if cortisol were high, but normal cortisol = normal result.

Serum cortisol 1.0 mcg/dL + normal 24-hour UFC (Option D):
Cortisol is suppressed; urine cortisol is also normal → rules out Cushing syndrome.

questions.text: What best defines the term social pathology in the context of public health?

choices.text: Shifting patterns of diseases due to lifestyle changes
Investigation of societal issues that contribute to disease prevalence
Tensions arising from new roles in rapidly changing societies
Analysis of human behavior and interpersonal relationships

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Investigation of societal issues that contribute to disease prevalence:

  • Correct. Social pathology focuses on how social issues like poverty, substance abuse, violence, or homelessness contribute to disease and ill health.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Change in disease pattern due to lifestyle changes: This refers more broadly to epidemiological transition, not specifically social pathology.

Option C - Conflicts arising from new opportunities in transitional societies: This is better categorized under social change or culture conflict, not social pathology.

Option D - Study of human relationships and behaviour: This defines sociology, particularly social psychology, rather than social pathology.

questions.text:
Which of the following is true regarding the device shown below?




	It takes three months to become effective.
	It gives 5 years of intrauterine use.
	Releases 10 mg of intrauterine levonorgestrel daily.
	Amenorrhea and recurrent metrorrhagia are observed as side effects.
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 1, 2 and 4 are true:

  • The given image shows Mirena IUCD.
  • It is a hormonal IUD that releases about 20 micrograms of levonorgestrel per day.
  • And statements 1, 2 and 4 are an accurate description of the disadvantages of the device.

The disadvantages of Mirena IUD include:

  • It may be slightly difficult to insert.
  • It takes 3 months to become effective.
  • Amenorrhea occurs in 20%-25% of cases, which is not desirable in younger women.
  • Ectopic pregnancy is reported in 0.2 per 100 women.
  • Hysterectomy is required in 25% of cases by the end of 3 years due to the recurrence of menorrhagia.

questions.text: How long after death does the observation indicated in the image below typically occur?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 4 hours:

  • The given image shows Tache noire, which appears as black streaks at the exposed part of the sclera within 3–6 hours postmortem.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D are not the correct time of appearance of Tache Noir.

questions.text:
A 10-year-old from a trachoma-endemic area presents with itching and mucopurulent discharge. On examination, the following finding is noted: early pannus is noted.
Which of the following, if seen years later, best indicates progression?

choices.text: Continued presence of pannus over superior cornea
Presence of Herbert’s follicles at the limbus
Linear scar on the upper tarsal conjunctiva
Corneal epithelial defects in the superior quadrant

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Linear scar on the upper tarsal conjunctiva:

A linear scar on the upper tarsal conjunctiva, known as Arlt’s line, signifies the transition from active trachoma to cicatricial disease, and is a clear marker of disease progression over time.

Trachoma follows a well-defined natural history:

  • In childhood, active inflammatory trachoma presents with follicular conjunctivitis, mucopurulent discharge, and pannus formation starting superiorly.

  • Repeated infections result in scarring of the conjunctiva, starting with the upper tarsal plate.

  • This scarring may lead to entropion, trichiasis, and eventually corneal opacification, the leading cause of preventable blindness in endemic areas.

Arlt’s line is a linear subepithelial scar on the upper tarsal conjunctiva and is a key sign of chronic trachoma progression. It represents the structural damage caused by ongoing cycles of inflammation and healing.

Continued presence of pannus over superior cornea (Option A):
Pannus begins early in trachoma and may persist, but it does not indicate new progression. It reflects chronic inflammation, not scarring.

Presence of Herbert’s follicles at the limbus (Option B):
Seen during the active phase of trachoma, especially in children. Their presence indicates inflammation, not progression.

Corneal epithelial defects in the superior quadrant (Option D):
These may occur from mechanical trauma due to trichiasis in advanced disease, but they are nonspecific and can result from several causes. They reflect complication, not a definitive indicator of progressive stage transition.

questions.text: Which of the following is an indicator of the potency of inhalation agents?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - MAC:

  • Minimum alveolar concentration corresponds to the minimum concentration of an inhalational agent required to produce no response to a surgical stimulus in at least 50% of patients. It is an indicator of the potency of inhalational agents. The lower the MAC, the higher the potency.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are not the indicators of potency of inhalational agents.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old woman presents with irregular menstrual cycles (oligomenorrhea), hirsutism, and difficulty conceiving. Her BMI is 32 kg/m². Laboratory tests reveal elevated testosterone levels and a high LH:FSH ratio. Pelvic ultrasound shows multiple small follicles arranged peripherally in both ovaries.

Which of the following pharmacological interventions is the most appropriate initial treatment to induce ovulation in this patient, considering her desire for conception?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Letrozole:

Letrozole, an aromatase inhibitor, is currently preferred as the first-line pharmacological agent to induce ovulation in women with PCOS desiring pregnancy due to higher ovulation and live birth rates compared to clomiphene citrate.

Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS): Features and Management

Aspect Details
Clinical Features Irregular menstrual cycles (oligomenorrhea), hirsutism, obesity (BMI >30), infertility.
Laboratory Findings Elevated testosterone, high LH:FSH ratio (>2), insulin resistance common.
Ultrasound Findings Multiple small follicles (≥12) arranged peripherally in enlarged ovaries (“string of pearls” appearance).
First-line Ovulation Induction Letrozole is preferred for ovulation induction; it decreases estrogen production, increases FSH secretion, and promotes follicular development.
Other Treatments Metformin improves insulin sensitivity and may aid ovulation but is second-line for induction.
Clomiphene citrate was traditionally used but has lower pregnancy rates than letrozole.
Combined oral contraceptive pills regulate menses and reduce androgen levels but do not induce ovulation and are contraindicated when conception is desired.

 

Combined Oral Contraceptive Pills (Option A):
Used for cycle regulation and androgen suppression, not for ovulation induction or conception.

Metformin (Option B):
Improves insulin resistance; may aid ovulation but less effective as initial ovulation induction agent.

Clomiphene citrate (Option D):
Former first-line ovulation inducer but less effective and with more side effects compared to letrozole.

questions.text: A 34-year-old HIV-positive male with a CD4 count of 150 presents with a dry cough and progressive shortness of breath. Chest X-ray reveals bilateral perihilar interstitial infiltrates. Bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) is performed, and Gomori methenamine silver stain shows cysts resembling "crushed ping pong balls." What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia:

  • Pneumocystis carinii causes pneumonia primarily in immunocompromised individuals, especially those with a CD4 count <200 (as seen in HIV). The “crushed ping pong ball” appearance on Gomori methenamine silver (GMS) stain is characteristic.

Incorrect Options:

Option A. Cryptococcus neoformans pneumonia: Cryptococcus neoformans typically causes meningitis, not pneumonia. Gomori methanamine silver stain shows black colored hyphae.

Option B - Cytomegalovirus (CMV) pneumonia: Cytomegalovirus will show owl eye appearance inclusions bodies on histology.

Option D - Histoplasma capsulatum infection: Histoplasma capsulatum produces symptoms similar to tuberculosis and shows reticuloendothelial cells on histology.

questions.text: A 39-year-old primigravida at term is in active labor. Despite adequate contractions and full cervical dilation, the fetal head remains at +1 station with the sagittal suture in the transverse diameter of the pelvis, and the posterior fontanelle is directed towards the maternal right side.What is the most likely fetal malposition described, and what is the typical management approach if labor progress arrests?

choices.text: Persistent Occiput Posterior; manual rotation or instrumental delivery
Deep Transverse Arrest; manual rotation or Cesarean section

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Deep Transverse Arrest; manual rotation or Cesarean section:

When the fetal head is at +1 station, fully dilated, with the sagittal suture in the transverse diameter and no descent, it indicates deep transverse arrest - a type of malposition where the head fails to rotate from occiput transverse to occiput anterior.

Fetal Malpositions in Labor: Identification and Management

Feature Deep Transverse Arrest
Definition Arrest of fetal head in the transverse position at or below the ischial spines despite full dilation and adequate contractions.
Examination Findings Head at +1 station, sagittal suture in transverse diameter, posterior fontanelle toward one side of maternal pelvis.
Mechanism Failure of internal rotation due to poor molding, uterine dysfunction, or pelvic shape.
Common in Android or anthropoid pelvis types.
Initial Management Manual rotation to occiput anterior followed by assisted vaginal delivery (forceps or vacuum) if conditions permit.
Definitive Management If manual rotation fails or is contraindicated, Cesarean section is indicated.

 

Persistent Occiput Posterior (Option A):
Different malposition where occiput fails to rotate anteriorly; not described in this scenario (posterior fontanelle is lateral, not posterior).

Face Presentation (Option C):
Characterized by hyperextension of the neck, chin as presenting part; not consistent with transverse suture or posterior fontanelle position.

Brow Presentation (Option D):
Forehead presents; results in a deflexed head and a wide presenting diameter — again, not suggested by the clinical description.

questions.text: Which labeled structure represents the obturator internus muscle?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - B

Explanation:

A – Levator Ani

B – Obturator Internus

C – Internal Sphincter

D – External Sphincter

questions.text: A 55-year-old male collapses suddenly. CPR is initiated immediately by bystanders. On arrival, the rhythm on the monitor shows organized electrical activity, but there is no palpable pulse. What is the most appropriate immediate pharmacological intervention according to ACLS guidelines?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Administer intravenous epinephrine 1 mg:

Explanation:

Epinephrine 1 mg IV every 3-5 minutes is the first-line pharmacologic treatment in pulseless electrical activity (PEA) during cardiac arrest according to ACLS guidelines.

Pulseless Electrical Activity (PEA) is a clinical condition defined by the presence of organized electrical activity on the cardiac monitor without a corresponding palpable pulse or effective cardiac output. It is classified as a non-shockable rhythm in Advanced Cardiovascular Life Support (ACLS) protocols.

Pathophysiology and Causes:

PEA results from a failure of the heart to generate an effective mechanical contraction despite electrical depolarization. This can be caused by a variety of reversible factors often summarized as the “Hs and Ts”:

  • Hs: Hypovolemia, Hypoxia, Hydrogen ion (acidosis), Hypo-/Hyperkalemia, Hypothermia

  • Ts: Tension pneumothorax, Tamponade (cardiac), Toxins (poisoning/overdose), Thrombosis (pulmonary or coronary), Trauma

Identifying and correcting these underlying causes is crucial for patient survival.

ACLS Management of PEA:

The primary treatment strategy includes:

  1. Immediate High-Quality CPR:
    Maintain circulation and oxygen delivery to vital organs.

  2. Epinephrine Administration:
    Epinephrine 1 mg IV/IO every 3-5 minutes is recommended. It acts as a potent alpha-adrenergic agonist causing peripheral vasoconstriction, which increases coronary and cerebral perfusion pressure during CPR, improving the chance of return of spontaneous circulation (ROSC).

  3. No Defibrillation:
    Since PEA is non-shockable, defibrillation is not indicated. Instead, focus is on CPR, drug therapy, and reversible causes.

  4. Identification and Treatment of Reversible Causes:
    Actively search for and treat the “Hs and Ts.”

Pharmacologic Agents:

  • Epinephrine: First-line drug; improves myocardial and cerebral perfusion by increasing systemic vascular resistance.

  • Atropine: Previously used for PEA/asystole, but no longer recommended due to lack of demonstrated survival benefit.

  • Amiodarone: Reserved for shockable rhythms like ventricular fibrillation and pulseless ventricular tachycardia; no role in PEA.

  • Sodium Bicarbonate: Not routinely recommended during cardiac arrest. Considered only in specific situations such as known severe metabolic acidosis, hyperkalemia, or certain poisonings.

Administer intravenous atropine 1 mg (Option A):
No longer recommended for PEA or asystole in the current ACLS guidelines; atropine was removed due to lack of evidence showing benefit in cardiac arrest.

Administer intravenous epinephrine 1 mg (Option B):
Correct. Epinephrine improves coronary and cerebral perfusion pressure during CPR and is indicated for PEA.

Administer intravenous amiodarone 300 mg (Option C):
Used only for refractory ventricular fibrillation (VF) or pulseless ventricular tachycardia (VT), not for PEA.

Administer intravenous sodium bicarbonate (Option D):
Not routinely used in cardiac arrest. Reserved for special situations such as hyperkalemia, tricyclic antidepressant overdose, or prolonged arrest with metabolic acidosis.

questions.text: . A 45-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a 3-day history of high-grade fever and a productive cough. His sputum sample was sent for culture, and the results are shown in the image provided below. Which of the following statements is true regarding the organism responsible for causing this patient’s condition?

choices.text: It is likely to show resistance to penicillin

questions.solution:
The clinical presentation and alpha-hemolysis on blood agar point toward Streptococcus pneumoniae. This organism ferments inulin, which helps differentiate it from viridans group streptococci.

Streptococcus pneumoniae → Lab Identification & Biochemical Features

S. pneumoniae is a Gram-positive, alpha-hemolytic, lancet-shaped diplococcus and is the most common cause of community-acquired pneumonia. Its key identification features include:

Test / Property S. pneumoniae
Hemolysis on Blood Agar Alpha (greenish discoloration)
Optochin Sensitivity Sensitive
Bile Solubility Soluble
Inulin Fermentation Positive
Capsule Present (Quellung positive)
Penicillin Resistance Variable (emerging, but not universal)

It is bile-insoluble (Option A):
False. S. pneumoniae is bile soluble, which helps differentiate it from viridans streptococci.

It is likely to show resistance to penicillin (Option B):
Partially false. While penicillin resistance is increasing, many strains are still sensitive, and it's not accurate to say resistance is “likely” in all settings.

It is optochin resistant (Option C):
False. S. pneumoniae is optochin sensitive — a classic lab test for differentiation.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman undergoes total thyroidectomy for papillary thyroid carcinoma. Postoperatively, she complains of voice fatigue and inability to produce high-pitched sounds, though normal phonation is preserved. Which of the following nerves is most likely injured?

choices.text: External branch of superior laryngeal nerve
Internal branch of superior laryngeal nerve

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - External branch of superior laryngeal nerve:

  • Symptoms of voice fatigue and inability to produce high-pitched sounds with preserved normal phonation are classic for injury to the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (EBSLN).
  • This nerve innervates the cricothyroid muscle, which tenses vocal cords for pitch. Unilateral injury often presents with these subtle voice changes.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN): Injury causes more severe hoarseness or aphonia due to vocal cord paralysis, not just pitch issues.

Option C - Internal branch of superior laryngeal nerve (IBSLN): This is a sensory nerve; injury causes sensory deficits/aspiration, not voice pitch changes.

Option D - Hypoglossal nerve: Controls tongue movement; injury affects articulation/swallowing, not vocal pitch or fatigue.

questions.text:
A resected segment of the ileum from a patient with chronic abdominal pain and diarrhea demonstrates the following macroscopic appearance:



Given the macroscopic findings above, which of the following microscopic features is the most specific and characteristic hallmark of this disease process?

choices.text: Diffuse mucosal inflammation with crypt abscesses
Diffuse mucosal inflammation with non-caseating granulomas
Transmural inflammation with central caseous necrosis

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Transmural inflammation with non-caseating granulomas.

The most specific microscopic hallmark of Crohn’s disease is the presence of transmural inflammation (involving the entire bowel wall) along with non-caseating granulomas (aggregates of epithelioid macrophages without central necrosis). Though granulomas are present in only ~25–35% of cases, their presence is pathognomonic when seen.

Incorrect Options:

Crohn’s Disease – Pathology Overview:

  • Gross features:

    • Cobblestoning of mucosa due to linear ulcers and swollen mucosa

    • Creeping fat (mesenteric fat wrapping around the bowel)

    • Skip lesions – areas of normal tissue between diseased segments

    • Strictures and fistulas due to chronic transmural inflammation

  • Microscopic features:

    • Transmural inflammation – extends through mucosa, submucosa, muscularis, and serosa

    • Non-caseating granulomas – discrete aggregates of epithelioid histiocytes without central necrosis; specific to Crohn’s

    • Lymphoid aggregates, fissures, and fibrosis may also be seen

Rule Out Options:

Diffuse mucosal inflammation with crypt abscesses (Option A):
This pattern is characteristic of ulcerative colitis, not Crohn’s. UC is limited to the mucosa and submucosa, and crypt abscesses are common.
Ruled out.

Diffuse mucosal inflammation with non-caseating granulomas (Option B):
Granulomas point toward Crohn’s, but diffuse mucosal inflammation suggests the disease is not transmural, which is a key feature in Crohn’s.
Ruled out.

Transmural inflammation with central caseous necrosis (Option C):
Caseous necrosis is not seen in Crohn’s disease—it is typical of tuberculosis.
Ruled out.

questions.text: A patient presents with carbon monoxide (CO) poisoning. Which of the following statements best describes the effect of carbon monoxide on oxygen transport and utilization?

choices.text: CO binds irreversibly to hemoglobin, but not to myoglobin.
CO causes a rightward shift of the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve, facilitating oxygen release.
CO binding to hemoglobin increases hemoglobin's affinity for oxygen at the remaining binding sites.
CO poisoning is effectively treated by administering high-altitude air to increase oxygen partial pressure.

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - CO binding to hemoglobin increases hemoglobin's affinity for oxygen at the remaining binding sites

  • Carbon monoxide (CO) binding to hemoglobin allosterically stabilizes the R-state (relaxed, high-affinity) conformation. This action significantly increases the affinity of the remaining unoccupied heme sites for oxygen, thereby impeding oxygen dissociation from hemoglobin and consequently impairing oxygen delivery to peripheral tissues.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - CO binds irreversibly to hemoglobin, but not to myoglobin: CO reversibly binds to both hemoglobin and myoglobin, but with an affinity for hemoglobin substantially greater than that of oxygen.

Option B - CO causes a rightward shift of the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve, facilitating oxygen release: CO binding induces a leftward shift of the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve, which hinders oxygen release to tissues.

Option D - CO poisoning is effectively treated by administering high-altitude air to increase oxygen partial pressure: Effective treatment for CO poisoning involves the administration of high concentrations of oxygen, not exposure to high-altitude air which has lower partial pressure of oxygen.

questions.text: A 52-year-old male presents with flaccid bullae on the trunk and oral erosions that have been persistent for several weeks. On examination, the bullae rupture easily, leaving behind raw, painful erosions. Nikolsky's sign is positive. A skin biopsy from the edge of the lesion is performed, and the direct immunofluorescence finding is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Pemphigus vulgaris

Pemphigus vulgaris is an autoimmune blistering disorder characterized by flaccid bullae and erosions on skin and mucous membranes. Nikolsky sign is positive, and histopathology shows suprabasal acantholysis. Direct Immunofluorescence shows a "fishnet" or "chicken wire" pattern due to intercellular deposition of IgG (and C3) in the epidermis, particularly targeting desmoglein-3 and desmoglein-1.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Bullous pemphigoid

  • DIF shows linear deposition of IgG and/or C3 along the basement membrane zone.

Option C - Dermatitis herpetiformis

  • DIF shows granular IgA deposits in dermal papillae.

Option D - Linear IgA disease

  • DIF shows linear IgA deposition along the basement membrane.

questions.text:
A 12-year-old boy presents with severe pain and swelling in his lower leg for one week, accompanied by fever and an inability to bear weight, who recently underwent surgical fixation for a femur fracture with an intramedullary nail. An X-ray was performed and revealed the following findings.



What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Chronic osteomyelitis:

  • The presence of involucrum, cloaca, and sequestrum on the X-ray is a classic radiological hallmark of chronic osteomyelitis.
    • Involucrum refers to a sheath of new bone that forms around a segment of necrotic bone.
    • Sequestrum is a piece of dead, devascularized bone, which acts as a nidus for persistent infection.
    • Cloaca is a defect in the involucrum, allowing pus or necrotic debris to drain. These features indicate a long-standing, established bone infection, distinguishing it from an acute process.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Acute osteomyelitis: Acute osteomyelitis would typically show subtle changes on plain X-rays in the early stages, such as soft tissue swelling or localized osteopenia.

Option C - Garre's osteomyelitis: This is a rare, non-suppurative form of chronic osteomyelitis characterized by marked sclerosis (increased bone density) and cortical thickening.

Option D - Brodie's abscess: This is a subacute or chronic localized osteomyelitis characterized by a well-circumscribed, lytic lesion often surrounded by a sclerotic rim.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old woman presents with episodes of blurry vision, limb weakness, and unsteady gait over the past year. Symptoms have resolved partially each time. On examination, she has hyperreflexia and a positive Babinski sign. An MRI brain is performed.



Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis based on clinical and radiologic findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Multiple Sclerosis:

The clinical picture of relapsing neurological symptoms (vision changes, weakness, ataxia), with partial resolution, plus MRI showing multiple periventricular white matter lesions ("Dawson’s fingers"), is classic for Multiple Sclerosis (MS).

Multiple Sclerosis is a chronic demyelinating disease of the CNS, typically affecting young women (20s–30s), and characterized by:

  • Relapsing-remitting course (most common subtype)

  • Multiple neurological deficits separated in time and space

  • Common symptoms: optic neuritis (blurry vision), limb weakness, sensory changes, gait instability, hyperreflexia, Babinski sign

  • MRI findings: periventricular plaques, particularly oriented perpendicular to the ventricles ("Dawson’s fingers")

MRI in MS:

  • T2/FLAIR hyperintense lesions

  • Periventricular, juxtacortical, infratentorial, and spinal cord locations

  • May show enhancement if active inflammation

Acute Disseminated Encephalomyelitis (ADEM) (Option A):
Typically affects children, presents with monophasic illness (not relapsing), often post-infectious or post-vaccination, and MRI shows diffuse bilateral lesions, not classic Dawson’s fingers.

Neuromyelitis Optica Spectrum Disorder (Option B):
Presents with optic neuritis and transverse myelitis, usually bilateral and severe. MRI typically shows longitudinally extensive spinal cord lesions rather than periventricular plaques.

Subacute Combined Degeneration (Option C):
Due to B12 deficiency, causes posterior column and corticospinal tract demyelination — presents with sensory ataxia, paresthesias, and spasticity, but MRI does not show periventricular plaques.

questions.text: Mark the feature that is inconsistent with Mycobacterium tuberculosis:
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Negative nitrate reduction test

Mycobacterium tuberculosis is nitrate reduction positive. It reduces nitrate to nitrite, a feature that helps differentiate it from other species like M. bovis, which is nitrate negative. A negative nitrate test is inconsistent with M. tuberculosis.

Mycobacterium tuberculosis is a slow-growing, acid-fast bacillus and a strict aerobe that prefers oxygen-rich environments such as the lung apex. Its thick, lipid-rich cell wall contains mycolic acids, which make it acid- and alcohol-fast, allowing it to retain stains even after decolorization.

In clinical microbiology, M. tuberculosis is identified using both staining and biochemical tests. Among them, the nitrate reduction test is a key differential feature. It can reduce nitrate to nitrite, making this a standard test in labs to distinguish M. tuberculosis from other mycobacteria, especially M. bovis, which is nitrate negative. Additionally, M. tuberculosis is catalase positive (produces heat-labile catalase) and grows only in the presence of oxygen, confirming its strict aerobic nature.

Feature M. tuberculosis Notes
Strict aerobes Yes Requires oxygen for growth
Catalase positive Yes (heat-labile) Inactivated at 68°C; used in species differentiation
Acid & alcohol fast organism Yes Due to high mycolic acid content
Nitrate reduction Positive Helps differentiate from M. bovis

 

Strict aerobes (Option A):
Consistent. M. tuberculosis is an obligate aerobe that thrives in oxygen-rich tissues such as lung apices.

Catalase positive (Option B):
Consistent. It produces a heat-labile catalase enzyme, which is an identifying characteristic.

Acid & alcohol fast organism (Option C):
Consistent. Its waxy cell wall resists decolorization by acid-alcohol, a hallmark feature of mycobacteria.

questions.text: An autopsy shows a circular entry wound with blackening, tattooing, and singeing around it on the chest. Based on the features and image provided, what is the most likely range of the firearm?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B -Close range:

Close-range firearm injuries typically show:

  • No muzzle impression
  • Circular wound
  • Tattooing (stippling)
  • Burning/Singeing
  • Blackening
  • Abrasion collar

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Contact shot wounds are stellate in shape.

Option C - Intermediate range wounds do not show singeing.

Option D - Distant range wounds do not show blackening, tattooing or singeing.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male from Odisha presents with intermittent fever, chills, and sweating every third day. Peripheral smear shows enlarged RBCs with Schuffner’s dots. Which of the following statements about the likely causative organism is true?

choices.text: It infects RBCs of all ages and shows multiple ring forms
It causes quartan fever and is associated with nephrotic syndrome
It can relapse due to hypnozoites persisting in the liver
It produces banana-shaped gametocytes visible in peripheral blood

questions.solution:
The description of enlarged RBCs with Schüffner’s dots and tertian fever (every third day) indicates Plasmodium vivax infection. This species is known for forming hypnozoites—dormant liver stages that can cause relapses.

A 28-year-old male from Odisha, an endemic region for malaria, presents with intermittent fever with chills and sweating every third day. The peripheral smear shows enlarged red blood cells with Schüffner’s dots, which is a key morphologic clue pointing toward Plasmodium vivax.

P. vivax infects young RBCs, causes them to enlarge and display Schüffner's stippling, and is responsible for tertian malaria (fever every 48 hours). A crucial biological feature of P. vivax is its ability to form hypnozoites—latent forms in the liver that can reactivate weeks to months after the primary infection and cause relapsing malaria. Treatment with chloroquine alone does not eradicate hypnozoites; primaquine is required for radical cure.

Feature Plasmodium vivax
RBC preference Young RBCs; causes enlargement
RBC features Schüffner’s dots
Fever pattern Every third day (tertian)
Relapse potential Yes — due to hypnozoites
Gametocyte shape Round or oval (not banana-shaped)

 

It infects RBCs of all ages and shows multiple ring forms (Option A):
Incorrect. This describes Plasmodium falciparum, not vivax. Vivax prefers young RBCs and does not show multiple ring forms.

It causes quartan fever and is associated with nephrotic syndrome (Option B):
Incorrect. Plasmodium malariae is responsible for quartan fever (every 72 hours) and may cause chronic kidney complications.

It produces banana-shaped gametocytes visible in peripheral blood (Option D):
Incorrect. Banana- or crescent-shaped gametocytes are characteristic of Plasmodium falciparum, not vivax.

questions.text: Which of the following fiber tracts projects to the ventral posterior nucleus of the thalamus?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Medial lemniscus

The medial lemniscus is a major ascending tract in the dorsal column-medial lemniscal pathway. It carries:

  • Fine touch

  • Vibration

  • Proprioception

...from the body (below the neck) via the gracile and cuneate nuclei, then crosses over in the medulla and ascends as the medial lemniscus to terminate in the ventral posterolateral (VPL) nucleus of the thalamus.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A - Lateral lemniscus:
    Part of the auditory pathway, it carries sound information to the inferior colliculus, and eventually to the medial geniculate body — not the VP nucleus of the thalamus.

  • Option C - Corticospinal tract:
    A descending motor tract, not involved in sensory transmission and does not project to the thalamus.

  • Option D - Spinal lemniscus:
    This term generally includes spinothalamic tracts, which carry pain and temperature sensations to the VPL nucleus of the thalamus — it contributes, but medial lemniscus is more directly named in this context.

questions.text: A malnourished patient is started on a carbohydrate-rich diet and subsequently develops metabolic acidosis with elevated lactate levels. Which vitamin deficiency is most likely contributing to this metabolic derangement?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Thiamine:

  • Thiamine (vitamin B1) is converted in the body to thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP), which functions as a crucial coenzyme for the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex (PDH).
  • In thiamine deficiency, the conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA is blocked.
  • As a result, pyruvate is instead converted to lactate via lactate dehydrogenase, leading to the accumulation of lactic acid in the blood — a hallmark of lactic acidosis.
  • This condition is especially pronounced when thiamine-deficient patients receive glucose loads (e.g., refeeding syndrome).

questions.text: A 62-year-old obese woman, G3P3, presents with a 3-month history of intermittent postmenopausal vaginal bleeding. She has a history of type 2 diabetes and hypertension. Transvaginal ultrasound reveals an endometrial thickness of 15 mm.What is the most appropriate next diagnostic step for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Hysteroscopy with directed biopsy:

In a postmenopausal woman with vaginal bleeding and increased endometrial thickness (>4-5 mm), hysteroscopy with directed biopsy is the most accurate diagnostic procedure to evaluate for endometrial pathology, including hyperplasia or carcinoma.

Evaluation of Postmenopausal Bleeding and Endometrial Thickening

Aspect Details
Clinical Presentation Postmenopausal vaginal bleeding is a red flag for endometrial pathology; risk factors include obesity, diabetes, hypertension.
Endometrial Thickness >4-5 mm thickness on transvaginal ultrasound in postmenopausal women warrants further evaluation.
Diagnostic Procedures Hysteroscopy with directed biopsy allows direct visualization and targeted sampling of endometrium, increasing diagnostic accuracy.
Alternative Procedures Dilation and curettage (D&C) samples endometrium blindly and may miss focal lesions; less preferred.
Medical Management Oral progestin therapy is not diagnostic and may mask pathology; reserved for confirmed hyperplasia without atypia or as treatment.
Follow-up Imaging Repeat ultrasound without biopsy is inappropriate in symptomatic postmenopausal bleeding with thickened endometrium.

 

Repeat transvaginal ultrasound in 3 months (Option A):
Delay in diagnosis risks missing malignancy; not appropriate.

Oral progestin therapy (Option C):
Not a diagnostic tool; inappropriate as initial management.

Dilation and Curettage (Option D):
Blind sampling; less sensitive than hysteroscopy-guided biopsy.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man with known HIV infection (CD4 count: 45 cells/µL) presents with a 1-month history of chronic diarrhea, lower abdominal pain, and significant unintentional weight loss. Physical examination reveals mild tenderness in the left iliac fossa. Given the clinical suspicion of CMV colitis, which of the following is the most definitive diagnostic test?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Colonoscopy with mucosal biopsy:

Explanation:

Colonoscopy with mucosal biopsy is the gold standard for diagnosing CMV colitis, allowing direct visualization of mucosal lesions and histopathological confirmation by identifying characteristic CMV inclusion bodies.

CMV Colitis in HIV Patients

Topic Details
Etiology CMV (Cytomegalovirus) is a herpesvirus causing opportunistic infections in immunocompromised hosts, especially with CD4 counts < 50 cells/µL.
Clinical Features Chronic diarrhea, lower abdominal pain, significant weight loss, possible fever or rectal bleeding.
Pathophysiology CMV infects colonic mucosal cells causing ulcerations, inflammation, and colitis.
Diagnostic Modalities Serum CMV IgG indicates prior exposure, not active disease. Urine CMV DNA PCR shows viral shedding but is nonspecific. Plasma CMV PCR detects viremia but cannot localize infection. Colonoscopy with biopsy visualizes ulcers and provides tissue for histology, showing enlarged cells with “owl’s eye” inclusions.
Treatment Intravenous ganciclovir or oral valganciclovir, alongside immune reconstitution with antiretroviral therapy.
Prognosis Dependent on immune recovery; untreated CMV colitis has high morbidity and mortality.

 

Serum CMV IgG (Option A):
Indicates previous infection; not diagnostic for active CMV colitis.

Urine CMV DNA PCR (Option B):
Reflects viral shedding but does not confirm colonic involvement.

Plasma CMV PCR (Option C):
Detects systemic viremia but cannot localize infection to the colon.

questions.text: The type of connective tissue present in the arrow-marked area is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Dense irregular

The dermis of the skin is composed primarily of dense irregular connective tissue, which is characterized by:

  • Collagen fibers arranged in multiple directions (random orientation)

  • Provides tensile strength in various directions

  • Contains fibroblasts, macrophages, and mast cells

  • Located in areas subjected to multidirectional mechanical stress

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Loose and irregular

  • Found in lamina propria, around blood vessels, and under epithelial linings

  • Has more ground substance and fewer fibers – not suitable for tensile strength

Option B - Specialized connective tissue

  • Includes bone, cartilage, adipose tissue, blood, etc.

  • Not a classification for the dermis

Option D - Dense regular

  • Collagen fibers arranged in parallel rows

  • Found in tendons and ligaments, providing strength in one direction only

questions.text: All of the following diuretics inhibit the Na⁺–K⁺–2Cl⁻ symporter, except:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Thiazide

Explanation:

Thiazide diuretics act on the Na⁺–Cl⁻ symporter in the early distal convoluted tubule, not on the Na⁺–K⁺–2Cl⁻ symporter, which is targeted by loop diuretics such as furosemide, ethacrynic acid, and mersalyl. Therefore, thiazide is the exception in this list.

Option Target Site & Transporter Inhibits Na⁺–K⁺–2Cl⁻? Notes
Furosemide (A) Thick ascending limb of loop of Henle → Na⁺–K⁺–2Cl⁻ symporter Yes Classical loop diuretic
Thiazide (B) Early distal convoluted tubule → Na⁺–Cl⁻ symporter No Acts at a different site
Ethacrynic acid (C) Thick ascending limb → Na⁺–K⁺–2Cl⁻ symporter Yes Non-sulfa loop diuretic
Mersalyl (D) Loop of Henle → Na⁺–K⁺–2Cl⁻ symporter Yes Mercury-based obsolete loop diuretic

 

Furosemide (Option A):
A loop diuretic that inhibits the Na⁺–K⁺–2Cl⁻ symporter in the thick ascending limb.
Ruled out.

Ethacrynic acid (Option C):
A non-sulfonamide loop diuretic that also inhibits the Na⁺–K⁺–2Cl⁻ symporter in the loop of Henle.
Ruled out.

Mersalyl (Option D):
An obsolete organomercurial loop diuretic that inhibits the Na⁺–K⁺–2Cl⁻ symporter.
Ruled out.

questions.text:
A 34-year-old HIV-positive male with a CD4 count of 85/mm³ presents with severe odynophagia and retrosternal chest pain. He denies any oral lesions. An upper GI endoscopy is performed, and the image below is obtained:



Which of the following features best supports the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Concentric esophageal rings with mucosal furrows on endoscopy
Dense infiltration of eosinophils in mucosal biopsy with food impaction history
Biopsy from the ulcer edge showing multinucleated giant cells with ground-glass nuclei
Biopsy showing budding yeast with pseudohyphae on PAS staining

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Biopsy from the ulcer edge showing multinucleated giant cells with ground-glass nuclei:

This HIV-positive patient with CD4 <200, odynophagia, retrosternal pain, and an endoscopic image showing well-demarcated, "punched-out" esophageal ulcers, is most consistent with Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) esophagitis. The classic histological finding is multinucleated giant cells with ground-glass nuclear inclusions.

HSV Esophagitis :

  • Common in immunocompromised patients, especially HIV with CD4 <200/mm³

  • Symptoms: Severe odynophagia, retrosternal chest pain; oral lesions may be absent

  • Endoscopy:

    • Well-circumscribed, "volcano-like" or punched-out ulcers

    • Usually in distal esophagus

  • Histology (Tzanck smear or biopsy):

    • Multinucleated giant cells

    • Ground-glass nuclei

    • Cowdry type A inclusions

 

Concentric esophageal rings with mucosal furrows (Option A):
Seen in eosinophilic esophagitis, often in younger patients with allergic history and food impaction, not typical in advanced HIV.

Dense infiltration of eosinophils in mucosal biopsy with food impaction (Option B):
Also refers to eosinophilic esophagitis, which doesn’t cause discrete punched-out ulcers.

Biopsy showing budding yeast with pseudohyphae on PAS (Option D):
Characteristic of Candida esophagitis, which presents with white plaques, not discrete ulcers.

questions.text: A 11-month-old child is brought to the clinic with loose stools for 2 days. He is alert and drinks eagerly. His skin pinch goes back slowly. What is the appropriate fluid management for this child?

choices.text: Give ORS 10mL/kg with each loose stool
Give ORS 75 mL/kg over first 4 hours and 10mL/kg with each loose stool
IV Ringer lactate with 5% Dextrose: ORS 30 mL/kg over first 30 minutes and then at 70 mL/kg over next 2.5 hours
IV Ringer lactate with 5% Dextrose: 70 mL/kg over first 30 minutes and then at 70mL/kg over next 2.5 hours

questions.solution:
Correct Option B -Give ORS 75 mL/kg over first 4 hours and 10mL/kg with each loose stool:

  • This is a case of mild dehydration, based on WHO classification.

Management includes:

  • ORS solution
  • Dose: 75 mL/kg over first 4 hours
  • Replace ongoing fluid loss: 10mL/kg with each loose stool

Incorrect Options:

Option A: It is not adequate to treat some dehydration.

Option C: It is used to treat severe dehydration.

Option D: It is not the management of some dehydration.

questions.text: A 50-year-old chronic alcoholic is admitted after stopping alcohol abruptly. Three days later, he becomes confused, disoriented, and starts seeing snakes on the wall. His BP is 160/100 mmHg, pulse is 120/min, and he is sweating profusely. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Delirium tremens:

  • Delirium tremens (DTs) is the most severe form of alcohol withdrawal, usually seen 48–72 hours after the last drink. It is characterized by confusion, agitation, visual hallucinations, and autonomic instability.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Wernicke’s encephalopathy involves a triad of confusion, ophthalmoplegia, and ataxia, mainly due to thiamine deficiency.

Option B: Marchiafava-Bignami Syndrome involves epilepsy, ataxia, hallucinations, and dysarthria.

Option D: Korsakoff’s syndrome involves amnesia and confabulation in chronic thiamine deficiency.

questions.text: A 22-year-old female with a history of multiple severe allergies to peanuts accidentally ingests food containing peanuts. Within minutes, she develops generalized urticaria, facial angioedema, wheezing, and lightheadedness. Her blood pressure drops to 80/50 mmHg. What is the single most appropriate immediate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Intramuscular epinephrine:

Explanation:

Intramuscular epinephrine is the first-line, life-saving treatment for anaphylaxis. It rapidly reverses airway obstruction, vasodilation, and hypotension by stimulating alpha- and beta-adrenergic receptors.

Anaphylaxis: Overview and Management

Aspect Details
Definition A severe, rapid-onset systemic allergic reaction involving multiple organ systems; potentially fatal.
Common Triggers Foods (e.g., peanuts), insect stings, medications, latex.
Clinical Features Generalized urticaria, facial angioedema, wheezing, hypotension, lightheadedness, and shock.
Pathophysiology IgE-mediated mast cell and basophil degranulation releasing histamine and other mediators causing vasodilation, bronchospasm, and increased vascular permeability.
Immediate Treatment Intramuscular epinephrine administered promptly in the mid-outer thigh.
Adjunctive Treatments Corticosteroids and antihistamines help prevent prolonged or biphasic reactions but act too slowly to be initial therapy.
Supportive Care Airway management, oxygen supplementation, intravenous fluids for hypotension, and monitoring for biphasic reactions.

 

Intravenous corticosteroids (Option A):
Useful to prevent late-phase allergic reactions but too slow to serve as initial treatment.

Intravenous H1 antihistamines (Option B):
Help relieve urticaria and itching but do not reverse airway obstruction or shock.

Nebulized albuterol (Option D):
Relieves bronchospasm but does not address hypotension or systemic vasodilation.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male from an endemic area presents with vague right upper quadrant pain. An abdominal ultrasound is performed, which reveals a well-defined hepatic cyst with multiple internal daughter cysts, giving it a "honeycomb" or "wagon-wheel" appearance. According to the Gharbi classification of hepatic hydatid cysts, what type does this represent?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Type III:

  • The ultrasound finding of a hepatic cyst with multiple internal daughter cysts or a "honeycomb" / "wagon-wheel" appearance is the defining characteristic of a Gharbi Type III hydatid cyst.
  • Gharbi’s classification of Hydatid cyst
    • Type I (Simple Cyst): A purely anechoic (fluid-filled), unilocular cyst with well-defined walls. Represents an active, early-stage cyst.
    • Type II (Cyst with Detached Endocyst): A cyst with a detached, undulating endocyst membrane floating within the fluid, often described as a "water lily" sign. Also represents an active stage.
    • Type III (Cyst with Septations/Daughter Cysts): Characterized by multiple internal daughter cysts, septations, or a "honeycomb" appearance. Represents a maturing or mature active cyst, as described in the clinical vignette.
    • Type IV (Heterogeneous Solid/Liquid): A heterogeneous, predominantly solid or mixed echogenic mass with irregular walls and internal echoes, often described as a "pseudo-tumor" appearance.
    • Type V (Calcified Cyst): A largely or completely calcified lesion with posterior acoustic shadowing. This represents an inactive or dead cyst

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B , and D are incorrect.

questions.text: A 1-year-old child presents with bluish discoloration of lips and nails during crying and feeding. Examination shows a harsh systolic murmur in the left upper sternal border. His chest X-ray is given below. What is the definitive treatment?

choices.text: VSD closure & repair of pulmonary stenosis

questions.solution:
Correct Option C -VSD closure & repair of pulmonary stenosis:

The clinical features - cyanosis during crying/feeding, harsh systolic murmur at the left upper sternal border, and the characteristic "boot-shaped heart" on chest X-ray - are classic for Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF). The definitive treatment is surgical correction, which includes closure of the ventricular septal defect (VSD) and relief of right ventricular outflow tract (RVOT) obstruction (usually due to pulmonary stenosis).

Tetralogy of Fallot: Features and Definitive Management

Feature Description
Classic Tetralogy Components 1. VSD
2. Pulmonary stenosis (RVOT obstruction)
3. Overriding aorta
4. Right ventricular hypertrophy
Clinical Signs Cyanosis, especially during crying/feeding ("tet spells"), harsh systolic murmur (pulmonary stenosis)
Chest X-ray Finding Boot-shaped heart (coeur en sabot) due to RVH and upturned apex
Definitive Treatment Intracardiac repair: VSD closure and RVOT/pulmonary stenosis relief (e.g., infundibular resection, patch)
Timing of Surgery Typically done between 6 months to 1 year of age or earlier if spells are severe
Temporary Palliation (if needed) Blalock–Taussig shunt (for unstable cyanotic neonates before full repair)

 

Balloon atrial septostomy (Option A):
Used for transposition of the great arteries (TGA) to improve mixing — not indicated in TOF.

Coil embolization (Option B):
Used for closing small abnormal vessels like PDA or AV malformations — not relevant to TOF management.

Arterial switch operation (Option D):
Definitive surgery for TGA, not TOF.

questions.text: A patient of rheumatoid arthritis was on DMARDs for 7 years. Fundus examination revealed the features shown in the image. Which of the following is the likely drug responsible for these findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Hydroxychloroquine

Explanation:

Bull’s eye maculopathy is a classic and characteristic finding of hydroxychloroquine-induced retinal toxicity. It occurs due to drug accumulation in the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE), especially after long-term use (usually >5 years) or high cumulative doses. Hydroxychloroquine is a DMARD commonly used in rheumatoid arthritis.

Drug Ocular Toxicity? Explanation
Methotrexate Rare, not typical More commonly causes hepatotoxicity, mucositis, bone marrow suppression
Hydroxychloroquine Yes — Bull’s eye maculopathy Causes retinal pigment epithelium damage after long-term use
Leflunomide No known retinal toxicity Associated with hepatotoxicity, hypertension
Sulfasalazine Rare ocular side effects More likely to cause rash, hemolysis in G6PD deficiency

 

Methotrexate (Option A):
Incorrect. Methotrexate can cause many systemic side effects, but not typical retinal toxicity like bull’s eye maculopathy.

Leflunomide (Option C):
Incorrect. While used in RA, leflunomide does not cause retinal toxicity.

Sulfasalazine (Option D):
Incorrect. Not associated with retinal changes; side effects are mostly gastrointestinal, hematologic, and hypersensitivity-related.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with frequent bulky, foul-smelling stools, failure to gain weight, and repeated episodes of cough with expectoration. On examination, there is clubbing and crackles in bilateral lungs. A sweat chloride test shows levels of 80 mmol/L. Which of the following is a new drug approved for managing this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Ivacaftor:

  • The clinical scenario is suggestive of Cystic Fibrosis, an autosomal recessive disorder due to CFTR gene mutation, which leads to defective chloride transport, causing thick secretions affecting lungs and pancreas. Ivacaftor is a newly approved drug for cystic fibrosis that acts by increasing the conductance of chloride ions.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Taletrectinib is a kinase inhibitor indicated for the treatment of adult patients with locally advanced or metastatic ROS1-positive non-small cell lung cancer.

Option B: Meloxicam is a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) for use in the management of moderate-to-severe pain.

Option C: Acoltremon is a first-in-class TRPM8 thermoreceptor agonist indicated for the treatment of xerophthalmia.

questions.text: The transfer of drug resistance in S. pneumoniae primarily occurs through which mechanism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Transformation:

  • S. pneumoniae is naturally competent and primarily acquires antibiotic resistance by transformation, taking up naked DNA from the environment and incorporating it into its genome.

Horizontal Gene Transfer (HGT) in Bacteria

This question falls under Microbiology → Bacterial Genetics → Mechanisms of Antibiotic Resistance Acquisition, specifically within the context of Horizontal Gene Transfer (HGT) — the movement of genetic material between organisms other than by vertical transmission (from parent to offspring).

Comparative Table of HGT Mechanisms:

Feature Transformation Conjugation Transduction
Definition Uptake of naked DNA from environment Direct DNA transfer via sex pilus DNA transfer via bacteriophage
Mediated by Competence proteins Conjugative plasmids, pili Bacteriophage (virus infecting bacteria)
Requires Cell Contact No Yes No
Plasmid Involvement Not necessary Yes (plasmid-based) No
Common in Naturally competent bacteria (e.g., S. pneumoniae) Mostly Gram-negative rods (e.g., E. coli) Wide range; phage-host dependent
Clinical Relevance Spread of resistance in S. pneumoniae (e.g., altered PBPs) Spread of multi-drug resistance via plasmids Transfer of toxin/virulence genes
Example Organisms Streptococcus pneumoniae, Neisseria E. coli, Klebsiella Salmonella, Corynebacterium diphtheriae

Conjugation (Option B):
Requires sex pili and plasmids, typical of Gram-negative bacteria. S. pneumoniae is Gram-positive and lacks this machinery.

Transduction (Option C):
Though possible in theory, it is not the predominant method for resistance transfer in S. pneumoniae.

Horizontal transmission (Option D):
Non-specific umbrella term that includes all the above mechanisms. Not a mechanism itself.

questions.text: Which of the following acts as the intermediate host in South American Trypanosomiasis?
questions.solution:
In South American Trypanosomiasis (Chagas disease), the Reduviid bug (also called Triatomine bug or kissing bug) acts as the intermediate host. It harbors the infective trypomastigote form of Trypanosoma cruzi, which is transmitted to humans when the bug's feces contaminate the bite site.

Trypanosoma cruzi is the protozoan responsible for Chagas disease, endemic in South America. It follows an indirect life cycle with two hosts:

  • Definitive host: Human (where the parasite undergoes sexual reproduction and causes disease)

  • Intermediate host/vector: Reduviid bug, where the parasite undergoes part of its developmental cycle.

Transmission occurs when the bug takes a blood meal and defecates near the bite site; the trypomastigotes in feces enter the human host through the wound or mucous membranes.

Host Role in Life Cycle
Man Definitive host; harbors replicating amastigotes
Tsetse fly Incorrect vector — involved in African trypanosomiasis (T. brucei)
Armadillo Reservoir host; can carry T. cruzi but not intermediate
Reduviid bug Intermediate host; transmits T. cruzi

 

Man (Option A):
Incorrect. Humans are the definitive host, not intermediate.

Tsetse fly (Option B):
Incorrect. Vector for Trypanosoma brucei (African sleeping sickness), not T. cruzi.

Armadillo (Option C):
Incorrect. May act as a reservoir, not an intermediate host.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes is deficient in the benign condition known as essential fructosuria?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Ketohexokinase

  • Essential fructosuria is a benign, asymptomatic metabolic disorder characterized by the accumulation of fructose in the blood and its excretion in the urine following fructose ingestion.
  • This condition is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme fructokinase (also known as ketohexokinase), primarily found in the liver, kidney, and small intestine.
  • Without fructokinase, fructose cannot be rapidly phosphorylated to fructose-1-phosphate, leading to its systemic accumulation and excretion.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Aldolase B: Deficiency leads to Hereditary Fructose Intolerance (HFI), a severe, symptomatic disorder.

Option C - Fructose-1,6-bisphosphatase: Deficiency causes Hereditary Fructose-1,6-bisphosphatase Deficiency, resulting in severe fasting hypoglycemia and metabolic acidosis.

Option D - Triose kinase: Deficiency of this enzyme is not associated with essential fructosuria.

questions.text: Which of the following cannot be measured using the device shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure:

  • The instrument in the image is a Swan-Ganz catheter, and it does not measure pulmonary capillary wedge pressure.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and C can be measured using the Swanz Ganz catheter.

questions.text: A 58-year-old multiparous woman, G4P4, presents with a sensation of "something coming down" from her vagina, especially when coughing or standing for prolonged periods. She also reports difficulty with defecation, requiring manual splinting. On examination, a bulge is noted from the posterior vaginal wall. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for the patient's primary complaint related to defecation difficulty?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Rectocele:

A rectocele is a herniation of the rectum into the posterior vaginal wall. It typically presents with a bulge from the posterior wall and difficulty in defecation, often requiring digital splinting of the vaginal wall.

Pelvic Organ Prolapse Types and Clinical Features

Type of Prolapse Anatomical Defect Key Clinical Features
Cystocele Herniation of the bladder into the anterior vaginal wall Urinary incontinence, frequency, urgency, anterior vaginal wall bulge
Uterine Prolapse Descent of the uterus into or beyond the vaginal canal Sensation of something coming down, visible cervix at or beyond introitus
Rectocele Herniation of rectum into the posterior vaginal wall Difficulty with defecation, feeling of incomplete evacuation, manual splinting
Enterocele Herniation of small bowel into the upper posterior vaginal wall Vague pelvic pressure, often post-hysterectomy, upper posterior wall bulge

 

Cystocele (Option A):
Causes anterior vaginal wall bulge and urinary complaints — not primarily defecation-related.

Uterine Prolapse (Option B):
May cause a general bulge but does not typically lead to splinting or defecation difficulty.

Enterocele (Option D):
Presents as upper posterior bulge, usually after hysterectomy; symptoms less specifically related to defecation.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child, who has never received any vaccinations, visits a Primary Health Centre (PHC) immunization clinic for the first time. Which of the following is the most appropriate set of immunizations to be given?

choices.text: BCG, DPT-1, OPV-1, Measles, Vitamin A

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - DPT-1, OPV-1, Measles, Vitamin A:

  • Correct – This includes DPT (against diphtheria, pertussis, tetanus), OPV (oral polio vaccine), Measles, and Vitamin A, which are all appropriate for a 3-year-old beginning catch-up immunization.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - BCG, Measles, Vitamin A: Incorrect – This omits DPT and OPV, which are essential components of the primary immunization schedule for a 3-year-old. BCG at this age has less utility, especially in the absence of Mantoux testing or TB exposure.

Option B - DT-1, OPV-1, Measles, Vitamin A: Incorrect – DT is used as a booster or substitute for DPT in children above 5 years, not in 3-year-olds. This option skips necessary DPT protection.

Option C - BCG, DPT-1, OPV-1, Measles, Vitamin A: Incorrect – BCG is not routinely given after age 1 unless there's a compelling reason (e.g., high TB risk). At 3 years, it's not indicated routinely.

questions.text:
Match the following adverse effects with their most likely anti-tubercular drug causes:


	
		
			
			Adverse Effect
			
			
			Drug
			
		
		
			
			A. Optic neuritis
			
			
			1. Rifampicin
			
		
		
			
			B. Hepatotoxicity
			
			
			2. Bedaquiline
			
		
		
			
			C. Hearing loss
			
			
			3. Streptomycin

			 
			
		
		
			
			D. QT Prolongation
			
			
			4. Ethambutol
questions.solution:
Correct Option A: A – (4), B – (1), C – (3), D – (2)

Explanation:

Each listed adverse effect is a well-known, drug-specific complication of first-line or second-line antitubercular therapy:

  • Ethambutol → Optic neuritis (reversible, dose-dependent, affects visual acuity and red-green color vision)

  • Rifampicin → Hepatotoxicity (can cause elevated liver enzymes and, in severe cases, liver failure)

  • Streptomycin → Hearing loss (an aminoglycoside, causes ototoxicity by damaging vestibulocochlear nerve)

  • Bedaquiline → QT prolongation (a newer drug for MDR-TB, known to prolong QT interval on ECG)

Topic Discussion:
Understanding the toxicity profiles of anti-tubercular drugs is critical, as most regimens are prolonged and multi-drug based. Monitoring for adverse effects ensures patient compliance and safety.

Drug Major Adverse Effect
Ethambutol Optic neuritis (reversible, early symptom: red-green color blindness)
Rifampicin Hepatotoxicity, red-orange body fluids, drug interactions via CYP450 induction
Streptomycin Ototoxicity – can cause hearing loss and balance issues (vestibulotoxic)
Bedaquiline QT prolongation – requires ECG monitoring, used for MDR/XDR TB

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient has well-established chronic hypertension with a consistent arterial blood pressure averaging 160/90 mmHg. If this patient suddenly experiences a further, acute increase in blood pressure to 180/100 mmHg, what is the expected response of their carotid sinus baroreceptors?

choices.text: Increase firing, trying to lower pressure to 120/80
Show no firing change, fully adapted to hypertension
Increase firing, trying to lower pressure to previous baseline

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Increase firing, trying to lower pressure to previous baseline:

  • In chronic hypertension, baroreceptors undergo resetting. The patient's consistent arterial pressure of 160/90 mmHg has become their new, reset physiological baseline around which their baroreceptors are operating.
    • When the blood pressure suddenly increases further from this 160/90 mmHg to 180/100 mmHg, the baroreceptors will respond by increasing their firing rate.
    • Their goal is to regulate pressure around their new, reset baseline. Therefore, they will try to lower the acutely elevated pressure (180/100 mmHg) back towards their previous chronic hypertensive baseline of 160/90 mmHg, not the original normotensive 120/80 mmHg.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Increase firing, trying to lower pressure to 120/80: This is incorrect. Baroreceptors reset in chronic hypertension and do not aim to return pressure to the original normotensive levels.

Option B - Show no firing change, fully adapted to hypertension: This is incorrect. While they adapt their baseline, they still respond to acute changes in pressure from that new baseline.

Option D - Decrease firing, signaling hypotension: This is incorrect. An increase in pressure would lead to an increase in firing, not a decrease.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with a generalized tonic-clonic seizure lasting more than 5 minutes. This is the first seizure episode. What is the first-line drug for management?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - IV Lorazepam:

  • This is a case of status epilepticus (seizure >5 min) that requires prompt benzodiazepine therapy:
  • IV lorazepam is preferred, but if not available, IV diazepam is used.

Incorrect Options

Options A, C, and D are preferred if medical management with IV lorazepam fails or if the seizures persists.

questions.text: A patient presents with acute bleeding. Bone marrow aspirate shows >20% blast cells, which are positive for Myeloperoxidase (MPO), and exhibit prominent primary granules as shown in the image. These findings are most strongly associated with which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation (DIC) 

The patient's acute bleeding, >20% MPO-positive blasts with prominent primary granules on microscopy is characteristic of Acute Promyelocytic Leukemia (APL / M3 subtype of AML). APL is strongly associated with DIC due to the release of procoagulant granule contents from the abnormal promyelocytes, triggering widespread coagulation and fibrinolysis.


Acute Promyelocytic Leukemia (APL) is a medical emergency due to its propensity to cause life-threatening coagulopathy:

  • Cytogenetics: t(15;17) → PML-RARA fusion gene

  • Cells: Promyelocytes with heavy granules and Auer rods

  • Stains: MPO-positive

  • Classic complication: DIC (often presents with bleeding diathesis)

  • Treatment: ATRA (all-trans retinoic acid) + arsenic trioxide; initiated immediately even before confirmation if APL is suspected

Tumor lysis syndrome (Option A):
More common in lymphoid leukemias/lymphomas with high tumor burden, particularly post-chemotherapy. Not the classic initial complication of APL.
Ruled out.

Hyperleukocytosis with leukostasis (Option C):
Seen in AML with very high WBC counts, especially monocytic variants (M4/M5). Not typically associated with APL.
Ruled out.

Splenomegaly and hypersplenism (Option D):
Seen in chronic leukemias, not acute leukemia like APL.
Ruled out.

questions.text: In a town, an outbreak of Hepatitis A occurred between June and August, with 60% of total cases concentrated in July. What is the most likely source of this outbreak?

choices.text: Single common source exposure of short duration
Single common source exposure of long duration
Multiple sources exposure of short duration
Multiple sources exposure of long duration

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Multiple sources exposure of long duration:

  • The spread over three months and concentration in one month (July) implies ongoing transmission from more than one source, e.g., recurring contamination from various water or food supplies.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Single common source exposure of short duration: Incorrect. A short-duration point source exposure typically causes a sharp peak in the epidemic curve over a short time span. It doesn't explain a 3-month-long outbreak.

Option B - Single common source exposure of long duration: Incorrect. A prolonged single-source outbreak would cause a gradual rise and fall in case numbers but is still tied to one contaminated source, not multiple.

Option C - Multiple sources exposure of short duration: Incorrect. Though multiple sources might cause cases in different locations, a short-duration exposure wouldn't sustain infections across three months.

questions.text: All of the following are correct statements regarding intravenous adrenergic drugs except:

choices.text: IV noradrenaline increases systolic and diastolic blood pressure and causes tachycardia
IV adrenaline increases systolic, decreases diastolic BP and causes tachycardia
IV isoproterenol increases systolic, decreases diastolic BP and causes tachycardia
Dopamine increases peripheral resistance and improves renal perfusion

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - IV noradrenaline increases systolic and diastolic BP and causes tachycardia:

Explanation:

Although IV noradrenaline raises both systolic and diastolic blood pressure due to strong α₁-mediated vasoconstriction, it usually leads to reflex bradycardia, not tachycardia. The increase in blood pressure activates baroreceptors, which in turn reduce heart rate through vagal stimulation.

Drug α₁ Action β₁ Action β₂ Action BP Effect HR Effect
Noradrenaline Strong ↑ Mild ↑ Minimal ↑ Systolic & ↑ Diastolic Reflex bradycardia
Adrenaline Moderate ↑ Strong ↑ Moderate ↓ (vasodilation) ↑ Systolic, ↓ Diastolic Tachycardia
Isoproterenol None Strong ↑ Strong ↓ ↑ Systolic, ↓ Diastolic, ↓ MAP Tachycardia
Dopamine (mod dose) Mild ↑ Moderate ↑ None ↑ MAP, renal perfusion preserved Mild ↑ or reflex ↑ HR

 

IV adrenaline increases systolic, decreases diastolic BP and causes tachycardia (Option B):
Correct. Adrenaline activates both β₁ and β₂ receptors, leading to increased systolic (β₁), decreased diastolic (β₂ vasodilation), and tachycardia (β₁).

IV isoproterenol increases systolic, decreases diastolic BP and causes tachycardia (Option C):
Correct. Isoproterenol is a pure β agonist, increasing systolic (β₁) and reducing diastolic BP (β₂). The drop in MAP causes reflex and direct tachycardia.

Dopamine increases peripheral resistance and improves renal perfusion (Option D):
Correct. At low doses, dopamine acts on D₁ receptors improving renal blood flow. At moderate to high doses, α₁-mediated vasoconstriction raises peripheral resistance and BP.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents with an uncomfortable crawling sensation in her legs that worsens during the evening and night, especially when lying down to sleep. She reports temporary relief after moving or shaking her legs. These symptoms have disrupted her sleep for the past few weeks. What is the most appropriate first-line treatment for her condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Pramipexole

Explanation:

The patient’s symptoms are classic for Restless Legs Syndrome (RLS): an unpleasant, crawling sensation in the legs, worse at rest and at night, and relieved by movement. The first-line treatment for moderate to severe RLS is a dopamine agonist such as pramipexole, which reduces the urge to move the legs and improves sleep quality.

Restless Legs Syndrome (RLS) is a sensorimotor neurological disorder characterized by:

  • An urge to move the legs

  • Unpleasant sensations (e.g., crawling, tingling)

  • Symptoms worsen at night and at rest

  • Relief with movement

First-line pharmacological treatment:

  • Dopamine agonists (e.g., pramipexole, ropinirole) are most effective for moderate-to-severe cases

  • Gabapentin/pregabalin are alternatives, especially in RLS with comorbid pain, anxiety, or insomnia

Other considerations:

  • Iron deficiency can be associated with RLS; hence, serum ferritin should be checked. Iron supplementation is only beneficial if ferritin is <75 ng/mL

  • Vitamin B12 deficiency can cause neuropathy but does not directly cause RLS

Gabapentin (Option B):
Used for RLS with neuropathic pain, but not first-line unless dopamine agonists are contraindicated or poorly tolerated.
Ruled out.

Vitamin B12 supplementation (Option C):
Helpful for peripheral neuropathies, but does not address RLS symptoms directly.
Ruled out.

Oral iron tablets (Option D):
Iron therapy is indicated only if serum ferritin is low (<75 ng/mL). Since no such data is provided, it is not first-line here.
Ruled out.

questions.text: In first-order kinetics, what percentage of a drug is eliminated after 3 half-lives?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 87.5%

In first-order kinetics, a constant fraction (not amount) of the drug is eliminated per unit time. After each half-life, 50% of the remaining drug is cleared. After 3 half-lives, 87.5% of the drug is eliminated.

In first-order kinetics:

Time (in half-lives) Drug Remaining (%) Drug Eliminated (%)
0 100% 0%
1 50% 50%
2 25% 75%
3 12.5% 87.5%
4 6.25% 93.75%
5 3.125% 96.875%

 

Thus, after 3 half-lives, 12.5% of the drug remains, and 87.5% has been eliminated.

12.5% (Option A): Incorrect. This is the amount of drug remaining, not eliminated.

75% (Option B): Incorrect. This corresponds to elimination after 2 half-lives.

94% (Option D): Incorrect. This corresponds to elimination after about 4 half-lives.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old man with poorly controlled diabetes presents with progressive, painless vision loss in both eyes. Fundus examination reveals microaneurysms, hard exudates at the macula, dot and blot hemorrhages in 3 quadrants, and intraretinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMA) in one quadrant.
Which of the following if additionally present, would NOT change the current management protocol?

choices.text: New-onset neovascularization on the optic disc

questions.solution:
Option: C. Venous beading in one quadrant

Involvement of venous beading in only one quadrant does not meet the threshold for severe non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR) and thus does not change current management. It is still classified as moderate NPDR when present in just one quadrant.

In diabetic retinopathy, disease severity guides treatment decisions:

  • Non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR) is divided into mild, moderate, and severe stages. Moderate NPDR includes findings like dot and blot hemorrhages in multiple quadrants and intraretinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMA) in up to one quadrant.

  • Severe NPDR is defined by the 4-2-1 rule:

    • 4 quadrants of hemorrhages/microaneurysms,

    • 2 or more quadrants of venous beading,

    • 1 or more quadrants of IRMA.
      Meeting any one of these qualifies as severe NPDR, which requires closer monitoring and may be a trigger for early pan-retinal photocoagulation (PRP) if vision is threatened.

  • Clinically significant macular edema (CSME) is a separate treatment indication irrespective of NPDR or proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR) status. It warrants intervention with focal/grid laser or anti-VEGF therapy.

  • Neovascularization, especially on the optic disc, is a hallmark of PDR and requires immediate treatment (usually with PRP or anti-VEGF) to reduce the risk of severe vision loss.

  • Vitreous hemorrhage, particularly when it obscures the macula, suggests active PDR with bleeding from fragile neovascular vessels. This mandates urgent evaluation and potential surgical or anti-VEGF therapy depending on the extent of hemorrhage and visual impairment.

New-onset neovascularization on the optic disc (Option A):
Defines proliferative diabetic retinopathy, and immediate treatment is indicated to prevent progression to tractional retinal detachment and irreversible vision loss.

Clinically significant macular edema (Option B):
Requires treatment even if retinopathy is not proliferative. Anti-VEGF injections or laser therapy is indicated to preserve central vision.

Vitreous hemorrhage obscuring the macula (Option D):
Represents a serious complication of PDR, often requiring vitrectomy or intravitreal anti-VEGF therapy.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male came for a pre-anesthetic checkup. What is the Modified Mallampatti class based on the given image?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Class III:

  • Only the hard and soft palates are visible, so it will be classified as class III according to the Modified Mallampati classification.

Incorrect Options:

Option |A - The hard palate, soft palate, uvula, tip of the uvula, and tonsillar pillars are visible in class I.

Option B - The hard palate, soft palate, uvula, and tonsillar pillars are visible in class II.

Option D - Only the hard palate is visible in class IV.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is FALSE regarding chronic maxillary sinusitis?

choices.text: A normal X-ray effectively excludes hypertrophic mucosa
FESS is indicated for failure of medical treatment or presence of sino-nasal polyp
Headache is absent except during exacerbation of acute sinusitis

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Headache is absent except during exacerbation of acute sinusitis

False. Headache or facial pressure can occur even in chronic sinusitis, not just during acute flare-ups.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Normal X-ray effectively excludes hypertrophic mucosa
True. Mucosal thickening or fluid levels are visible on X-ray; a normal X-ray excludes significant hypertrophy, though CT is more sensitive.

Option B -  FESS is indicated for failure of medical treatment or presence of sino-nasal polyp
True. Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery (FESS) is indicated when medical therapy fails or polyps block sinus drainage.

Option C - Patient complains of postnasal discharge
True. One of the most common complaints in chronic maxillary sinusitis is postnasal drip due to chronic mucosal inflammation.

questions.text: During thoracocentesis, which of the following muscles is NOT pierced by the needle?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Transversus thoracis

Thoracocentesis (pleural tapping) is commonly performed in the midaxillary line, typically between the 7th to 9th intercostal spaces, just above the upper border of the lower rib to avoid the neurovascular bundle.

In this lateral approach, the needle passes through:

  • Skin
  • Superficial fascia
  • External intercostal muscle
  • Internal intercostal muscle
  • Innermost intercostal muscle
  • Endothoracic fascia
  • Parietal pleura

The transversus thoracis is a thin muscle group located anteriorly on the inner surface of the chest wall, especially around the sternum. It includes muscle slips like the sternocostalis and subcostalis, and is not present laterally in the midaxillary line.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A - Internal intercostal:
    This muscle lies deep to the external intercostal and is definitely pierced in a lateral thoracocentesis.

  • Option B- External intercostal:
    The most superficial intercostal muscle and definitely pierced during the procedure.

  • Option C- Innermost intercostal:
    Lies deep to the internal intercostal and is pierced before entering the pleural cavity.

questions.text: Which of the following anticancer drugs is most likely to require dose adjustment or withholding during radiotherapy due to the risk of severe radiation toxicity (radiation recall syndrome)?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B – Dactinomycin:

Explanation

 

Dactinomycin is well-known to cause radiation recall syndrome, a severe inflammatory reaction in previously irradiated tissues, often triggered when the drug is administered after or during radiotherapy. It can lead to skin necrosis, ulceration, or severe dermatitis in the irradiated field.

Radiation recall syndrome is an acute inflammatory reaction confined to previously irradiated areas, triggered by certain chemotherapy agents given days to months later. Dactinomycin is the prototypical agent associated with this phenomenon.

Mechanism: Though not completely understood, it likely involves chemotherapy-induced reactivation of local tissue sensitivity to radiation.

Drug Radiation Recall Risk Notes
Dactinomycin High Classically causes radiation recall
Vincristine Low/None Neurotoxic, not radiosensitizing
Cyclophosphamide Minimal Not typically associated with recall reactions
6-Mercaptopurine None Myelosuppressive, not linked to recall

 

Vincristine (Option A):
Incorrect. Neurotoxic agent with no known association with radiation recall.

Cyclophosphamide (Option C):
Incorrect. An alkylating agent; can cause other toxicities (e.g. hemorrhagic cystitis), but not recall syndrome.

6-Mercaptopurine (Option D):
Incorrect. A purine analog causing myelosuppression, not radiation sensitization or recall.

questions.text: A starry sky appearance on Immunofluorescence is seen in?
questions.solution:
