The "starry sky" appearance on immunofluorescence is classically associated with Post-streptococcal Glomerulonephritis (PSGN).
On immunofluorescence, granular deposits of IgG and C3 appear scattered in the glomeruli, giving a pattern reminiscent of stars against a dark sky. This reflects immune complex deposition in the mesangium and along the basement membrane.

Starry Sky Appearance – A Contextual Comparison

Appearance Seen In Modality Explanation
Starry sky on histology Burkitt lymphoma H&E stain Macrophages (clear spaces) amid dense tumor cells resemble stars
Starry sky on immunofluorescence PSGN IF microscopy Granular immune complex deposits (IgG, C3) scattered in glomeruli
Granular IF (not starry sky) Membranous nephropathy IF microscopy Uniform subepithelial IgG/C3 deposition (spike and dome on EM)

 

 

  •  

Burkitt Lymphoma (Option A):

  • Modality: Histopathology (H&E stain), not immunofluorescence

  • Pattern: "Starry sky" due to tingible body macrophages scattered among sheets of rapidly dividing lymphocytes.

  • Why Incorrect: Although it shows a "starry sky" on histology, the question specifically asks about immunofluorescence, which is irrelevant here.

Diffuse Large B-Cell Lymphoma (DLBCL) (Option B):

  • Modality: Histopathology, IHC (immunohistochemistry)

  • Pattern: Does not characteristically show a starry sky appearance.

  • Why Incorrect: DLBCL shows diffuse sheets of large atypical B-cells, and no starry sky pattern on IF or histology. This option has no link to the description.

Membranous Nephropathy (Option D):

  • Modality: Immunofluorescence & Electron Microscopy

  • IF Pattern: Granular deposition of IgG and C3 along capillary loops

  • EM: Subepithelial spike and dome appearance

  • Why Incorrect: While IF is used, the appearance is not scattered like a starry sky. Instead, the deposits are uniform and linear in distribution over the basement membrane.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old child presents after a fall onto an outstretched hand. An X-ray was done, and the following findings were seen.



Given this type of injury, which of the following nerves is most commonly injured?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Anterior Interosseous Nerve (AIN):

  • The X-ray findings are classic for a supracondylar fracture of the humerus. Among the nerves commonly affected, the Anterior Interosseous Nerve (AIN), which is a pure motor branch of the median nerve, is the most frequently injured. Injury to the AIN typically results in the inability to flex the interphalangeal joint of the thumb and the distal interphalangeal joint of the index finger (pinch sign inability).

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: A 5-month-old infant is brought to the emergency department due to persistent vomiting, increasing irritability, and episodes of lethargy. Laboratory findings reveal elevated serum ammonia levels, and further genetic testing confirms an X-linked urea cycle disorder. Given this presentation, which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency:

  • Ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency is the most common urea cycle defect.
  • It is inherited in an X-linked recessive pattern, affecting males more severely.
  • Symptoms include vomiting, lethargy, irritability, and encephalopathy in neonates or infants.

Lab findings:

  • Hyperammonemia
  • Low citrulline
  • Elevated orotic acid in urine (due to carbamoyl phosphate excess shunting into pyrimidine pathway)

questions.text: A 25-year-old male from a region endemic for viral hepatitis presents for a routine health check. His serological markers for Hepatitis B virus (HBV) are as follows: HBsAg positive, Anti-HBc (total) positive, HBeAg negative, Anti-HBe positive, and HBV DNA undetectable. Based on these findings, what is the most appropriate management approach for this patient at this time?

choices.text: Initiate immediate antiviral therapy (e.g., Tenofovir or Entecavir).
Recommend liver biopsy to assess for cirrhosis.
Regular monitoring of liver function tests and HBV DNA, without immediate antiviral therapy.

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Regular monitoring of liver function tests and HBV DNA, without immediate antiviral therapy:

Explanation:

The patient's serological profile indicates an inactive hepatitis B carrier state with minimal or no viral replication (HBV DNA undetectable, HBeAg negative, anti-HBe positive). Such patients typically do not require immediate antiviral therapy but do need regular monitoring for any changes in viral activity or liver function.


Hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection has multiple phases, each defined by characteristic serological markers, viral load, and liver inflammation status.

  • Inactive Carrier State:

    • HBsAg positive, anti-HBc positive, HBeAg negative, anti-HBe positive.

    • HBV DNA levels are very low or undetectable.

    • Liver enzymes are usually normal.

    • Minimal or no active inflammation or fibrosis in the liver.

    • This phase carries a relatively good prognosis but requires regular follow-up to detect any reactivation.

  • Management Principles:

    • No immediate antiviral therapy if viral load is undetectable and liver function tests are normal.

    • Regular monitoring every 6–12 months with liver enzymes, HBV DNA levels, and liver imaging to screen for hepatocellular carcinoma, especially in high-risk patients.

    • Lifestyle advice includes avoidance of alcohol and hepatotoxic drugs.

  • When to Treat:

    • Elevated HBV DNA levels with abnormal liver enzymes.

    • Evidence of active hepatitis or liver fibrosis/cirrhosis.

    • HBeAg-positive chronic hepatitis with high viral replication.

 

Initiate immediate antiviral therapy (e.g., Tenofovir or Entecavir) (Option A):
Not indicated here because the patient is in an inactive carrier phase with undetectable HBV DNA and no evidence of active liver disease.

Recommend liver biopsy to assess for cirrhosis (Option B):
Not routinely required in asymptomatic inactive carriers with normal liver tests and low viral load.

Recommend a course of Interferon-alpha (Option D):
Interferon-alpha is generally reserved for patients with active viral replication and evidence of liver inflammation. It is not indicated in inactive carriers with undetectable HBV DNA because it can cause unnecessary side effects without benefit.

questions.text: A patient presents with Zollinger-Ellison syndrome due to a gastrinoma. He has two bleeding ulcers and diarrhea. Which of the following drugs irreversibly inhibits the H⁺/K⁺ ATPase in gastric parietal cells?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Omeprazole:

Explanation:

Omeprazole, a proton pump inhibitor (PPI), irreversibly inhibits the H⁺/K⁺ ATPase enzyme on the luminal surface of gastric parietal cells, which is the final step in acid secretion. This makes it the most effective agent for acid suppression, particularly in Zollinger-Ellison syndrome, where gastrin-secreting tumors cause excessive acid production, leading to refractory ulcers and diarrhea.

Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome – Key Points:

  • Caused by a gastrinoma (gastrin-secreting neuroendocrine tumor)

  • Leads to massive gastric acid hypersecretion

  • Presents with multiple peptic ulcers, diarrhea, and GERD-like symptoms

  • Requires potent acid suppression, usually with high-dose PPIs

  • H⁺/K⁺ ATPase is the final common pathway for gastric acid secretion

Rule Out Options:

Cimetidine (Option A):
H₂ receptor antagonist. It reversibly blocks histamine-mediated acid secretion, but does not inhibit the proton pump directly. Less potent than PPIs and not adequate for Zollinger-Ellison syndrome.
Ruled out.

Cisapride (Option B):
Prokinetic agent that acts via 5-HT₄ receptor agonism, enhances GI motility. No effect on acid secretion or proton pump inhibition.
Ruled out.

Glycopyrrolate (Option C):
Antimuscarinic drug. Reduces vagally mediated acid secretion via M3 receptor blockade, but again does not inhibit H⁺/K⁺ ATPase. Also has many anticholinergic side effects.
Ruled out.

Omeprazole (Option D):
Correct. A PPI that irreversibly inhibits the H⁺/K⁺ ATPase, leading to profound acid suppression- ideal for Zollinger-Ellison syndrome.
Chosen option.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most mitotically active layer of the skin?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - D

The layer labelled as D is the stratum basale, and it is the most mitotically active layer.

Incorrect options: Options A, B, and C are not the most metabolically active layers.

questions.text:
A 38-year-old female presents with chronic diarrhea, abdominal bloating, and unexplained weight loss for the past 6 months. She also reports recurrent aphthous ulcers. A preliminary workup for suspected celiac disease is initiated, and her serum Anti-tissue Transglutaminase (tTG) IgA antibody levels return as negative. Despite this, her physician maintains a high suspicion for celiac disease.

Which of the following conditions, if present, would necessitate further specific serological testing to reliably diagnose celiac disease, and what is the most appropriate antibody test in such a scenario?

choices.text: Concomitant Crohn's disease; Anti-Saccharomyces cerevisiae antibodies (ASCA)
Selective IgA deficiency; Anti-Deamidated Gliadin Peptide (DGP) IgG antibodies
Recent gluten-free diet adherence; Endomysial Antibodies (EMA) IgG
Small intestinal bacterial overgrowth (SIBO); Anti-Celiac disease autoantibodies (CDA) IgM

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Selective IgA deficiency; Anti-Deamidated Gliadin Peptide (DGP) IgG antibodies:

In patients with suspected celiac disease who have negative anti-tTG IgA but persistent symptoms, Selective IgA deficiency should be considered. It's the most common immunodeficiency in celiac patients, and can lead to false-negative IgA-based tests. In this case, IgG-based serologic tests such as anti-DGP IgG or tTG IgG are appropriate alternatives.

Clinical Context:

  • The patient has classic signs of celiac disease:

    • Chronic diarrhea

    • Weight loss

    • Bloating

    • Aphthous ulcers (common extraintestinal sign)

  • Anti-tTG IgA is the first-line test for celiac disease.

  • A negative result should prompt evaluation for IgA deficiency if suspicion remains high.

Selective IgA Deficiency in Celiac Disease:

  • Occurs in up to 2–3% of celiac patients (much higher than in the general population).

  • Leads to false-negative IgA-based antibody tests (like tTG IgA, EMA IgA).

  • IgG-based tests (especially anti-DGP IgG) are useful and reliable in this context.

Crohn’s disease & ASCA (Option A):
ASCA (Anti-Saccharomyces cerevisiae antibodies) is used as a marker in Crohn's disease, not celiac disease. It has no diagnostic role in confirming or excluding celiac disease.

Recent gluten-free diet & EMA IgG (Option C):
Starting a gluten-free diet can cause both tTG and EMA antibodies to normalize, leading to false-negative results regardless of the test isotype. Also, EMA IgG is less sensitive and specific than DGP IgG in this setting.

SIBO & CDA IgM (Option D):
SIBO (Small Intestinal Bacterial Overgrowth) can mimic malabsorption symptoms seen in celiac disease but is not diagnosed using celiac-specific antibodies. "CDA IgM" is not a recognized or validated test in the evaluation of celiac disease.

questions.text: A first-year anesthesia resident accidentally administers a high dose of lignocaine during a nerve block. What is the earliest sign of systemic lignocaine toxicity seen in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Perioral numbness:

  • The first sign of lignocaine toxicity is perioral numbness followed by tremors, seizures, and respiratory depression.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D are not the first signs noticed during lignocaine toxicity.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child develops wheezing, rhinitis, and conjunctival redness within minutes of exposure to pollen. Serum tryptase levels are elevated. Which of the following is most likely involved in the pathogenesis of this condition?

choices.text: Immune complex deposition and complement activation
Formation of granulomas by TH1 cells

questions.solution:
The child’s acute-onset symptoms—wheezing, rhinitis, conjunctival redness—immediately following pollen exposure, along with elevated serum tryptase, point to a Type I hypersensitivity reaction, mediated by IgE-triggered mast cell degranulation.

This presentation is classic for allergic (atopic) hypersensitivity, which is a Type I hypersensitivity reaction. The pathogenesis involves:

  1. Sensitization phase: Initial allergen exposure leads to the production of IgE antibodies that bind to FcεRI receptors on mast cells.

  2. Re-exposure phase: Allergen cross-links IgE on mast cells → degranulation → release of histamine, leukotrienes, prostaglandins, and tryptase.

  3. Clinical result: Immediate allergic symptoms like bronchospasm (wheezing), nasal congestion, tearing, itching, and urticaria.

Serum tryptase is a specific marker of mast cell activation and is elevated in Type I hypersensitivity, including anaphylaxis and allergic rhinitis.

Feature Findings in this case
Onset Immediate (within minutes)
Symptoms Wheezing, rhinitis, conjunctivitis
Trigger Pollen (environmental allergen)
Serum marker Tryptase ↑ (mast cell activation marker)
Immunologic mechanism IgE-mediated mast cell degranulation

 

Immune complex deposition and complement activation (Option A):
Incorrect. Describes Type III hypersensitivity, seen in diseases like serum sickness or SLE—not relevant here.

Cytotoxic T cell-mediated apoptosis (Option B):
Incorrect. Seen in Type IV hypersensitivity, such as contact dermatitis or graft rejection—delayed, not immediate.

Formation of granulomas by TH1 cells (Option D):
Incorrect. Seen in chronic inflammation (e.g., TB, sarcoidosis), involves TH1-mediated delayed response, not acute allergy.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, 5 days postpartum, becomes tearful, irritable, and anxious. She reports mood swings and difficulty sleeping. There are no suicidal thoughts or delusions. What is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Observe and reassure:

  • This is a case of postpartum blues, which typically occurs 3-5 days postpartum. It is self-limiting and managed with reassurance, support, and education.

Incorrect Options:

Option A & B: SSRIs and CBT are used for postpartum depression, not postpartum blues.

Option D: Lithium and antipsychotics are used for postpartum psychosis, not postpartum blues.

questions.text: A diabetic patient presents with uncontrolled blood sugar. He has a history of pancreatitis and a family history of urinary bladder carcinoma. He is allergic to sulfonylureas and is unwilling to take injectable drugs. Which of the following drugs can be safely added to control his blood sugar?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Canagliflozin

Canagliflozin, an SGLT-2 inhibitor, is an oral antidiabetic agent that reduces blood glucose by promoting glucosuria. It is not a sulfonylurea, is not injectable, and does not significantly increase pancreatitis risk. Although initial concerns existed regarding bladder cancer with some SGLT-2 inhibitors, canagliflozin is not specifically linked to increased bladder cancer risk (this concern was more with dapagliflozin). Therefore, canagliflozin can be safely used in this patient.

Diabetes Treatment Considerations in This Patient:

Clinical Factor Therapeutic Implication
History of pancreatitis Avoid GLP-1 agonists and DPP-4 inhibitors
Allergy to sulfonylureas Avoid glipizide and related drugs
Family history of bladder carcinoma Avoid agents with bladder cancer concerns (e.g. dapagliflozin)
Refusal of injectables Use only oral medications

Liraglutide (Option A):
Ruled out. Though effective, liraglutide is an injectable GLP-1 analog. The patient is unwilling to take injectables. Moreover, GLP-1 agonists are associated with increased risk of pancreatitis, making it unsuitable in a patient with past pancreatitis.

Sitagliptin (Option B):
Ruled out. Though oral and generally well tolerated, DPP-4 inhibitors like sitagliptin have been associated (albeit rarely) with pancreatitis in clinical studies. Given the patient's history of pancreatitis, it is best avoided.

Canagliflozin (Option C):
Correct. An oral SGLT-2 inhibitor. Not a sulfonylurea. Not injectable, and no strong evidence links it to bladder cancer. Also not associated with pancreatitis, making it safe in this patient.

Glipizide (Option D):
Ruled out. A sulfonylurea, and the patient has a known allergy to sulfonylureas.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a parameter included in the APGAR score?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Respiratory rate:

The APGAR score assesses a newborn's condition at 1 and 5 minutes after birth using five parameters, none of which is specifically “respiratory rate.” Instead, it evaluates respiratory effort, the quality of breathing, not the rate itself.

APGAR Score: Components and Interpretation

Parameter What It Measures Scoring (0–2) Details
Appearance (Color) Skin coloration 0 = Pale/blue; 1 = Blue extremities; 2 = Completely pink
Pulse Heart rate 0 = Absent; 1 = <100 bpm; 2 = ≥100 bpm
Grimace Reflex irritability (response to stimulation) 0 = No response; 1 = Grimace; 2 = Cough/sneeze/cry
Activity Muscle tone 0 = Limp; 1 = Some flexion; 2 = Active movement
Respiratory effort Breathing quality 0 = Absent; 1 = Slow/irregular; 2 = Good crying

 

Pulse (Option A):
Correct APGAR component; measures heart rate.

Grimace (Option C):
Correct APGAR component; evaluates reflex irritability.

Activity (Option D):
Correct APGAR component; assesses muscle tone.

questions.text: A new diagnostic test is introduced that can detect a disease one year earlier than the standard diagnostic timeline. It does not change the disease's natural history or mortality documentation practices. What is the most likely epidemiological impact observed over the next 10 years?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Apparent 5-year survival rate will increase:

Explanation:

  • The test detects the disease earlier without altering outcomes. This results in lead time bias: the patient is diagnosed earlier, making the survival interval appear longer even though the disease course and outcome remain the same. The true incidence, prevalence, and age-adjusted mortality rates remain unaffected, but the 5-year survival rate appears artificially improved due to earlier detection.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is scheduled for tonsillectomy. On the day of surgery, he presents with runny nose, dry cough, and low-grade fever (37.5°C). What is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Proceed with surgery next day after starting IV antibiotics and paracetamol
Proceed with surgery same day after starting IV antibiotics and paracetamol
Get a chest X-ray and proceed if normal
Cancel surgery for 3 weeks and start antibiotics

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Cancel surgery for 3 weeks and start antibiotics

  • Correct. Elective surgeries should be postponed for at least 3 weeks in children with symptoms of URI. Antibiotics are started only if bacterial infection is suspected.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A - Surgery should be done next day and child should be put on IV antibiotics and paracetamol
    This still risks anesthesia complications, especially laryngospasm and pulmonary aspiration, due to the active upper respiratory tract infection (URI).
     
  • Option B - Can proceed for surgery on the same day after starting IV antibiotics and paracetamol
    Tonsillectomy is an elective procedure, and proceeding during URI increases risks of bronchospasm, laryngospasm, and bleeding.
     
  • Option C - Get X-ray chest done and if normal proceed for surgery. A normal chest X-ray does not rule out upper airway sensitivity or inflammation. Surgery should be deferred regardless of CXR findings.

questions.text:
A 38-year-old nulliparous woman presents with heavy menstrual bleeding (menorrhagia) and pelvic pressure for the past 6 months. She also reports increased urinary frequency. On bimanual examination, the uterus is enlarged, firm, and irregularly shaped. Transvaginal ultrasound confirms multiple uterine fibroids, with the largest being 8 cm, located submucosally.

Considering her desire to preserve fertility, which of the following is the most appropriate surgical management option for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Laparoscopic Myomectomy:

Laparoscopic myomectomy is the preferred surgical option for women with symptomatic fibroids who wish to preserve fertility. It removes fibroids while retaining the uterus and has lower morbidity compared to open surgery.

Uterine Fibroids: Fertility-Preserving Management

Aspect Details
Clinical Features Menorrhagia, pelvic pressure, urinary frequency, enlarged irregular uterus.
Common Types Submucosal fibroids (projecting into the uterine cavity) are most associated with heavy bleeding and infertility.
Diagnostic Confirmation Transvaginal ultrasound is the first-line imaging for detecting fibroids and their location.
Preferred Surgical Option Laparoscopic myomectomy allows targeted removal of fibroids with minimal invasiveness, preserving uterine integrity for future fertility.
Alternative Options Hysteroscopic myomectomy may be used if fibroids are completely intracavitary.
Role of Other Treatments Total hysterectomy eliminates fertility. UAE may impair uterine blood flow. Endometrial ablation is contraindicated in women desiring future pregnancy.

 

Total Abdominal Hysterectomy (Option A):
Removes the uterus, permanently ending fertility; not appropriate for women desiring conception.

Uterine Artery Embolization (Option B):
May shrink fibroids but risks compromised uterine perfusion and is not recommended for women seeking fertility.

Endometrial Ablation (Option D):
Destroys the endometrial lining and is contraindicated in women who wish to conceive.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old man presents to the clinic with a two-week history of progressive bilateral lower limb edema and a 5 kg weight gain. Physical examination reveals pitting edema up to his mid-shins and mild ascites.

Laboratory studies are notable for:


	Serum Albumin: 1.8 g/dL (Normal: 3.5-5.5 g/dL)
	Urinalysis: 4+ protein
	24-hour urine protein: 10.5 g
	Serum Creatinine: 0.9 mg/dL


A renal biopsy is performed. Light microscopy and immunofluorescence studies are unremarkable. However, electron microscopy reveals diffuse effacement of podocyte foot processes.

Which of the following best describes the primary mechanism responsible for this patient's proteinuria?

choices.text: Deposition of IgA-containing immune complexes in the mesangium
Formation of subepithelial immune deposits and subsequent complement activation
Cytokine-mediated podocyte injury leading to loss of slit diaphragm integrity
Progressive glomerulosclerosis secondary to adaptive hyperfiltration

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Cytokine-mediated podocyte injury leading to loss of slit diaphragm integrity:

This patient's clinical features (massive proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, edema) and renal biopsy findings (normal LM & IF, but podocyte effacement on EM) are classic for Minimal Change Disease (MCD), where the primary mechanism of proteinuria is cytokine-induced podocyte injury, leading to slit diaphragm dysfunction and selective albuminuria.

Minimal Change Disease (MCD):

  • Most common nephrotic syndrome in children, but can also occur in adults.

  • Etiology: Often idiopathic, but may be associated with NSAIDs, Hodgkin lymphoma, or allergens.

  • Pathophysiology:

    • T-cell dysfunction leads to cytokine release (e.g., IL-13)

    • These cytokines cause podocyte (epithelial cell) injury

    • Leads to effacement of foot processes, seen only on electron microscopy

    • Loss of slit diaphragm integrity → massive proteinuria, mostly albumin

  • Biopsy findings:

    • Light Microscopy (LM): Normal

    • Immunofluorescence (IF): Negative

    • Electron Microscopy (EM): Diffuse podocyte foot process effacement

Deposition of IgA-containing immune complexes in the mesangium (Option A):
Describes IgA nephropathy, a nephritic syndrome with hematuria, not heavy proteinuria.

Formation of subepithelial immune deposits and complement activation (Option B):
Seen in membranous nephropathy, which shows subepithelial "spikes" on EM and granular IF - not consistent with this case.

Progressive glomerulosclerosis secondary to adaptive hyperfiltration (Option D):
Describes focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS), often with segmental sclerosis on LM - not normal as seen here.

questions.text:
A 36-year-old man presents with subtle difficulties reading and locating objects in the upper right field of view. Visual acuity is preserved. Fundus examination is normal. Visual field charting is shown below.



Based on the field defect, which of the following is the most probable site of the lesion?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Left parietal lobe – Baum’s loop

The visual field chart shows a right homonymous inferior quadrantanopia, indicating a lesion in the left parietal lobe, specifically in Baum’s loop, which carries fibers from the superior retina (inferior visual field).

The visual pathway beyond the optic chiasm is retinotopically organized, with fibers dividing into two major loops in the optic radiations:

  • Meyer's loop (temporal lobe):

    • Carries inferior retinal fibers (which represent superior visual field)

    • Lesion causes superior quadrantanopia (“pie in the sky”)

  • Baum’s loop (parietal lobe):

    • Carries superior retinal fibers (representing inferior visual field)

    • Lesion causes inferior quadrantanopia (“pie on the floor”)

In this case:

  • The right inferior visual field is affected in both eyes, indicating a left-sided post-chiasmal lesion.

  • The defect is congruous and respects the vertical meridian, which favors a lesion in the optic radiations rather than occipital cortex.

Left temporal lobe – Meyer's loop (Option A):
Lesion here would cause a right superior quadrantanopia, not an inferior one.

Right parietal lobe – Baum’s loop (Option B):
Would produce a left inferior quadrantanopia, which is not seen here.

Right temporal lobe – Meyer's loop (Option C):
Would result in a left superior quadrantanopia, inconsistent with the field defect.

questions.text: Identify the given instrument:
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Killian’s nasal speculum

The given image shows Killian’s self-retaining nasal speculum. It is used in nasal surgeries like septoplasty, FESS, and turbinoplasty.

Incorrect options:

Option A - Thudicum’s nasal speculum

Option B - Tiley’s nasal packing forceps

Option C - Luc’s forceps

questions.text:
A 58-year-old male presents to the emergency department with crushing central chest pain radiating to the left arm for the past 45 minutes. He is diaphoretic and anxious. He has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and smoking. On examination, his BP is 100/70 mmHg, HR is 92 bpm, and SpO₂ is 96% on room air. An ECG is obtained and shows the following:


	ST-segment elevation in leads V2 to V5
	Reciprocal ST depression in leads II, III, and aVF


Cardiac enzymes are pending.

Which of the following coronary arteries is most likely occluded?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Left anterior descending artery

ST-segment elevation in leads V2 to V5 indicates an anterolateral wall myocardial infarction, which is classically supplied by the left anterior descending (LAD) artery.

The ECG distribution of myocardial infarction helps localize the area of infarction and, by extension, the culprit coronary artery:

  • Leads V1–V4: Anterior wall (LAD)

  • Leads V3–V6, I, aVL: Anterolateral wall (LAD or diagonal branches)

  • Leads II, III, aVF: Inferior wall (usually right coronary artery – RCA)

  • Reciprocal ST depression in inferior leads (II, III, aVF) often supports a high anterior infarct

In this case:

  • ST elevation in V2 to V5 → Anterior and anterolateral wall

  • Reciprocal ST depression in inferior leads → Supports a significant anterior infarct

  • This pattern is classically due to LAD occlusion

Left circumflex artery (Option A):
Typically causes lateral wall infarction (leads I, aVL, V5–V6), not widespread anterior ST elevation.

Right coronary artery (Option B):
Usually causes inferior MI (ST elevation in II, III, aVF), which shows ST depression here — making RCA occlusion unlikely.

Posterior descending artery (Option D):
Supplies the posterior wall, typically seen as ST depression in V1–V3 (posterior equivalents). Not consistent with anterior ST elevation.

questions.text: In the given bacterial growth curve, which of the following phases denotes exotoxin production?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Phase C

Exotoxins are typically produced during the stationary phase (Phase C), when bacterial growth rate slows and nutrient levels begin to decline. In this phase, bacteria focus on survival and secondary metabolite production, including exotoxins.

Bacterial Growth Curve Phases and Their Characteristics:

Phase Name Duration Key Features
A Lag Phase ~0–2 hrs Bacteria adapt to environment; no division yet
B Log (Exponential) ~2–8 hrs Rapid cell division; antibiotics most effective here
C Stationary Phase ~8–24 hrs Nutrient depletion; growth = death; exotoxin production
D Death Phase ~24–48 hrs Cell death exceeds growth; toxin levels may persist

 

Exotoxins are actively secreted proteins, mostly by Gram-positive bacteria (e.g., Clostridium, Streptococcus, Staphylococcus), and are commonly released during the stationary phase, when metabolic stress triggers the production of virulence factors.

 

Phase A (Option A):
Lag phase – cells are metabolically active but not dividing; no toxin production occurs.

Phase B (Option B):
Log phase – active cell division; primary focus is on growth, not exotoxin secretion.

Phase C (Option C):
Correct phase – Stationary phase is associated with stress responses, including exotoxin production.

Phase D (Option D):
Death phase – cells die; while some residual toxins may remain, active production decreases.

questions.text: A patient presents with palpitations. Which of the following drugs is NOT indicated for the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Adenosine

The ECG strip provided shows an irregularly irregular rhythm with absence of P waves, which is diagnostic of atrial fibrillation (AF). In atrial fibrillation, adenosine is not indicated, as it has no effect on the chaotic atrial activity and may transiently worsen AV nodal conduction abnormalities or unmask accessory pathway conduction (as in WPW syndrome).

Drug Class Use in Atrial Fibrillation? Rationale
Amiodarone Class III antiarrhythmic Yes Used for rhythm control in atrial fibrillation
Propranolol Non-selective β-blocker Yes Used for rate control in AF by slowing AV nodal conduction
Verapamil Non-dihydropyridine CCB Yes Also used for rate control in AF
Adenosine AV nodal blocker No Not effective in AF; does not terminate atrial fibrillation and may worsen conduction via accessory pathways

 

Propranolol (Option B):
Correct. Effective β-blocker for controlling ventricular rate in AF.

Verapamil (Option C):
Correct. Also slows AV nodal conduction to reduce ventricular rate.

Adenosine (Option D):
Incorrect. Adenosine is ineffective in terminating AF, which originates from multiple atrial foci, and it is not recommended for this rhythm.

questions.text: Clonidine has the following attributes except:

choices.text: Can produce rebound hypertension on abrupt withdrawal

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Can produce CNS stimulation:

Explanation:

Clonidine is a centrally acting α₂-adrenergic receptor agonist, which inhibits sympathetic outflow from the CNS. This leads to CNS depression, not stimulation. Therefore, the statement that it can produce CNS stimulation is incorrect.

Property Present in Clonidine? Explanation
Acts on α₂ adrenergic receptors Yes Clonidine selectively stimulates central α₂ receptors → ↓ sympathetic tone
Rebound hypertension on withdrawal Yes Abrupt cessation leads to sudden sympathetic overactivity → rebound HTN
CNS stimulation No Clonidine causes CNS depression (sedation, fatigue), not stimulation
Inhibits salivation Yes By reducing parasympathetic activity and sympathetic tone

 

Acts on α2 adrenergic receptors (Option A):
Correct. Clonidine is a central α₂ agonist, reducing sympathetic outflow → ↓ BP.

Can produce rebound hypertension on abrupt withdrawal (Option B):
Correct. Sudden stoppage causes excessive sympathetic activity, leading to rebound hypertension.

Can produce CNS stimulation (Option C):
Incorrect. Clonidine causes sedation, drowsiness, and mental dulling, not stimulation.

Inhibits salivation (Option D):
Correct. It reduces salivary secretion by decreasing central sympathetic activity and may have mild anticholinergic-like effects.

questions.text:
A 14-year-old boy presents with a painless, gradually enlarging swelling in the floor of his mouth for 3 weeks. His mother reports that the swelling seems to fluctuate in size, especially while eating. On examination, the following findings were observed:



What is the treatment of choice?

choices.text: Excision of the ranula and the sublingual gland

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Excision of the ranula and the sublingual gland:

  • The clinical presentation of a painless, gradually enlarging, fluctuating, bluish, dome-shaped, translucent swelling on the floor of the mouth is classic for a ranula, which is a type of mucin extravasation cyst, typically originating from the sublingual gland.
  • For a definitive cure with minimal recurrence, the treatment of choice is excision of the ranula along with the ipsilateral sublingual gland, the source of the mucus leakage.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Incision and drainage: Offers temporary relief but has a very high recurrence rate.

Option B - Marsupialization: Less invasive but has a high recurrence rate, making it less definitive for long-term cure.

Option D - Aspiration with sclerotherapy: Aspiration alone is ineffective. Sclerotherapy can be an option, but excision of the gland is generally more definitive.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant is brought by parents due to poor feeding, hypotonia, and failure to thrive. On follow-up at 2 years, the child has developed obesity and developmental delay. What is the likely genetic defect in this child?

choices.text: Deletion of maternal genes on chromosome 17
Deletion of maternal genes on chromosome 15
Deletion of paternal genes on chromosome 17
Deletion of paternal genes on chromosome 15

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Deletion of paternal genes on chromosome 15:

The clinical picture is characteristic of Prader-Willi syndrome (PWS), which results from paternal deletion of genes in the 15q11–q13 region.

Prader-Willi Syndrome: Genetic Basis and Clinical Features

Feature Description
Genetic Defect Paternal deletion of chromosome 15q11–q13 or maternal uniparental disomy.
Inheritance Pattern Usually sporadic; involves genomic imprinting.
Early Clinical Features Hypotonia, poor suck/feeding difficulties, failure to thrive (infancy).
Later Clinical Features Hyperphagia, central obesity, developmental delay, intellectual disability, hypogonadism.
Facial Features Narrow bifrontal diameter, almond-shaped eyes, downturned mouth.
Diagnostic Confirmation Methylation studies or FISH (Fluorescence in situ hybridization).

 

Deletion of maternal genes on chromosome 17 (Option A):
Not associated with Prader-Willi syndrome.

Deletion of maternal genes on chromosome 15 (Option B):
This causes Angelman syndrome, not Prader-Willi. Presents with ataxia, seizures, and happy demeanor.

Deletion of paternal genes on chromosome 17 (Option C):
Not a known cause of either Prader-Willi or Angelman syndromes.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old male presents with a 4-month history of frequent bloody bowel movements (6–8 times per day) associated with urgency, tenesmus, and crampy lower abdominal pain. He reports mild fatigue and has lost 3 kg unintentionally. Physical examination reveals mild tenderness in the left lower quadrant. Laboratory studies show hemoglobin of 10.2 g/dL, ESR 55 mm/hr, and CRP 45 mg/L. Stool cultures are negative for pathogenic bacteria. A colonoscopy is performed, revealing continuous inflammation extending from the rectum proximally, with loss of vascular pattern, friability, and scattered areas of raised, edematous mucosa. Biopsies are taken.

Which of the following findings is most characteristic of the likely diagnosis in this patient?

choices.text: Transmural inflammation with non-caseating granulomas on colonic biopsy
Discontinuous inflammation with skip lesions and cobblestoning on colonoscopy
Presence of crypt abscesses and goblet cell depletion on rectal biopsy
Extensive ulcerations limited to the terminal ileum with stricture formation

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Presence of crypt abscesses and goblet cell depletion on rectal biopsy:

Explanation:

This patient presents with classic features of Ulcerative Colitis (UC) — including bloody diarrhea, urgency, tenesmus, weight loss, and elevated inflammatory markers — along with continuous mucosal inflammation starting from the rectum on colonoscopy. The most characteristic histological finding in UC is the presence of crypt abscesses and goblet cell depletion on biopsy.

Ulcerative Colitis – Key Diagnostic Features:

  • Mucosal and submucosal inflammation (not transmural)

  • Always involves the rectum and extends proximally in a continuous fashion

  • Colonoscopy shows:

    • Loss of vascular markings

    • Granularity

    • Friability

    • Continuous erythema

  • Biopsy shows:

    • Crypt architectural distortion

    • Crypt abscesses (neutrophils in gland lumens)

    • Goblet cell depletion

    • No granulomas

Transmural inflammation with non-caseating granulomas on colonic biopsy (Option A):
Seen in Crohn’s disease, not UC. Crohn’s is transmural and may form granulomas.

Discontinuous inflammation with skip lesions and cobblestoning on colonoscopy (Option B):
Also typical of Crohn’s disease, which is patchy (skip lesions) and may show cobblestoning of mucosa.

Extensive ulcerations limited to the terminal ileum with stricture formation (Option D):
Suggestive of Crohn’s ileitis, not UC. UC never affects the small bowel, except in backwash ileitis (a limited extension into terminal ileum, not with strictures).

questions.text:
Match the given conditions to their recommended treatment:


	
		
			
			1
			
			
			Uterine prolapse
			
			
			a. Posterior colporrhaphy
			
		
		
			
			2
			
			
			Vault prolapse
			
			
			b. Sacrospinous ligament suspension
			
		
		
			
			3
			
			
			Cystocele
			
			
			c. Vaginal hysterectomy
			
		
		
			
			4
			
			
			Rectocele
			
			
			d. Anterior colporrhaphy
questions.solution:
Correct Option A) 1-c, 2-b, 3-d, 4-a:
 

1

Uterine prolapse

c) Vaginal hysterectomy

2

Vault prolapse

b) Sacrospinous ligament suspension

3

Cystocele

d) Anterior colporrhaphy

4

Rectocele

a) Posterior colporrhaphy

 

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are incorrectly matched.

questions.text: A 60-year-old smoker presents with sudden-onset leg pain, absent pulses, mottled skin, sluggish capillary refill, reduced sensation, and minimal foot movement. What is the most appropriate Rutherford classification?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Class IIb – Immediately threatened:

  • The patient's presentation with absent pulses, mottled skin, reduced sensation, and minimal foot movement directly aligns with Rutherford Class IIb – Immediately threatened.
  • This class indicates a salvageable limb with significant sensory and motor deficits (more than minimal, but not paralysis), requiring urgent revascularization.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: A 22-year-old female from a rural area presents with multiple, painless swellings on the right side of her neck for the past 6 months. Over the past few weeks, the swellings have softened and ruptured, discharging caseous material. On examination, there are multiple indurated, violaceous nodules and sinuses on the neck, with scarring from previous lesions. She is afebrile and has no systemic symptoms. Mantoux test is positive. Chest X-ray is normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Scrofuloderma

Scrofuloderma is a form of cutaneous tuberculosis that results from direct extension of TB from underlying infected lymph nodes, bones, or joints into the overlying skin. It is common in children and young adults. It presents as painless, firm subcutaneous swellings (usually cervical lymph nodes) that may progress to cold abscess, then ulceration with sinus formation.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Actinomycosis

It also forms discharging sinuses, but the discharge is sulfur granule-containing, yellow, and gritty.

Option C -Cutaneous Sporotrichosis

It is caused by Sporothrix schenckii and presents as nodular lymphangitis: primary ulcerated lesion + linear nodules along lymphatics ("sporotrichoid spread"). No caseation or lymph node abscess formation.

Option D -Lupus vulgaris

It is also a form of cutaneous TB, but it presents as a slowly growing, reddish-brown plaque with apple jelly nodules on diascopy.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother due to multiple small, painless, tan-coloured papules on his trunk and extremities. His mother reports that the lesions have been slowly increasing in number over the past few weeks. If a skin scraping of one of these lesions were to be performed and examined under light microscopy, what characteristic microscopic findings would be observed?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Henderson-Patterson bodies:

The image and clinical scenario are characteristic of Molluscum contagiosum, a viral infection caused by a poxvirus. The diagnostic finding on microscopic examination is the presence of Henderson-Patterson bodies, which are large eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusion bodies found in infected epidermal cells.

The child presents with multiple, painless, dome-shaped, umbilicated papules, commonly found on the trunk, extremities, or face. This classic presentation strongly indicates Molluscum contagiosum, a benign self-limited cutaneous infection that spreads via direct contact or contaminated surfaces (fomites).

Histologically, the virus replicates in the cytoplasm of keratinocytes, forming Henderson-Patterson bodies, which appear as large, ovoid, eosinophilic inclusions that displace the nucleus peripherally.

Inclusion Body Disease Associated Location & Appearance
Henderson-Patterson bodies Molluscum contagiosum (poxvirus) Cytoplasmic, large, eosinophilic inclusions
Negri bodies Rabies virus Cytoplasmic, in neurons (hippocampus, cerebellum)
Lipschütz bodies HSV (Herpes simplex virus) Intranuclear inclusions in keratinocytes
Councilman bodies Yellow fever, viral hepatitis Apoptotic hepatocytes (eosinophilic bodies)

Negri bodies (Option A):
Incorrect. Seen in rabies, typically in neurons, not skin.

Lipschütz bodies (Option B):
Incorrect. Intranuclear inclusions in HSV infections, not poxvirus.

Councilman bodies (Option D):
Incorrect. Apoptotic hepatocytes in yellow fever or viral hepatitis, not skin lesions.

questions.text: Which of the following microorganisms exhibits the phenomenon shown in the image given below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Actinomyces

The Splendore-Hoeppli phenomenon is a histopathological finding where eosinophilic, club-shaped material surrounds organisms or antigen-antibody complexes. This is classically seen in Actinomyces infections, forming sulfur granules encased in the radiating eosinophilic material.

The Splendore-Hoeppli phenomenon represents an antigen-antibody complex with debris, surrounded by host inflammatory proteins (e.g., fibrin, immunoglobulins, eosinophils). It is seen in a variety of infectious and non-infectious conditions but is most classically associated with actinomycetoma caused by Actinomyces israelii, an anaerobic Gram-positive filamentous bacterium.

Other organisms can exhibit this reaction, but Actinomyces is the prototypical example, especially in chronic granulomatous infections like cervicofacial actinomycosis.

Organism Association with Splendore-Hoeppli? Notes
Nocardia Rarely Filamentous, weakly acid-fast, but doesn’t classically show this
Actinomyces Yes — Classic association Sulfur granules show the Splendore-Hoeppli reaction
Madurella / Exophiala Sometimes (eumycetoma) May show similar reaction, but less classically
Rhinosporidium seeberi Yes Also shows Splendore-Hoeppli, but less pathognomonic

 

Nocardia (Option A):
Incorrect. Filamentous bacteria, weakly acid-fast, usually does not show Splendore-Hoeppli prominently..

Madurella / Exophiala (Option C):
Incorrect. Can cause mycetoma but Splendore-Hoeppli is not a consistent hallmark.

Rhinosporidium seeberi (Option D):
Incorrect. Can also show this reaction, but less consistently than Actinomyces, and the classic teaching example remains Actinomyces.

questions.text: According to the POCSO Amendment Act, 2019, what is the minimum duration of imprisonment for using a child for pornographic purposes?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 5 years:

  • As per the POCSO Amendment Act 2019, using a child for pornographic purposes will lead to imprisonment for a minimum of 5 years.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D are not the minimum duration of imprisonment for child pornography as per the POSCO Act 2019.

questions.text: A patient presents with a wound over the scalp as shown in the image below. What type of injury is this?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Split laceration:

  • The image shows Split lacerations, which occur when skin is crushed between two hard objects, e.g., scalp over bone, giving clean-looking margins that mimic incised wounds.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D are not observed in this image.

questions.text: Atropine is substituted by phenylephrine to facilitate fundus examination when:

choices.text: Mydriasis and cycloplegia both are required
Cycloplegia and mydriasis both are not required

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Mydriasis is required without cycloplegia:

Explanation:

Phenylephrine is an α₁-adrenergic agonist that causes mydriasis (pupil dilation) by stimulating the dilator pupillae muscle. It does not affect the ciliary muscle, so cycloplegia (loss of accommodation) does not occur. Hence, it is preferred when only dilation is needed, such as for fundus examination.


Mydriatic and cycloplegic agents are used in ophthalmology for different purposes. Understanding their mechanisms helps in choosing the right drug for the clinical context.

  • Mydriasis (pupil dilation) can be achieved either by:

    • Stimulating α₁-receptors on the dilator pupillae (e.g., phenylephrine), or

    • Blocking muscarinic receptors on the sphincter pupillae (e.g., atropine, tropicamide).

  • Cycloplegia (loss of accommodation) occurs only with antimuscarinic agents, as it requires paralysis of the ciliary muscle, which is under parasympathetic control.

Therefore:

  • When only mydriasis is needed (e.g., to view the retina during fundoscopy), phenylephrine is sufficient and preferred to avoid blurred near vision.

  • When both mydriasis and cycloplegia are required (e.g., for cycloplegic refraction in children), agents like atropine or cyclopentolate are used.

Drug Mydriasis Cycloplegia Use Case
Phenylephrine Yes No Fundus examination
Atropine Yes Yes Cycloplegic refraction
Tropicamide Yes Yes Short-acting cycloplegic/mydriatic
Cyclopentolate Yes Yes Pediatric cycloplegic refraction

 

Cycloplegia is required (Option B):
Incorrect. Cycloplegia is caused by muscarinic antagonists, not adrenergic drugs like phenylephrine. This would require atropine, homatropine, or cyclopentolate.

Mydriasis and cycloplegia both are required (Option C):
Incorrect. This combination is needed in cycloplegic refraction, where antimuscarinic drugs are used. Phenylephrine alone is inadequate because it lacks cycloplegic action.

Cycloplegia and mydriasis both are not required (Option D):
Incorrect. If neither effect is needed, no pharmacological agent would be administered. Using phenylephrine in this scenario would be unnecessary and inappropriate.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presents with complaints of asymptomatic nodules on the hair of her axilla for the past 3 months. On examination, multiple soft, white nodules are seen loosely attached to the hair shafts. They can be easily pulled off and are not associated with hair breakage. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Trichosporon asahii

White Piedra is a superficial fungal infection of hair shafts, characterized by soft, white to light brown nodules on hair, which are loosely attached. It is commonly caused by Trichosporon asahii.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Piedraia hortae is the causative organism of Black Piedra, not White Piedra.

Option C - Malassezia furfur is responsible for Pityriasis Versicolor (Tinea versicolor), not piedra.

Option D - Microsporum audouinii is a dermatophyte that causes Tinea capitis.

questions.text: In a research study, participants are first divided into specific sub-groups based on characteristics such as age or gender. Then, a random sample is taken from each sub-group. What type of sampling method is being used?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Stratified random sampling:

  • Correct. This technique first divides the population into strata (sub-groups), then performs random sampling within each stratum to ensure proportional representation.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Simple random sampling: Incorrect. In this method, every individual in the population has an equal chance of selection without dividing into sub-groups.

Option B - Cluster random sampling: Incorrect. Here, entire groups or clusters (e.g., villages, schools) are randomly selected, not individual sub-groups based on characteristics.

Option C - Systematic random sampling: Incorrect. Involves selecting every kth individual from a list, not subgroup-based selection.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the thoracolumbar fascia is incorrect?

choices.text: It attaches to the spinous processes of the lumbar vertebrae
It attaches to the transverse processes of the lumbar vertebrae
It lies posterior to the posterior abdominal wall muscles
It provides origin to internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscles

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - It lies posterior to the posterior abdominal wall muscles

This statement is false. The thoracolumbar fascia is a deep fascial structure that lies posterior to the paraspinal muscles but is deep to (i.e., anterior to) the posterior abdominal wall muscles. Therefore, it does not lie posterior to the abdominal wall muscles—rather, the muscles of the posterior abdominal wall (like quadratus lumborum) lie within or anterior to the fascial layers.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A - It attaches to the spinous processes of the lumbar vertebrae:
    Correct. The posterior layer of the thoracolumbar fascia attaches to the spinous processes of lumbar and lower thoracic vertebrae.

  • Option B - It attaches to the transverse processes of the lumbar vertebrae:
    Correct. The middle layer of the fascia is attached to the transverse processes, helping compartmentalize the deep back muscles.

  • Option D - It provides origin to internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscles:
    Correct. The posterior abdominal wall muscles like internal oblique and transversus abdominis arise from the thoracolumbar fascia, particularly from its middle and posterior layers.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding eFAST in trauma is NOT true?

choices.text: eFAST may need to be repeated or supplemented with other investigations
eFAST does not directly detect hollow viscus injuries
eFAST can detect free fluid in the pericardial or peritoneal cavity

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - eFAST reliably excludes retroperitoneal injuries:

  • This statement is NOT true. eFAST primarily detects free fluid in pericardial/peritoneal spaces. It has significant limitations in visualizing and reliably excluding injuries within the retroperitoneum due to overlying structures and bowel gas.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - eFAST may need to be repeated or supplemented with other investigations: This is true. eFAST is a screening tool; findings may evolve or require further detailed imaging (like CT) or intervention.

Option B - eFAST does not directly detect hollow viscus injuries: This is true. eFAST detects free fluid, which might be a secondary sign of hollow viscus injury, but it doesn't directly visualize the injury itself.

Option D - eFAST can detect free fluid in the pericardial or peritoneal cavity: This is true. This is the primary and most effective application of eFAST in trauma.

questions.text:
A 19-year-old female with a known history of type 1 diabetes mellitus presents to the emergency department with 2 days of progressively worsening nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, and polyuria. Her parents report that she had recently skipped several insulin doses because she felt too sick to eat. On examination, she is lethargic but arousable, her breathing is deep and rapid, and her breath has a fruity odor. Initial lab results show:


	Blood glucose: 580 mg/dL
	Arterial pH: 7.18
	Bicarbonate: 8 mEq/L
	Urine ketones: Large


Which of the following is the primary physiological mechanism leading to the acidosis and ketosis in this patient?

choices.text: Increased peripheral glucose utilization leading to lactic acid production
Absolute insulin deficiency resulting in unchecked lipolysis and ketogenesis
Excessive glucagon secretion causing hepatic gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis
Renal tubular dysfunction leading to impaired acid excretion

questions.solution:
Correct Option B- Absolute insulin deficiency resulting in unchecked lipolysis and ketogenesis:

This patient is in diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) — the hallmark mechanism is absolute insulin deficiency, which leads to uncontrolled lipolysis, releasing free fatty acids that are converted to ketone bodies (acetoacetate, β-hydroxybutyrate), causing high anion gap metabolic acidosis.

Pathophysiology of DKA:

In type 1 diabetes mellitus, there is an absolute lack of insulin. Without insulin:

  • Glucose cannot enter cells, so the body behaves as if it’s in a fasting/starved state.

  • Lipolysis is activated in adipose tissue → releases free fatty acids (FFA)

  • FFAs are transported to the liver, where they undergo ketogenesis → producing ketone bodies (acids)

  • Accumulation of ketones leads to metabolic acidosis with low bicarbonate and low pH

Key lab findings in DKA:

  • Hyperglycemia (e.g., 580 mg/dL)

  • Metabolic acidosis (pH 7.18, bicarbonate 8 mEq/L)

  • Positive urine ketones

  • Kussmaul breathing (deep, rapid respirations)

  • Fruity breath odor (acetone)

Increased peripheral glucose utilization leading to lactic acid production (Option A):
This would suggest lactic acidosis, not ketone-mediated acidosis. Not the primary mechanism in DKA.

Excessive glucagon secretion causing hepatic gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis (Option C):
This contributes to hyperglycemia, but not directly to acidosis and ketosis. It is a secondary contributor.

Renal tubular dysfunction leading to impaired acid excretion (Option D):
Seen in renal tubular acidosis, which typically presents with normal anion gap acidosis, not the high anion gap seen in DKA.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with fatigue, unexplained weight loss, and left upper quadrant fullness. His complete blood count reveals marked leukocytosis (WBC 150,000/µL) with a predominance of neutrophils, myelocytes, and metamyelocytes, and a low leukocyte alkaline phosphatase (LAP) score. Given the most likely diagnosis, which of the following is the most appropriate initial targeted therapy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Imatinib:

Explanation:

This patient's presentation — fatigue, weight loss, left upper quadrant fullness (suggestive of splenomegaly), marked leukocytosis with myeloid precursors, and a low leukocyte alkaline phosphatase (LAP) score) — is classic for Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML). The first-line targeted therapy for CML is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor (TKI) like Imatinib, which specifically targets the BCR-ABL fusion protein produced by the Philadelphia chromosome (t(9;22)).

CML :

  • Etiology: Clonal myeloproliferative disorder caused by the BCR-ABL fusion gene.

  • Diagnostic Clues:

    • Marked leukocytosis with full spectrum of granulocytic precursors (e.g., myelocytes, metamyelocytes)

    • Low LAP score (differentiates from leukemoid reaction)

    • Splenomegaly

  • Confirmatory Test: PCR or FISH for BCR-ABL translocation (Philadelphia chromosome)

  • Treatment of Choice:

    • Imatinib, a TKI, inhibits BCR-ABL tyrosine kinase and leads to durable remissions.

 

All-trans retinoic acid (ATRA) (Option A):
Used in Acute Promyelocytic Leukemia (APL), characterized by t(15;17) and promyelocytes with Auer rods, not in CML.

Cytarabine and Daunorubicin (Option C):
Induction chemotherapy for Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML), not appropriate for chronic-phase CML.

Hydroxyurea as monotherapy (Option D):
May be used temporarily to control WBC counts in CML but is not a targeted therapy and does not alter disease progression like TKIs.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought to the paediatric OPD with visible severe wasting, bilateral pedal edema, and weight-for-height < -3 SD. What is the first dietary step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - F-75 diet:

The F-75 diet is the initial therapeutic feed used in the stabilization phase of severe acute malnutrition. It provides adequate energy and protein while being gentle on the compromised metabolism of the child.

Dietary Management in Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM)

Aspect Details
Definition Severe acute malnutrition characterized by weight-for-height < -3 SD, visible wasting, and/or nutritional edema.
Clinical Features Severe wasting, bilateral pedal edema (kwashiorkor), lethargy, and increased susceptibility to infections.
Initial Dietary Management F-75 diet is given first; it is low in protein and sodium, provides 75 kcal/100 ml, and supports metabolic stabilization without overwhelming the child’s compromised system.
Transition Phase After stabilization, transition to F-100 diet (100 kcal/100 ml), which is higher in protein and energy for rehabilitation and weight gain.
Therapeutic Feeding Total therapeutic feeding of approximately 125 kcal/kg/day is the target during rehabilitation, not the initial step.
Home-made Diet Not suitable initially due to unpredictable nutrient content and risk of refeeding syndrome.

 

Therapeutic feeding with 125 kcal/kg/day (Option A):
Target for rehabilitation phase, not the initial stabilization.

F-100 diet (Option B):
Used after initial stabilization with F-75, during rehabilitation.

Home-made high-calorie diet (Option D):
Not recommended initially due to risk of inadequate nutrient balance and refeeding complications.

questions.text: A patient presents with a spinal cord injury resulting in Brown-Sequard Syndrome. Which of the following best describes the typical neurological deficits in this condition?

choices.text: Ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature, contralateral loss of motor function and proprioception
Ipsilateral loss of motor function, vibration, and proprioception; contralateral loss of pain and temperature
Contralateral loss of all sensory modalities and motor function below the lesion
Bilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation below the lesion, with preserved motor function

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Ipsilateral loss of motor function, vibration, and proprioception; contralateral loss of pain and temperature:

  • Brown-Séquard Syndrome results from a hemisection (damage to one half) of the spinal cord. This leads to distinct neurological deficits depending on the tract involved and its decussation point:
    • Ipsilateral (Same Side as the Lesion) Deficits:
      • Loss of Motor Function (Paresis/Paralysis): This occurs due to damage to the descending lateral corticospinal tract, which controls voluntary movement and has already crossed in the medulla.
      • Loss of Vibration, Proprioception, and Fine/Discriminative Touch: These sensations are carried by the ascending dorsal column-medial lemniscus pathway. These fibers ascend on the same side as the lesion and only decussate higher up in the medulla.
    • Contralateral (Opposite Side of the Lesion) Deficits:
      • Loss of Pain and Temperature Sensation: This occurs below the lesion due to damage to the ascending lateral spinothalamic tract. Critically, the sensory fibers for pain and temperature decussate to the opposite side of the spinal cord very soon after entering. Therefore, a lesion on one side of the spinal cord impacts pain and temperature sensation on the opposite side of the body.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: Which nerve is most likely to be injured during spinal anesthesia of the upper limb?
questions.solution:
Correct Option  A - Phrenic nerve:

  • Spinal anesthesia of the upper limb is another name for the supraclavicular block. The most common nerve to be injured during a supraclavicular block is the phrenic nerve.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are not the most common nerves injured during supraclavicular block.

questions.text: Which of the following findings is most characteristic of tuberculous otitis media?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Multiple perforation

  • Multiple small perforations of the tympanic membrane are classically associated with tuberculous otitis media. These may later coalesce into a larger perforation.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A - Marginal perforation
    Seen more commonly in chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM), especially with cholesteatoma. Not typical for TB otitis.
  • Option B -Attic perforation
    Also associated with atticoantral disease or cholesteatoma. Not characteristic of TB otitis media.
  • Option C -Central perforation
    Seen in tubotympanic (safe) CSOM, but not specific for tuberculosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is most likely to cause ischemia of the bowel without signs of obstruction, due to involvement of only part of the bowel wall?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Richter’s hernia:

  • A Richter's hernia occurs when only a portion of the circumference (or anti-mesenteric border) of the bowel wall becomes incarcerated and strangulated within a hernia sac.
  • Because the entire lumen is not entrapped, the bowel remains patent, allowing gas and stool to pass. Consequently, signs of complete bowel obstruction (like severe vomiting or obstipation) may be absent, even as the entrapped segment of the bowel wall becomes ischemic or gangrenous. This perfectly matches the scenario of bowel ischemia without signs of obstruction due to partial wall involvement.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Amyand’s hernia: Contains the appendix, not primarily causing partial bowel wall ischemia without obstruction.

Option B - Littre’s hernia: This is a hernia containing a Meckel’s diverticulum. While the diverticulum can become ischemic, it doesn't typically involve partial ischemia of the bowel wall

Option C - Maydl’s hernia: Involves two loops (W-shaped) with an ischemic intervening segment, a different mechanism than partial wall involvement of a single loop.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female reports a 3-month history of nocturnal numbness and tingling in her thumb, index, middle, and radial half of the ring finger, often relieved by shaking her hand. Which physical examination test would be most useful in reproducing her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Phalen's test:

  • The patient's symptoms (numbness/tingling in the median nerve distribution, nocturnal exacerbation, relief with hand shaking) are highly suggestive of Carpal Tunnel Syndrome (CTS), caused by compression of the median nerve at the wrist.
  • Phalen's test involves maximal wrist flexion for 30-60 seconds, which increases pressure in the carpal tunnel and commonly reproduces the symptoms of CTS.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Finkelstein's test: Used to diagnose De Quervain's tenosynovitis (tendinitis of the thumb extensors).

Option C - Neer's test: Used to diagnose shoulder impingement syndrome.

Option D - Trendelenburg test: Used to assess hip abductor muscle weakness (e.g., gluteus medius).

questions.text: A farmer ingests aluminium phosphide and dies within 24 hours. What is the most common cause of death due to aluminium phosphide poisoning?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Cardiogenic shock:

  • Aluminium phosphide (Celphos) poisoning inhibits the cytochrome oxidase enzyme and has a cytotoxic action. The most common cause of death is cardiogenic shock.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and C are not the most common causes of death due to celphos poisoning.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most preferred conduit for the marked structure in the given image?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Left internal mammary artery:

  • The Left Internal Mammary Artery (LIMA) is considered the most preferred graft for CABG and the "gold standard," particularly for the Left Anterior Descending (LAD) coronary artery.
  • Its superior long-term patency stems from its arterial nature, allowing the lumen to remain patent consistently through systole and diastole, unlike collapsible venous grafts.
  • LIMA's biological advantages make it the preferred choice for long-term revascularization.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Long saphenous vein: Most commonly used due to length, but not the most preferred due to lower patency from its collapsible lumen.

Option B - Radial artery: A viable arterial graft, but LIMA remains the gold standard.

Option D - Right gastroepiploic artery: A less common arterial graft; LIMA is generally preferred where anatomically feasible.

questions.text: Which of the following is the yoke muscle of the right lateral rectus during right gaze?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A. Left medial rectus

In right gaze, the right lateral rectus abducts the right eye. Its yoke muscle is the left medial rectus, which adducts the left eye to allow for conjugate gaze to the right.

Yoke muscles are pairs of extraocular muscles in each eye that work together to produce binocular movement in the same direction. According to Hering’s law of equal innervation, these paired muscles receive equal neural signals to maintain conjugate eye movement.

In right gaze:

  • The right eye moves outward (abduction) via the right lateral rectus (innervated by CN VI).

  • The left eye simultaneously moves inward (adduction) via the left medial rectus (innervated by CN III).

Thus, the right lateral rectus and the left medial rectus are yoke muscles during rightward gaze.

Right medial rectus (Option B):
Acts in left gaze, not right — not a yoke pair for this movement.

Left lateral rectus (Option C):
Abducts the left eye — involved in left gaze, not right gaze.

Left superior rectus (Option D):
Elevates the left eye — not involved in horizontal gaze.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with intermittent episodes of bloody diarrhea for the past two weeks. Stool microscopy shows trophozoites with a single nucleus, central karyosome, and ingested red blood cells. He has a history of travel to endemic areas. Which of the following is correct regarding the causative organism?

choices.text: It produces a cyst with thin chromatoid bodies
The infective form is the quadrinucleate cyst, resistant to chlorination

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - The infective form is the quadrinucleate cyst, resistant to chlorination

 

 

The clinical picture and stool findings point to Entamoeba histolytica, which causes amoebic dysentery. The infective form of E. histolytica is the quadrinucleate cyst, which is resistant to chlorination and survives in the environment, facilitating fecal–oral transmission.

The patient presents with bloody diarrhea, and stool microscopy reveals trophozoites with a central karyosome and ingested RBCs, which is diagnostic of Entamoeba histolytica. This protozoan causes amoebiasis, commonly seen in individuals from or traveling to endemic areas with poor sanitation.

The life cycle of E. histolytica includes:

  • Trophozoites: Active, invasive form seen in stool during disease; shows erythrophagocytosis (ingested RBCs), which helps differentiate it from commensal amoebae.

  • Cysts: Infective form; the mature quadrinucleate cyst is resistant to environmental stress and chlorination, allowing transmission through contaminated water.

Feature Entamoeba histolytica
Trophozoite features Single nucleus, central karyosome, ingested RBCs
Type of pseudopodia Blunt pseudopodia (true for histolytica)
Infective form Quadrinucleate cyst
Chlorination resistance Yes
Erythrophagocytosis Yes — hallmark of invasive disease
Chromatoid bodies in cyst Present, but thick and rounded ends

 

Option A: It produces a cyst with thin chromatoid bodies
Incorrect. E. histolytica cysts have thick, blunt (rounded) chromatoid bodies, not thin.

Option B: It shows blunt pseudopodia
Incorrect as a distractor. This is true, but not the most defining or diagnostic feature compared to infective form and chlorination resistance.

Option D: It does not show erythrophagocytosis
Incorrect. E. histolytica does show erythrophagocytosis, which is pathognomonic.

questions.text:
Match the following immunohistochemical staining patterns for Cytokeratin 7 (CK7) and Cytokeratin 20 (CK20) with the carcinoma types they are most commonly associated with


	
		
			
			Column A 
			
			
			Column B
			
		
		
			
			1. CK7+ and CK20+
			
			
			a. Breast Cancer
			
		
		
			
			2. CK7+ and CK20-
			
			
			b. Colorectal cancer
			
		
		
			
			3. CK7- and CK20+
			
			
			c. Hepatocellular Carcinoma (HCC)
			
		
		
			
			4. CK7- and CK20-
			
			
			d. Bladder Cancer
questions.solution:
Correct Option B: 1-d, 2-a, 3-b, 4-c :

K7 and CK20 are intermediate filament proteins used in immunohistochemistry to help identify the tissue of origin in carcinomas. Their expression patterns vary among different tumors.

Matching Explanation:

1. CK7+ and CK20+ → Bladder Cancer (Option d)

  • Urothelial carcinoma (bladder) often expresses both CK7 and CK20.

2. CK7+ and CK20- → Breast Cancer (Option a)

  • Breast carcinomas typically show strong CK7 positivity and are CK20 negative.

3. CK7- and CK20+ → Colorectal Cancer (Option b)

  • Classic pattern for colorectal adenocarcinoma, which is CK20 positive and CK7 negative.

4. CK7- and CK20- → Hepatocellular Carcinoma (HCC) (Option c)

  • HCC usually lacks expression of both CK7 and CK20.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with polyuria, polydipsia, and failure to thrive. Laboratory findings reveal hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis. Which of the following is the most likely underlying defect in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - NKCC transporter defect:

This child presents with polyuria, polydipsia, failure to thrive, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis — all classic features of Gitelman syndrome, which is caused by a defect in the Na⁺/Cl⁻ cotransporter in the distal convoluted tubule.

Gitelman Syndrome – Key Features:

  • Autosomal recessive

  • Defect in the thiazide-sensitive Na⁺/Cl⁻ cotransporter in the distal convoluted tubule

  • Clinical and biochemical features:

    • Hypokalemia

    • Metabolic alkalosis

    • Hypomagnesemia

    • Hypocalciuria

    • Normal or low blood pressure

    • Symptoms: muscle weakness, cramps, polyuria, growth retardation

It typically presents in childhood or adolescence and mimics chronic thiazide diuretic use.

Ruling out other options:

ENaC mutation (Option A):
Seen in Liddle syndrome – causes hypertension, hypokalemia, metabolic alkalosis, but typically no polyuria/failure to thrive.

NKCC transporter defect (Option C):
This is seen in Bartter syndrome, which also presents with hypokalemia, metabolic alkalosis, and polyuria, but with normal or high urinary calcium. Onset is often earlier than Gitelman and more severe in infancy.

H⁺-ATPase mutation (Option D):
Associated with distal (type I) renal tubular acidosis, which presents with metabolic acidosis, not alkalosis, and often hypokalemia.

questions.text: During the transition from a sitting to a standing position, what movement occurs at the knee joint to facilitate locking in extension?

choices.text: Medial rotation of the femur on a fixed tibia
Lateral rotation of the femur on a fixed femur
Medial rotation of the tibia on a fixed femur
Lateral rotation of the tibia on a fixed femur

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Medial rotation of the femur on a fixed tibia

When a person extends the knee from a flexed position (as in rising from sitting to standing), the joint undergoes a locking mechanism that enhances stability, especially during weight-bearing.

In a closed kinetic chain (i.e., foot planted on the ground), as in standing:

  • The femur rotates medially on the fixed tibia during the last 10–15° of extension.
     
  • This is referred to as the "locking" of the knee joint, contributing to joint stability while standing.

This movement is facilitated by the shape of the femoral condyles, tension in ligaments, and muscle forces.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option B - Lateral rotation of the femur on a fixed femur:
    Illogical and anatomically incorrect — the femur cannot rotate on itself; rotation is described relative to the tibia.

  • Option C- Medial rotation of the tibia on a fixed femur:
    This occurs during unlocking (initiation of flexion) in open chain movements (non–weight-bearing), not during locking in extension.

  • Option D - Lateral rotation of the tibia on a fixed femur:
    Also occurs in open chain extension (non-weight-bearing), not in weight-bearing (standing up) actions.

questions.text: A newborn is diagnosed with a hemangioma localized on the face and scalp. From which embryonic germ layer are the cells constituting this vascular anomaly primarily derived?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Mesoderm alone

Hemangiomas are benign vascular tumors formed due to the proliferation of blood vessel endothelial cells. The vascular system—including blood vessels and their lining (endothelium)—is derived primarily from mesoderm, the middle germ layer of the embryo. During embryogenesis, mesoderm gives rise to:

  • Endothelial cells

  • Blood vessels

  • Cardiovascular system

  • Connective tissues

Hence, the cellular origin of hemangiomas is traced back to the mesoderm.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A - Ectoderm only:
    The ectoderm gives rise to the skin, nervous system, and some parts of sensory organs, but not the vascular system. It does not directly contribute to the formation of blood vessels or endothelial cells.

  • Option C - Endoderm only:
    The endoderm forms the epithelial lining of the gastrointestinal tract, respiratory tract, and related organs. It does not play a role in the formation of vascular tissue.

  • Option D - Ectoderm and mesoderm:
    While ectoderm is involved in skin development (the layer overlying a hemangioma), the vascular components themselves are purely mesodermal in origin. There is no dual ectodermal-mesodermal contribution to hemangioma cells.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with recurrent episodes of pancreatitis. His fasting lipid profile shows markedly elevated triglycerides, high chylomicrons, and very low levels of HDL-cholesterol. Which of the following enzymes is most likely deficient in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Lipoprotein lipase (LPL):

  • The patient's clinical picture of recurrent pancreatitis combined with markedly elevated triglycerides and high chylomicrons in a fasting state is the classic diagnostic hallmark of Type I Hyperlipoproteinemia or Familial Lipoprotein Lipase Deficiency.
    • Lipoprotein Lipase (LPL) is a key enzyme located on the endothelial surface of capillaries. Its primary role is to break down triglycerides found in chylomicrons and VLDL, releasing fatty acids for uptake by tissues.
    • A deficiency in LPL (or its activator, ApoC-II) leads to a dramatic accumulation of triglyceride-rich lipoproteins in the blood, causing severe hypertriglyceridemia, which is a common cause of acute pancreatitis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Hepatic lipase: Primarily acts on LDL and HDL in the liver, not the main enzyme for clearing circulating triglyceride-rich lipoproteins.

Option B - Cholesterol ester transfer protein (CETP): Transfers cholesterol esters and triglycerides between lipoproteins; it does not hydrolyze triglycerides.

Option D - Lecithin-cholesterol acyltransferase (LCAT): Involved in HDL maturation and cholesterol esterification; it does not hydrolyze triglycerides.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presents with horizontal diplopia that worsens when trying to look to the right. On examination, his right eye fails to abduct, while all other eye movements are intact. Based on a labeled diagram of cranial nerves at the brainstem level, which labeled structure (nerve) is responsible for this deficit?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C – C:

Abducent Nerve (CN VI)

  • Lateral gaze palsy refers to impaired abduction of the eye, which is controlled by the lateral rectus muscle.
     
  • The lateral rectus is innervated by the abducent nerve (cranial nerve VI).
     
  • Injury to this nerve causes inability to abduct the affected eye, leading to diplopia when attempting lateral gaze.
     
  • The abducent nerve has a long intracranial course, making it vulnerable to injury from raised intracranial pressure, basilar skull fractures, or brainstem lesions.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A - Oculomotor nerve (CN III):
    Controls most extraocular muscles (medial rectus, superior rectus, inferior rectus, inferior oblique) and levator palpebrae. Lesion causes ptosis, dilated pupil, and down-and-out eye — not lateral gaze palsy.
     
  • Option B - Trochlear nerve (CN IV):
    Innervates the superior oblique muscle, affecting downward and inward gaze. Injury causes vertical diplopia, especially when looking down (e.g., reading, stairs).
     
  • Option D - Ophthalmic nerve (V1 branch of CN V):
    A sensory nerve to the forehead, cornea, and upper eyelid. Not involved in eye movement.

questions.text: A 15-year-old male presents with new-onset tremors, ataxia, and jaundice. On examination, a brownish-green discoloration is noted at the limbus of both corneas. Laboratory tests show elevated liver enzymes. Which of the following is the primary therapeutic strategy for this patient's condition?

choices.text: Copper chelation therapy or zinc supplementation.

questions.solution:
