Correct Option C - Copper chelation therapy or zinc supplementation:

Explanation:

This presentation is classic for Wilson disease, a genetic disorder causing copper accumulation. The primary treatment involves copper chelation (e.g., penicillamine, trientine) or zinc supplementation to reduce copper levels and prevent organ damage.

Wilson Disease

Aspect Details
Etiology Autosomal recessive mutation in ATP7B gene → impaired copper excretion into bile → copper accumulation in liver, brain, cornea, kidneys.
Clinical Features Hepatic: Elevated liver enzymes, hepatitis, cirrhosis.
Neurologic: Tremors, ataxia, dysarthria.
Ophthalmologic: Kayser-Fleischer rings (brownish-green ring at corneal limbus).
Diagnosis Low serum ceruloplasmin.
Elevated 24-hour urinary copper.
Liver biopsy showing increased hepatic copper.
Presence of Kayser-Fleischer rings on slit-lamp exam.
Treatment Copper chelators: Penicillamine or trientine to promote copper excretion.
Zinc: Induces metallothionein, which blocks copper absorption.
Liver transplantation: Reserved for fulminant hepatic failure or end-stage liver disease.
Prognosis Early treatment improves prognosis and prevents irreversible organ damage.

Iron chelation therapy (Option A):
Used for iron overload conditions like hemochromatosis, not effective in copper accumulation disorders such as Wilson disease.

Low-protein diet and lactulose (Option B):
These are treatments for hepatic encephalopathy, a complication of liver failure, but do not address copper toxicity or the underlying cause.

Liver transplantation (Option D):
Reserved for severe cases with fulminant hepatic failure or end-stage liver disease that do not respond to medical therapy; not first-line treatment.

questions.text: In the intricate regulation of the intrinsic (mitochondrial) pathway of apoptosis, various Bcl-2 family proteins play critical roles. Based on their primary function, which of the following molecules is classified as an anti-apoptotic protein?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - BCL2

Follicular lymphoma is a type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma characterized by a t(14;18)(q32;q21) translocation. This translocation juxtaposes the BCL2 gene on chromosome 18 to the Ig heavy chain locus on chromosome 14, leading to overexpression of BCL2, an anti-apoptotic protein. This prevents normal cell death and contributes to the accumulation of neoplastic B cells in lymphoid follicles.

Follicular Lymphoma:

  • Origin: Germinal center B cells

  • Genetics: t(14;18) translocation in ~85% of cases

  • Marker: BCL2 overexpression

  • Immunophenotype: CD19+, CD20+, CD10+, BCL6+, BCL2+ (inappropriately positive in follicles)

  • Clinical features: Painless lymphadenopathy; often indolent course

  • Histology: Nodular/follicular pattern, cleaved centrocytes

Mechanism:

  • BCL2 normally prevents apoptosis.

  • In reactive follicles, BCL2 is not expressed, allowing B cells that fail affinity maturation to die.

  • In follicular lymphoma, BCL2 is aberrantly expressed, preventing apoptosis and allowing malignant cells to persist.

 

BCL6 (Option A):
Expressed in follicular lymphoma but not the defining mutation. BCL6 is more associated with diffuse large B-cell lymphoma.
Ruled out.

MYC (Option B):
Seen in Burkitt lymphoma, associated with t(8;14) translocation.
Ruled out.

Cyclin D1 (Option D):
Overexpressed in mantle cell lymphoma due to t(11;14) translocation.
Ruled out.

questions.text: A woman, pregnant with a single fetus who has had 2 sets of twins previously, is due in 4 weeks. Given that one set of twins is alive and well, and 1 twin of the second set was stillborn, what is her obstetric score?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) G3P2

Gravida (G) counts all pregnancies, regardless of outcome. Para (P) refers to number of deliveries beyond the age of viability (typically ≥20–24 weeks), not the number of babies delivered.

Calculating the Obstetric Score

Parameter Interpretation for This Patient
Gravida (G) 3 total pregnancies: 2 previous twin pregnancies + current singleton
Para (P) 2 deliveries: each twin pregnancy = 1 delivery, regardless of number of fetuses or outcomes
Current Pregnancy Ongoing, not yet delivered → not included in para yet

 

Breakdown:

  1. 1st Pregnancy: Twin delivery — both alive → 1 para

  2. 2nd Pregnancy: Twin delivery — one live, one stillborn → still 1 para

  3. 3rd Pregnancy (current): Singleton, not delivered yet → included in Gravida only

G2P1 (Option A): Incorrect - undercounts previous pregnancies and deliveries.

G5P2 (Option B): Incorrect - overcounts pregnancies; each pregnancy counts once, even if twins.

G3P3 (Option D): Incorrect - para counts pregnancies delivered, not number of babies.

questions.text: A patient presents with bluish-black pigmentation in the cartilage of the ears and nose, along with bluish-black discoloration of the sclera as seen in the image. This genetic disorder is caused by a deficiency in which of the following enzymes?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Homogentisate oxidase:

  • The clinical presentation of bluish-black pigmentation in cartilage (ears, nose) and sclera (Osler's sign) as seen in the image is pathognomonic for Alkaptonuria. This autosomal recessive genetic disorder is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme homogentisate oxidase.
  • This enzyme is crucial in the catabolic pathway of tyrosine, converting homogentisic acid (HGA) to maleylacetoacetate. The deficiency leads to the accumulation and subsequent oxidation and polymerization of HGA, which deposits in connective tissues, causing the characteristic ochronosis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Tyrosinase: Deficiency leads to Albinism, a disorder of melanin synthesis characterized by hypopigmentation.

Option B - Phenylalanine hydroxylase: Deficiency causes Phenylketonuria (PKU), a severe metabolic disorder affecting neurological development.

Option D - Branched-chain alpha-keto acid dehydrogenase: Deficiency causes Maple Syrup Urine Disease (MSUD), a disorder of branched-chain amino acid metabolism with severe neurological consequences.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman with morbid obesity (BMI 45 kg/m²) and poorly controlled type 2 diabetes is being evaluated for bariatric surgery. She has failed multiple attempts at medical weight loss. Which of the following bariatric surgeries is most effective in achieving long-term weight loss and diabetes remission?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Biliopancreatic diversion with duodenal switch (BPD-DS):

  • For morbid obesity (BMI 45) and poorly controlled type 2 diabetes, Biliopancreatic diversion with duodenal switch (BPD-DS) is the most effective surgery. It achieves the highest rates of long-term weight loss and diabetes remission through both restrictive (sleeve gastrectomy) and significant malabsorptive components, leading to profound metabolic benefits.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Adjustable gastric banding: Least effective for weight loss and diabetes remission, especially in severe cases, due to its purely restrictive nature.

Option B - Sleeve gastrectomy: Effective, but generally less so than bypass procedures for diabetes remission, particularly in severe cases.

Option C - Roux-en-Y gastric bypass: Highly effective and often a gold standard, but BPD-DS generally offers superior results for very high BMI and severe diabetes.

questions.text: What flap is most likely being harvested?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - DIEP flap

  • DIEP (Deep Inferior Epigastric Perforator) flap is a muscle-sparing autologous flap used for breast reconstruction.
  • It harvests skin and subcutaneous fat from the lower abdomen, along with perforating vessels from the deep inferior epigastric artery.
  • Rectus abdominis muscle is preserved, reducing postoperative weakness and hernia risk.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - TRAM flap (Transverse Rectus Abdominis Myocutaneous flap): A TRAM flap involves harvesting a portion of the rectus abdominis muscle, not preserving it.

Option B - Latissimus dorsi flap: This is a back-based flap involving the latissimus dorsi muscle, not an abdominal-based flap.

Option D - Gracilis flap: It is a muscle flap from the medial thigh

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant presents with severe generalized muscle weakness, hypotonia (floppy baby syndrome), cardiomegaly, and hepatomegaly. Laboratory investigations reveal significant glycogen accumulation in various tissues, particularly the heart and muscles, but no fasting hypoglycemia. This clinical presentation is most consistent with a deficiency in which enzyme?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Acid alpha-glucosidase (acid maltase)

  • The clinical picture of an infant with severe muscle weakness, hypotonia, cardiomegaly, hepatomegaly, and crucially, no fasting hypoglycemia is diagnostic for Type II Glycogen Storage Disorder (Pompe disease). This is caused by a deficiency of acid alpha-glucosidase (acid maltase), a lysosomal enzyme whose absence leads to widespread lysosomal glycogen accumulation.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Glucose-6-phosphatase (Type I): Causes Type I Glycogen Storage Disorder (Von Gierke disease), which primarily affects the liver and kidneys, leading to severe fasting hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, and hepatomegaly.

Option B - Muscle phosphorylase (Type V): Causes Type V Glycogen Storage Disorder (McArdle disease), characterized by exercise intolerance in older patients; no cardiac/liver involvement.

Option D - Debranching enzyme (Type III): Causes Type III Glycogen Storage Disorder (Cori or Forbes disease), leads to milder hypoglycemia and muscle weakness.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male undergoing a routine pre-employment check-up had the following chest X-ray. He is asymptomatic. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the radiological finding?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Pulmonary hamartoma:

Popcorn-like calcifications in a solitary, well-defined lung nodule are characteristic of pulmonary hamartoma, the most common benign lung tumor.

Pulmonary Hamartoma and Differential Diagnosis of Solitary Pulmonary Nodules

Topic Details
Definition Benign lung tumor consisting of an abnormal mixture of cartilage, fat, connective tissue, and sometimes bone.
Epidemiology Most common benign lung tumor
Typically occurs in adults aged 40-60 years
Pathology Composed mainly of cartilage and fat
Well-circumscribed, often “coin lesion” on chest X-ray
Radiological Features Solitary, round, well-defined nodule
Popcorn-like calcifications (coarse, chondroid calcifications) are hallmark
Usually located peripherally
Clinical Presentation Most patients asymptomatic
Often incidental finding during imaging for other reasons
Natural History & Prognosis Slow growing or stable
Benign with excellent prognosis
Rarely requires surgical removal unless symptomatic or diagnosis uncertain

 

Differential Diagnoses of Solitary Pulmonary Nodule

Condition Key Features
Bronchogenic carcinoma Malignant lung tumor
Usually irregular, spiculated mass
Calcification if present is eccentric or stippled
Associated with smoking and symptoms like cough, weight loss
Tuberculoma Localized granuloma due to Mycobacterium tuberculosis
Dense, central calcifications but no popcorn pattern
Often history of TB exposure or symptoms
Metastasis Usually multiple pulmonary nodules
Calcification rare, if present usually amorphous or irregular
History of extrapulmonary malignancy common

 

Bronchogenic carcinoma (Option B):
Usually presents as an irregular, spiculated mass with eccentric or stippled calcifications if any. Typically symptomatic and associated with smoking history.

Tuberculoma (Option C):
May have dense, central calcifications but lacks characteristic popcorn calcifications. Usually associated with clinical symptoms or TB exposure history.

Metastasis (Option D):
Typically presents with multiple nodules; solitary metastatic lesion is rare. Calcifications, if present, are irregular and not popcorn-like.

questions.text: Which anatomical structure forms the lateral boundary of the cubital fossa?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C -  Medial border of brachioradialis

The cubital fossa is a triangular depression located on the anterior aspect of the elbow joint. Its boundaries are:

  • Lateral boundary: Formed by the medial border of the brachioradialis muscle

  • Medial boundary: Formed by the lateral border of the pronator teres muscle

  • Base (superior boundary): An imaginary line joining the medial and lateral epicondyles of the humerus

  • Floor: Formed by the brachialis and supinator muscles

  • Roof: Formed by skin, superficial fascia, and bicipital aponeurosis

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A - Medial border of pronator teres:
    This does not contribute to the cubital fossa boundaries. The lateral border of pronator teres is relevant instead.

  • Option B - Lateral border of pronator teres:
    This forms the medial boundary, not the lateral boundary of the cubital fossa.

  • Option D -Lateral border of brachioradialis:
    The lateral border of this muscle lies outside the fossa and does not define any of its boundaries.

questions.text: Which cranial nerve is most likely indicated by the arrow?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Oculomotor nerve (CN III)

The nerve identified near the interpeduncular fossa, passing between the posterior cerebral and superior cerebellar arteries, is the oculomotor nerve (CN III).

questions.text: An allograft biopsy showing interstitial inflammation, peritubular capillaritis, fibrin thrombi within glomerular capillaries, and strong diffuse C4d staining in peritubular capillaries is most indicative of which type of acute transplant rejection?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Acute Humoral (Antibody-Mediated) Rejection (AMR)

The biopsy findings — interstitial inflammation, peritubular capillaritis, fibrin thrombi in glomerular capillaries, and diffuse C4d positivity in peritubular capillaries — are hallmark features of acute antibody-mediated rejection (AMR).

  • C4d staining reflects complement activation by donor-specific antibodies (DSAs), confirming a humoral immune response.

Topic Discussion: Types of Transplant Rejection and Histological Features

Type of Rejection Timing Key Histologic Features Immunologic Basis
Acute Cellular Rejection (ACR) Days to weeks Lymphocytic tubulitis, interstitial inflammation, arteritis T cell–mediated
Acute Humoral Rejection (AMR) Days to weeks Peritubular capillaritis, fibrin thrombi, C4d+ staining, neutrophils in capillaries Donor-specific antibodies (DSA) and complement
Chronic Allograft Nephropathy Months to years Interstitial fibrosis, tubular atrophy, transplant glomerulopathy, arteriosclerosis Mixed T cell and antibody-mediated injury
Hyperacute Rejection Minutes to hours Widespread thrombosis, neutrophilic infiltration, no C4d required, rapid graft failure Preformed antibodies (e.g., ABO mismatch)

 

Acute Cellular Rejection (Option A):

  • Mediated by T cells, typically presents with interstitial inflammation, tubulitis, and sometimes intimal arteritis.

  • No C4d positivity and no fibrin thrombi in glomerular capillaries.

  • Lacks the hallmark capillaritis and antibody involvement seen in AMR.

Chronic Allograft Nephropathy (Option C):

  • Develops months to years after transplant.

  • Shows interstitial fibrosis, tubular atrophy, arteriosclerosis, and sometimes transplant glomerulopathy.

  • Does not present with acute inflammation, fibrin thrombi, or prominent C4d staining, which are features of acute rather than chronic rejection.

Hyperacute Rejection (Option D):

  • Occurs within minutes to hours after transplantation due to preformed antibodies (e.g., ABO or HLA mismatch).

  • Characterized by widespread vascular thrombosis, neutrophilic infiltration, and immediate graft failure.

  • The described biopsy findings (especially interstitial inflammation and C4d positivity) are not typical of hyperacute rejection.

questions.text: Which of the following cellular changes is considered the critical point of no return, indicating irreversible cell injury?

choices.text: Cellular swelling due to ion pump failure
Detachment of ribosomes from rough endoplasmic reticulum
Pyknosis, karyorrhexis, and karyolysis of the nucleus

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Pyknosis, karyorrhexis, and karyolysis of the nucleus:

These nuclear changes are definitive indicators of irreversible cell injury. Once the nucleus undergoes pyknosis (condensation), karyorrhexis (fragmentation), and karyolysis (dissolution), the cell has crossed the point of no return and death is inevitable

Cell Injury Progression:

Stage Change Reversibility
Early Cellular swelling due to ATP depletion and Na⁺/K⁺ pump failure Reversible
Early Detachment of ribosomes from rER → ↓ protein synthesis Reversible
Early Switch to anaerobic glycolysis → ↓ pH, lactic acid buildup Reversible
Late Nuclear changes: pyknosis → karyorrhexis → karyolysis Irreversible

 

Why are nuclear changes critical?

  • They mark irreversible chromatin breakdown and structural disintegration.

  • Once these occur, the cell cannot recover.

 

Cellular swelling due to ion pump failure (Option A):
This occurs early in cell injury due to ATP depletion, leading to Na⁺/K⁺ pump failure and water influx. It is a reversible change, and the cell can recover if normal conditions are restored.

Detachment of ribosomes from rough endoplasmic reticulum (Option B):
Caused by energy depletion, this leads to reduced protein synthesis. However, it is still a reversible alteration and not a marker of irreversible injury.

Anaerobic glycolysis (Option D):
A metabolic adaptation to hypoxia resulting in lactic acid accumulation and lower pH. Though it contributes to cellular stress, it remains a reversible process during early injury.

.

questions.text:
Match the Hodgkin Lymphoma variant in Column A with its most characteristic pathological feature in Column B


	
		
			
			Column A
			
			
			Column B
			
		
		
			
			1. Nodular Sclerosis
			
			
			a. Classic RS cells
			
		
		
			
			2. Mixed Cellularity
			
			
			b. Popcorn cells (L&H cells) CD 15+
			
		
		
			
			3. Lymphocyte-Rich
			
			
			c. Polymorphic inflammatory background
			
		
		
			
			4. Lymphocyte-Depleted
			
			
			d. Lacunar cells
			
		
		
			
			5. Nodular Lymphocyte-Predominant
			
			
			e. Pleomorphic RS cells
			
		
		
			
			 
			
			
			f. Popcorn cells (L&H cells) CD 30-
			
		
	


Choose the correct set of matches:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B: 1-d, 2-c, 3-a, 4-e, 5-f

Subtype

Morphology and Immunophenotype

Nodular Sclerosis

Frequent lacunar cells and occasional diagnostic RS cells. Background infiltrate composed of T lymphocytes, eosinophils, macrophages, and plasma cells. Fibrous bands divide cellular areas into nodules. RS cells CD15+, CD30+; usually EBV-.

Mixed Cellularity

Frequent mononuclear and diagnostic RS cells. Background infiltrate rich in T lymphocytes, eosinophils, macrophages, and plasma cells. RS cells CD15+, CD30+; 70% EBV+.

Lymphocyte-Rich

Frequent mononuclear and diagnostic RS cells. Background infiltrate rich in T lymphocytes. RS cells CD15+, CD30+; 40% EBV+.

Lymphocyte-Depleted

Reticular variant: Frequent diagnostic RS cells and variants and a paucity of background reactive cells. RS cells CD15+, CD30+; most EBV+.

Nodular Lymphocyte-Predominant

Frequent L&H (popcorn cell) variants in a background of follicular dendritic cells and reactive B cells. RS cells CD20+, CD15-, CD30-; EB-.

 

Options A, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: A patient develops acute hemolytic anemia following administration of an antimalarial drug. A peripheral blood smear, when stained with a supravital stain, would most likely reveal which of the following red blood cell inclusions?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Heinz bodies

The patient has developed acute hemolytic anemia after antimalarial drug exposure, which is highly suggestive of Glucose-6-Phosphate Dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency. In this condition, oxidative stress (e.g., from drugs like primaquine or sulfa drugs) leads to denatured hemoglobin precipitates within RBCs- visible as Heinz bodies when stained with a supravital stain (e.g., crystal violet).

RBC Inclusions in Hemolytic Anemias and Special Stains

Clinical Context:

  • A patient develops acute hemolytic anemia after receiving an antimalarial drug.

  • This strongly suggests G6PD deficiency, an X-linked enzymatic disorder.

  • In G6PD deficiency, oxidative drugs (e.g., primaquine, sulfonamides, nitrofurantoin) cause accumulation of oxidized, denatured hemoglobin, which precipitates inside RBCs.

Key Point:

These precipitated hemoglobin clumps are called Heinz bodies, and are only visible using supravital stains such as crystal violet or brilliant cresyl blue — not on routine Wright or Giemsa stains.

Red Cell Inclusions: 

Inclusion Composition Seen In Stain Used Notes
Heinz bodies Denatured hemoglobin G6PD deficiency, oxidative hemolysis Supravital stain Not visible on routine stain
Howell-Jolly bodies DNA remnants Post-splenectomy, functional asplenia Wright/Giemsa One per cell, round, dark
Pappenheimer bodies Iron granules Sideroblastic anemia, post-splenectomy Prussian blue Small, multiple
Basophilic stippling Ribosomal RNA Lead poisoning, thalassemia Wright/Giemsa Fine or coarse granules

 

Howell-Jolly bodies (Option A):

  • DNA remnants in RBCs

  • Seen in asplenia or hyposplenia

  • Visible on Wright or Giemsa stain, not supravital

Pappenheimer bodies (Option B):

  • Iron-containing granules

  • Seen in sideroblastic anemia or post-splenectomy

  • Visible with Prussian blue stain, not supravital stain

Basophilic stippling (Option D):

  • Aggregated ribosomes

  • Seen in lead poisoning, thalassemias

  • Seen on Wright stain, not specific to oxidative hemolysis

questions.text: A patient with treatment-resistant schizophrenia was started on a drug that also reduces suicidal risk. Which dopamine receptor does this drug primarily target?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - D4 receptor:

  • Clozapine is effective in treatment-resistant schizophrenia and uniquely reduces suicide risk. It has a high affinity for D4 receptors.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D are not the main sites of action of clozapine.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about prasugrel is true as compared to clopidogrel?

choices.text: It is slower acting than clopidogrel
Due to higher risk of bleeding, prasugrel is contraindicated in stroke
It is a reversible antagonist of ADP receptors
It is effective orally unlike clopidogrel

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Due to higher risk of bleeding, prasugrel is contraindicated in stroke:

Prasugrel is a third-generation thienopyridine that, like clopidogrel, irreversibly inhibits the P2Y₁₂ subtype of ADP receptors on platelets, but more rapidly and more potently. However, it is associated with a higher risk of major bleeding, especially in patients with a history of stroke or transient ischemic attack (TIA). Therefore, prasugrel is contraindicated in such patients.

Statement (Option) Evaluation Explanation
It is slower acting than clopidogrel (Option A) False Prasugrel has faster onset due to more efficient metabolism
Due to higher risk of bleeding, prasugrel is contraindicated in stroke (B) True Greater bleeding risk → contraindicated in prior stroke/TIA
It is a reversible antagonist of ADP receptors (Option C) False Prasugrel (like clopidogrel) is an irreversible P2Y₁₂ inhibitor
It is effective orally unlike clopidogrel (Option D) False Both drugs are orally active prodrugs

questions.text: Which of the following conditions would cause a rightward shift of the Oxygen-Hemoglobin Dissociation Curve, thereby facilitating oxygen release to the tissues?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Decreased blood pH:

  • A rightward shift of the Oxygen-Hemoglobin Dissociation Curve indicates a lower affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen, which means oxygen is released more readily to the tissues. This is physiologically advantageous in situations where tissues have higher metabolic demands. The key factors that cause a rightward shift are:
    • Decreased pH (Increased H+ concentration / Acidosis): This is known as the Bohr effect. A lower pH (more acidic blood) directly reduces hemoglobin's oxygen affinity, causing it to unload oxygen.
    • Increased temperature.
    • Increased arterial PCO2 (part of the Bohr effect).
    • Increased 2,3-Bisphosphoglycerate (2,3-BPG) levels.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D: These conditions cause a LEFTWARD shift, increasing O2 affinity:

questions.text: Which of the following organisms will show the findings given in the image below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Escherichia coli

 

The image shows gas bubble formation in a catalase test, where hydrogen peroxide is broken down into water and oxygen. E. coli, a catalase-positive organism, produces vigorous bubbling due to oxygen release, which is seen in the right spot of the image.

Gross Topic Discussion:

Catalase Test is used to detect the presence of the catalase enzyme, which breaks down hydrogen peroxide (H₂O₂) into water and oxygen:

 2H2O2→2H2O + O2↑2

Key Features of Catalase Test:

Organism Catalase Status Interpretation
Staphylococcus epidermidis Positive Bubbles seen
Escherichia coli Positive Bubbles seen
Streptococcus pyogenes Negative No bubbles
Mycobacterium leprae Catalase-negative or weak Typically no significant bubbling

 

The presence of bubbles (right side) and absence on the left supports catalase-positive behavior (e.g., E. coli) vs. catalase-negative (e.g., Streptococcus pyogenes).

 

Staphylococcus epidermidis (Option A):
Catalase-positive, but gram-positive cocci; not the most classic organism to show in this context compared to E. coli.

Escherichia coli (Option B):
Correct Answer – Strongly catalase-positive Gram-negative bacillus. Bubbles evident in catalase-positive control (as shown).

Streptococcus pyogenes (Option C):
Catalase-negative – would not produce bubbling. Appears flat and inert on the left side of the image.

Mycobacterium leprae (Option D):
Difficult to grow and not typically tested with catalase; generally catalase-negative or weak.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents with a 6-month history of symmetrical small joint pain and swelling, primarily affecting her metacarpophalangeal (MCP) and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints, worse in the mornings. She reports morning stiffness lasting over an hour. Her physical examination reveals tender and swollen MCP and PIP joints bilaterally. Given the likely diagnosis, which of the following is the most appropriate initial disease-modifying antirheumatic drug (DMARD) for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Methotrexate:

Explanation:

Methotrexate is the first-line disease-modifying antirheumatic drug (DMARD) for rheumatoid arthritis (RA) due to its proven efficacy in reducing disease activity and preventing joint damage.

 

  • Rheumatoid arthritis is a chronic autoimmune inflammatory disorder primarily affecting small joints symmetrically, such as the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints.
  • Typical features include joint pain, swelling, and prolonged morning stiffness (>1 hour).
  • Diagnosis is clinical, supported by laboratory tests (e.g., rheumatoid factor, anti-CCP antibodies).
  • The goal of treatment is to control symptoms, reduce inflammation, prevent joint damage, and maintain function.
  • Disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs) are the cornerstone of therapy.
  • Methotrexate is considered the first-line DMARD because it is effective, well-studied, and has a favorable risk-benefit profile. It inhibits dihydrofolate reductase, leading to immunosuppressive and anti-inflammatory effects.
  • Other DMARDs include hydroxychloroquine and biologics such as etanercept (a TNF-alpha inhibitor), but these are generally used when methotrexate is contraindicated, not tolerated, or in combination therapy.
  • Corticosteroids like prednisone are useful for rapid symptom relief and bridging therapy but are not suitable as long-term monotherapy due to side effects.

 

Prednisone (Option A):
Useful as adjunct therapy for symptom control but not appropriate as initial DMARD due to side effects and inability to prevent joint damage.

Etanercept (Option B):
A biologic DMARD reserved for patients who fail or cannot tolerate methotrexate, not initial therapy.

Hydroxychloroquine (Option D):
Milder DMARD, often used in mild disease or in combination; less effective than methotrexate for moderate to severe RA.

questions.text:
A 38-year-old woman presents with a firm, irregular breast lump.


	Clinical suspicion of malignancy is high.
	USG: Hypoechoic lesion with irregular margins.
	FNAC: Suspicious, but not diagnostic.


What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Core needle biopsy:

  • The evaluation of a breast lump relies on a triple assessment, which includes clinical examination, imaging (e.g., USG, mammography), and pathological diagnosis.
  • In this case, clinical suspicion is high, and imaging is concerning. Since the FNAC (the initial pathological assessment) was "suspicious but not diagnostic," a core needle biopsy is the next best step. It provides a larger tissue sample for definitive histological diagnosis, allowing for accurate classification (benign vs. malignant) and tumor characterization, thus completing the pathological arm of the triple assessment.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Start tamoxifen therapy: This is a treatment for hormone-receptor-positive breast cancer and is premature without a definitive diagnosis and receptor status.

Option B - Excision biopsy: While definitive, a core needle biopsy is generally preferred as the initial definitive biopsy due to its less invasive nature, allowing for subsequent surgical planning if malignancy is confirmed.

Option C - Repeat FNAC: Repeating an FNAC that was previously inconclusive is unlikely to provide a definitive diagnosis and would delay appropriate management.

questions.text: Which of the tongue muscles develop from NCC-derived 4th pharyngeal arch mesoderm, which is neural crest cell?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - B

The palatoglossus muscle (labeled as B) is the only muscle of the tongue that is not derived from occipital somites. Instead, it originates from the 4th pharyngeal arch mesoderm, which is neural crest cell (NCC)-derived. This also explains why its motor innervation is from the vagus nerve (CN X) via the pharyngeal plexus, rather than the hypoglossal nerve (CN XII), which supplies all other intrinsic and extrinsic tongue muscles.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A - Styloglossus:
    Derived from occipital somites and innervated by hypoglossal nerve (CN XII).

  • Option C - Hyoglossus:
    Also derived from somites and supplied by hypoglossal nerve.

  • Option D - Genioglossus:
    This major extrinsic tongue muscle also originates from somite-derived mesoderm and is innervated by CN XII.

questions.text: A patient presented with acute exacerbation of bronchial asthma. Salbutamol inhalation did not improve the condition of the patient. So, intravenous corticosteroids and aminophylline were added and the condition improved. What is the mechanism of action of corticosteroids in this condition?

choices.text: They cause bronchodilation when given with xanthines
They increase bronchial responsiveness to salbutamol
They increase the action of aminophylline on adenosine receptors

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - They increase bronchial responsiveness to salbutamol:

Explanation:

Prasugrel is a third-generation thienopyridine antiplatelet agent that acts by irreversibly inhibiting the P2Y₁₂ ADP receptor on platelets, just like clopidogrel. However, it is more potent, has faster onset, and shows less inter-individual variability in response. This comes at the cost of an increased risk of major bleeding, particularly in patients with a history of stroke or transient ischemic attack (TIA)—in whom prasugrel is contraindicated.

Clinical Pharmacology:

  • Mechanism of Action:
    Prasugrel is a prodrug that is converted into its active metabolite more efficiently than clopidogrel, leading to more consistent and rapid platelet inhibition. It irreversibly binds to the P2Y₁₂ receptor, preventing ADP-mediated platelet activation and aggregation.

  • Clinical Use:
    Used in acute coronary syndrome (ACS) and after percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) with stent placement, often in dual antiplatelet therapy (with aspirin).

  • Bleeding Risk and Contraindications:
    Its stronger antiplatelet effect means it is contraindicated in patients with prior stroke or TIA, and used cautiously in those over 75 years or weighing less than 60 kg.

It is slower acting than clopidogrel (Option A):
Incorrect. Prasugrel has a faster onset due to more efficient hepatic conversion to its active metabolite.
Ruled out.

Due to higher risk of bleeding, prasugrel is contraindicated in stroke (Option B):
Correct. Major bleeding is more common with prasugrel, and it is absolutely contraindicated in patients with prior stroke or TIA.
Selected.

It is a reversible antagonist of ADP receptors (Option C):
Incorrect. Prasugrel (like clopidogrel) irreversibly binds the P2Y₁₂ ADP receptor.
Ruled out.

It is effective orally unlike clopidogrel (Option D):
Incorrect. Both prasugrel and clopidogrel are orally administered prodrugs that require metabolic activation.
Ruled out.

questions.text: A patient’s renal plasma flow (RPF) is estimated through para-aminohippuric acid (PAH) clearance measurement. The technician inadvertently uses the recommended dose of PAH thrice due to an error in the weighing. The RPF estimated is likely to be?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B – False-low:

  • Para-aminohippuric acid (PAH) is used to estimate Renal Plasma Flow (RPF) because, at low plasma concentrations, it is almost completely cleared from the blood in a single pass through the kidneys due to both glomerular filtration and highly efficient active tubular secretion. This allows its clearance to accurately reflect RPF.
  • However, when an excessively high dose of PAH is administered, the active tubular secretory transporters become saturated (i.e., their transport maximum, Tm, is exceeded).
  • This saturation means that a significant portion of the PAH delivered to the kidneys cannot be actively secreted into the urine and therefore is not cleared from the blood during that pass. As a result, the amount of PAH appearing in the urine will be less than what would be expected if all the PAH had been cleared.
  • When calculating RPF using the standard clearance formula (ClPAH​=(UPAH​×V)/PPAH​), this leads to an underestimation of the true renal plasma flow, resulting in a falsely low estimate.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and d are incorrect.

questions.text: During glycolysis, several enzymes catalyze steps that are either reversible or irreversible. Which one of the following enzymes is not responsible for an irreversible reaction in the glycolytic pathway?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Enolase:

Enolase catalyzes the conversion of 2-phosphoglycerate (2-PG) to phosphoenolpyruvate (PEP) → a reversible reaction in glycolysis.

In contrast, the following steps are irreversible due to their large negative ΔG (free energy change), making them rate-limiting and regulatory points:

  • Hexokinase: Glucose → Glucose-6-phosphate
  • Phosphofructokinase-1 (PFK-1): Fructose-6-phosphate → Fructose-1,6-bisphosphate
  • Pyruvate kinase: Phosphoenolpyruvate → Pyruvate

questions.text:
Analyze the inheritance pattern of a genetic disorder observed in a family, as described by the following pedigree characteristics:



Based on these observations, which of the following genetic disorders is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Alpha 1 Antitrypsin Deficiency:

Correct Answer: Alpha 1 Antitrypsin Deficiency

Short Justification:
The pedigree shows an autosomal recessive pattern:

  • Affected individuals are born to unaffected parents (carriers),

  • The trait skips generations,

  • Both sexes are equally affected,

  • There is male-to-male transmission, which rules out X-linked inheritance.

Alpha 1 Antitrypsin Deficiency is a classic autosomal recessive disorder and fits the pedigree pattern best.

Pedigree Analysis & Inheritance Patterns

1. Understanding Pedigree Symbols

  • ⬜ = Unaffected male

  • ⚪ = Unaffected female

  • ⬛ = Affected male

  • ⚫ = Affected female

  • Horizontal line = Mating

  • Vertical line = Offspring

  • Generations go from top (oldest) to bottom (youngest)

Step-by-Step Analysis of the Pedigree

A. Sex Distribution of Affected Individuals

  • Both males and females are affected

    • Rules out sex-limited inheritance.

    • X-linked disorders are still possible, but need further analysis.

B. Parent-to-Child Transmission

  • Affected individuals often born to unaffected parents.

    • Suggests recessive inheritance.

  • No consistent appearance of the disorder in every generation.

    • Suggests non-dominant pattern (rules out autosomal dominant).

  • Male-to-male transmission is present

    • Rules out X-linked inheritance, as fathers don’t pass X-linked traits to sons.

Comparison of the Given Disorders

Disorder

Inheritance

Key Features

Fit with Pedigree

Huntington's Disease (Option A)

Autosomal Dominant

Affects every generation, late onset

Doesn't skip generations

Alpha 1 Antitrypsin Deficiency (Option B)

Autosomal Recessive

Lung/liver involvement, both sexes

Matches pedigree perfectly

Hemophilia A (Option C)

X-linked Recessive

Mostly males, no male-to-male transmission

Male-to-male seen here

Hypophosphatemic Rickets (Option D)

X-linked Dominant

More females affected, passed from father to all daughters

Pattern inconsistent

questions.text:
Which of the following correctly matches the type of urethral injury with its features?


	
		
			
			Types of Urethral Injury
			
			
			Features
			
		
		
			
			1. Anterior urethral injury
			
			
			a. Road traffic accident
			
		
		
			
			2. Posterior urethral injury
			
			
			b. Straddle injury
			
		
		
			
			 
			
			
			c. Butterfly-shaped hematoma
			
		
		
			
			 
			
			
			d. Pelvic hematoma
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 1-b,c and 2-a,d:

  • Anterior Urethral Injury:
    • This is typically caused by a straddle injury (b).
    • The resulting hemorrhage can spread in the superficial perineal pouch, forming a characteristic butterfly-shaped hematoma (c).
  • Posterior Urethral Injury:
    • This is commonly associated with high-impact trauma like a road traffic accident (a), often leading to pelvic fractures.
    • Bleeding from this injury tends to accumulate as a pelvic hematoma (d) within the deep pelvic spaces.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: Which muscle's strong contraction or pull is primarily implicated in the mechanism of a Jones fracture?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Peroneus brevis:

  • The Peroneus brevis (also known as Fibularis brevis) muscle inserts onto the tubercle at the base of the 5th metatarsal. A Jones fracture occurs at the metaphyseal-diaphyseal junction of the 5th metatarsal, and the strong pull of the Peroneus brevis tendon can contribute to the fracture mechanism at this specific, vulnerable area.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Tibialis anterior: Inserts on the medial cuneiform and base of the first metatarsal; primarily an ankle dorsiflexor and invertor.

Option B - Peroneus longus: Inserts on the base of the first metatarsal and medial cuneiform; primarily an ankle evertor and plantarflexor.

Option D - Gastrocnemius: A major calf muscle responsible for ankle plantarflexion, not directly involved in the mechanism of a Jones fracture.

questions.text: Which of the following changes would most likely be observed in a patient with defective Pendrin protein?

choices.text: Increased TSH and impaired iodide organification
Normal TSH with increased serum T4 and T3

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Increased TSH and impaired iodide organification:

  • The Pendrin protein is an iodide-chloride transporter (Cl-/I- exchanger) on the apical membrane of thyroid follicular cells, crucial for transporting iodide from the cell into the follicular lumen (colloid). Here, iodide is oxidized and incorporated into thyroglobulin via a process called organification.
    • A defective Pendrin protein directly impairs this transport, leading to a defect in iodide organification. This significantly reduces the synthesis of thyroid hormones (T3 and T4).
    • The resulting low T3/T4 levels lead to a loss of negative feedback on the anterior pituitary, causing increased TSH secretion. This is the hallmark of primary hypothyroidism.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Decreased TSH and increased T3/T4: This describes hyperthyroidism, the opposite of the hypothyroid state caused by Pendrin deficiency.

Option C - Decreased thyroglobulin synthesis: Pendrin is involved in iodide transport and organification, not the synthesis of the thyroglobulin protein itself.

Option D - Normal TSH with increased serum T4 and T3: This describes euthyroidism or hyperthyroidism, which is inconsistent with Pendrin deficiency.

questions.text: Two diagnostic tests—Impedance plethysmography and radioactive fibrinogen leg scanning with I-125—are used together to detect deep vein thrombosis (DVT). What is the primary benefit of this testing approach?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Increase in negative predictive value:

  • Correct – Parallel testing increases sensitivity, which means fewer false negatives. This leads to an improvement in NPV, making it easier to rule out disease.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Positive Predictive Value (PPV): Incorrect – PPV increases with serial testing where both tests must be positive. In parallel testing, false positives increase, which can reduce PPV.

Option C - Pre-test Odds: Incorrect – Pre-test odds are based on disease prevalence and patient characteristics, and do not change with the number of tests used.

Option D - Specificity: Incorrect – Specificity increases in serial testing (both tests must be positive). Parallel testing may reduce specificity due to more false positives.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old male presents to the outpatient department with persistent swelling and dull aching pain around the knee joint. An X-ray of the knee joint reveals the following findings.



Which of the following is not a characteristic of the disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B – More common in males:

  • An X-ray of the knee joint reveals a well-defined, expansile, lytic lesion in the epiphysis, without periosteal reaction, giving a “soap bubble” appearance, which is suggestive of a Giant cell tumor.
  • Giant Cell Tumor (GCT) typically arises from the epiphysis of long bones (e.g., distal femur, proximal tibia).(Option A)
  • It most commonly occurs in young adults (20–40 years).
  • There is a female preponderance.
  • On clinical examination, eggshell crackling can be felt due to cortical thinning. (Option C)
  • Extended curettage with or without bone grafting/cementing is the treatment of choice; wide excision is reserved for aggressive or recurrent tumors. (Option D)

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: The mechanism shown in the image below is exhibited by all of the following microorganisms, except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Vibrio cholerae

Swarming motility is a type of rapid, coordinated surface movement exhibited by some flagellated bacteria on solid media. While Proteus, Clostridium tetani, and Bacillus cereus demonstrate this behavior, Vibrio cholerae does not exhibit swarming motility under normal culture conditions.

 

Bacterial Motility Patterns – particularly swarming, is a characteristic type of surface translocation seen in some Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacilli with peritrichous flagella. It's commonly observed as concentric rings or waves on agar plates due to synchronized movement.

Comparison of Swarming Behavior in Bacteria

Bacterium Gram Stain Flagella Type Swarming Motility Notes
Proteus mirabilis Gram-negative Peritrichous Yes Classic swarming; concentric growth rings
Clostridium tetani Gram-positive Peritrichous Yes Shows spreading growth on media
Bacillus cereus Gram-positive Peritrichous Yes Demonstrates swarming in rich media
Vibrio cholerae Gram-negative Single polar flagellum No Motile, but does not swarm

 

Proteus mirabilis (Option A):
Exhibits classic swarming on blood agar. Known for this behavior and often used as an example in microbiology.

Clostridium tetani (Option B):
Shows spreading colony morphology due to motility, including swarming-like behavior on moist media.

Bacillus cereus (Option D):
Exhibits swarming motility with rapid surface movement on nutrient-rich agar.

Vibrio cholerae (Option C):
Although motile with a single polar flagellum, it does not exhibit swarming behavior on solid media. Hence, this is the correct answer.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male is found unconscious near a pond and declared dead. Autopsy shows haemodilution, hyponatremia, and hyperkalemia. Lungs are overinflated, heavy, and show fine froth. Based on these findings, what type of drowning is most likely?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Freshwater drowning:

  • Freshwater drowning: Hypotonic water gets rapidly absorbed, leading to hemodilution, hemolysis, hyperkalemia, hyponatremia, and ventricular fibrillation. The person was possibly drowned in a freshwater and later his body was dumped near the pond.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: In dry water drowning, water does not enter the lungs.

Option B: Saltwater drowning causes hypernatremia and pulmonary edema due to hypertonicity of saltwater.

Option D: Atypical drowning is also known as dry drowning; water does not enter the lungs.

questions.text: Which of the following nerve fiber types is characterized by having the longest action potential duration?

choices.text: Spike duration is equal for all the nerve fibers

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - C fiber:

  • Nerve fibers are classified based on their diameter and myelination, which significantly influence their conduction velocity and action potential characteristics.
    • A fibers are large, myelinated, and have the fastest conduction velocity and the shortest action potential duration.
    • B fibers are medium-sized, myelinated, with intermediate conduction velocity and action potential duration.
    • C fibers are the smallest in diameter and unmyelinated. Due to their smaller size and lack of myelination, they have the slowest conduction velocity. Crucially, their ion channels operate more slowly, leading to a longer duration of depolarization and repolarization, resulting in the highest (longest) spike duration during an action potential among the three types.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presents with severe nausea and vomiting, vaginal bleeding, and uterine size larger than expected for her gestational age (estimated 12 weeks). Her serum β-hCG level is markedly elevated at 250,000 mIU/mL. Transvaginal ultrasound reveals a "snowstorm" appearance in the uterine cavity with no identifiable fetal pole.What is the most likely diagnosis, and what is the primary concern for long-term follow-up in this patient?

choices.text: Complete Hydatidiform Mole; risk of gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN)
Partial Hydatidiform Mole; risk of recurrent miscarriage
Missed Abortion; risk of Asherman's syndrome
Ectopic Pregnancy; risk of tubal rupture

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Complete Hydatidiform Mole; risk of gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN):

This patient presents with classic features of a complete molar pregnancy: first-trimester vaginal bleeding, excessive vomiting, uterine size larger than dates, extremely elevated β-hCG, and “snowstorm” appearance on ultrasound. The primary long-term concern is progression to gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN), including invasive mole or choriocarcinoma.

Molar Pregnancy (Hydatidiform Mole): Diagnosis and Long-Term Concerns

Feature Complete Mole Partial Mole
Karyotype 46,XX or 46,XY (paternal only) Triploid: 69,XXY/XXX/XYY (maternal + paternal)
Fetal Tissue Absent Present (but abnormal fetus)
Ultrasound Finding “Snowstorm” or cluster of grapes appearance, no fetal pole Abnormal fetus + cystic placenta
Uterine Size Larger than gestational age May be normal or slightly increased
β-hCG Levels Markedly elevated (>100,000 mIU/mL common) Mildly to moderately elevated
Common Symptoms Hyperemesis, early-onset preeclampsia, vaginal bleeding Similar but less severe
Risk of GTN 15–20% in complete mole 1–5% in partial mole
Follow-Up Requirement Serial β-hCG monitoring until undetectable for at least 6 months  
Contraception Advice Delay pregnancy for ≥6–12 months to monitor hCG levels clearly  

 

Partial Hydatidiform Mole; risk of recurrent miscarriage (Option B):
Partial mole has fetal parts and triploidy, but lesser risk of GTN. Recurrent miscarriage is not the primary concern.

Missed Abortion; risk of Asherman's syndrome (Option C):
This would not present with very high β-hCG or snowstorm appearance; Asherman’s is a complication of curettage, not molar pregnancy.

Ectopic Pregnancy; risk of tubal rupture (Option D):
Ectopic pregnancies show empty uterus and adnexal mass, not uterine enlargement or high β-hCG to this extent.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old male with a history of long-standing rheumatoid arthritis presents with increasing fatigue and dyspnea on exertion. His current medications include methotrexate and prednisone. Laboratory investigations reveal:


	Hemoglobin: 9.8 g/dL
	MCV: 78 fL (Normal: 80-100 fL)
	Serum Iron: 35 µg/dL (Normal: 60-170 µg/dL)
	Total Iron Binding Capacity (TIBC): 410 µg/dL (Normal: 250-400 µg/dL)
	Serum Ferritin: 110 ng/mL (Normal: 30-300 ng/mL)
	C-reactive protein (CRP): 32 mg/L (Normal: < 5 mg/L)


Given the most likely diagnosis of anemia in this patient, which of the following is the most appropriate initial management step?

choices.text: Oral iron supplementation at a dose of 325 mg ferrous sulfate daily.
Blood transfusion to achieve a hemoglobin target of 12 g/dL.

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Oral iron supplementation at a dose of 325 mg ferrous sulfate daily:

Explanation:

This patient with microcytic anemia (MCV 78 fL), low serum iron, elevated TIBC, and normal ferritin likely has iron deficiency anemia — not anemia of chronic disease. Despite having rheumatoid arthritis (RA) and an elevated CRP, the iron profile points more toward true iron deficiency, and oral iron therapy is the first-line management.

Iron Deficiency Anemia vs Anemia of Chronic Disease (ACD):

Parameter Iron Deficiency Anemia Anemia of Chronic Disease
Serum Iron ↓ ↓
TIBC ↑ ↓ or normal
Ferritin ↓ Normal or ↑
MCV ↓ (microcytic) Normal or ↓ (normocytic/micro)
CRP May be elevated if comorbid ↑

 

  • In this case:

    • Serum iron: Low

    • TIBC: Elevated → favors iron deficiency

    • Ferritin: Normal but may be falsely elevated in inflammation (acute phase reactant)

    • MCV: Microcytic

    • CRP: High (consistent with RA, but doesn't explain TIBC increase)

This pattern best fits iron deficiency anemia, and oral iron supplementation is the appropriate initial management.

 

Initiation of ESA therapy (Option A):
Used in anemia of chronic kidney disease or ACD only after iron repletion and when anemia is more severe. Not first-line in iron deficiency.

High-dose IVIG therapy (Option C):
Indicated for autoimmune cytopenias (e.g., ITP), not useful in iron deficiency or ACD.

Blood transfusion to achieve Hb of 12 g/dL (Option D):
Transfusion is reserved for severe anemia (e.g., Hb < 7 g/dL or symptomatic). Targeting Hb of 12 is not recommended and could be harmful.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents to the emergency department after being bitten by a snake. He complains of severe localized pain, swelling, and ecchymosis at the bite site. He also reports generalized weakness and has developed mild ptosis. There is no evidence of active bleeding from the bite site or other orifices. Which of the following is the most crucial initial treatment component for this patient?

choices.text: Surgical debridement of the bite site.
Application of a tourniquet above the bite.

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Administration of intravenous antivenom:

Explanation:

Snakebite envenomation can cause a spectrum of clinical manifestations, ranging from localized pain, swelling, and tissue damage to systemic symptoms like neurotoxicity, coagulopathy, and shock. The venom components vary by species but often include neurotoxins, hemotoxins, and cytotoxins.

Local signs: Pain, swelling, ecchymosis, and sometimes necrosis occur near the bite site. These indicate tissue injury and venom effect locally.

Systemic signs: Neurotoxicity is characterized by ptosis, muscle weakness, and respiratory failure due to paralysis of respiratory muscles. Hemotoxicity may lead to coagulopathy and bleeding.

Management:

  • Antivenom administration is critical and should be given intravenously as soon as systemic envenomation is evident or likely. It works by binding and neutralizing circulating venom components.

  • Supportive care includes monitoring airway, breathing, and circulation; managing shock or respiratory failure.

  • Surgical debridement is reserved for established tissue necrosis or compartment syndrome, not early in the course.

  • Antibiotics are only indicated if secondary infection develops; routine prophylactic antibiotics are not necessary.

  • Tourniquets and other constrictive devices are generally contraindicated as they can cause ischemic injury and worsen outcomes.

Early recognition and treatment with antivenom significantly reduce morbidity and mortality from snakebites.

 

Surgical debridement of the bite site (Option A):
Not indicated immediately. Surgery is only performed if there is clear necrosis or compartment syndrome after initial stabilization.

Prophylactic broad-spectrum antibiotics (Option C):
Not routinely recommended without signs of infection; snakebites are not uniformly infected.

Application of a tourniquet above the bite (Option D):
Contraindicated due to risk of ischemia and worsening tissue damage. Pressure immobilization may be used in some cases but tight tourniquets should be avoided.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male underwent thyroidectomy for a multinodular goiter. Postoperatively, he develops stridor. On indirect laryngoscopy, both vocal cords are in midline position. Which of the following is most likely responsible for his condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Bilateral Recurrent laryngeal nerve injury

  • The recurrent laryngeal nerve supplies all intrinsic muscles of the larynx except the cricothyroid (which is supplied by the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve). If both RLNs are injured, the vocal cords lie in midline position.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Unilateral superior laryngeal nerve injury does not cause stridor, and the affected vocal cord lies abducted, whereas the normal vocal cord lies in intermediate position.

Option B - Bilateral superior laryngeal nerve injury does not cause stridor, and both vocal cords lie in an abducted position.

Option C - Unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury causes dyspnea on exertion, not stridor. Also, the affected cord lies in the midline, and the normal cord lies in intermediate position.

questions.text: A 35-year-old known HIV-positive male dies due to respiratory complications. An autopsy is planned to determine the exact cause of death. Which of the following postmortem techniques is most appropriate in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - In-situ technique:

  • In infectious cases like HIV, the In-situ/Rockitansky technique (inside dissection) is preferred as it minimizes handling and exposure to infected blood and tissues.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D are not preferred while performing an autopsy on individuals with infectious diseases.

questions.text: What is the limit for blood loss in an LSCS after which intervention is required?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - 1000mL:

In cesarean section (LSCS), blood loss exceeding 1000 mL is considered postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) and requires intervention. This is the threshold defined by most obstetric guidelines for surgical deliveries.

Postpartum Hemorrhage (PPH): Definitions and Interventions

Parameter Vaginal Delivery Cesarean Section (LSCS)
Normal Expected Blood Loss ≤500 mL ≤1000 mL
PPH Definition >500 mL >1000 mL
Classification Minor: 500–1000 mL
Major: >1000 mL		 Minor: up to 1000 mL
Major: >1000 mL
Clinical Signs to Watch Hypotension, tachycardia, pallor, decreasing urine output  
Initial Management IV fluids, uterotonics (oxytocin, misoprostol), uterine massage  
Advanced Management Tranexamic acid, blood transfusion, surgical interventions (compression sutures, uterine artery ligation, hysterectomy)  

 

500 mL (Option A):
This is the PPH threshold for vaginal delivery, not cesarean section.

2000 mL (Option B):
This is considered severe PPH, but intervention should begin much earlier.

1500 mL (Option C):
Also indicates major hemorrhage, but action is required at 1000 mL.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents with unilateral, painless, progressive blurring of vision after a recent fall. On slit-lamp examination, a posterior subcapsular opacity is seen in the affected eye. Which of the following is LEAST likely related to the underlying cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: C. Oil drop cataract

 

The patient presents with unilateral, painless, progressive visual blurring following blunt trauma, with a posterior subcapsular opacity on slit-lamp examination — classical for traumatic cataract. Among the listed options, the oil drop cataract is not related to trauma but instead occurs in galactosemia, making it the least likely cause in this trauma-related presentation.

Traumatic Cataracts and Related Ocular Findings

Traumatic cataract typically follows blunt or penetrating injury to the eye. It commonly manifests as:

  • Rosette-shaped posterior subcapsular opacities (especially in blunt trauma)

  • Vossius ring (pigment imprint on anterior lens from iris)

  • Berlin’s edema (trauma-induced retinal whitening, also called commotio retinae)

In contrast, some cataract morphologies are linked to metabolic or systemic disorders, not trauma.
One example is the oil drop cataract, which is associated with galactosemia, a congenital metabolic disorder in infants.

 

 

Rosette cataract (Option A):

  • Classically seen in blunt ocular trauma.

  • Characterized by a stellate or rosette-shaped posterior subcapsular opacity.

  • Matches the traumatic mechanism and slit-lamp finding described.

Vossius ring (Option B):

  • Occurs due to blunt trauma, leading to pigment imprinting from the iris onto the anterior lens capsule.

  • Represents transient mechanical compression of the eye.

  • Commonly coexists with traumatic cataracts.

 

Berlin’s edema (Option D):

  • Also called commotio retinae.

  • Represents retinal whitening due to blunt trauma.

  • Though a retinal finding (not lens), it is a trauma-related entity and may co-occur with traumatic cataracts.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with chronic back pain that is worse in the morning, improves with exercise, and has been associated with progressive spinal stiffness for the past two years. Spinal imaging is performed.Which of the following radiological signs is not typically seen in a patient with Ankylosing Spondylitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Dog collar appearance:

  • The clinical history is classic for Ankylosing Spondylitis (AS), a chronic inflammatory arthropathy primarily affecting the axial skeleton.
  • Radiological findings seen in spine are:
    • Option A - Bamboo spine appearance: This is a characteristic sign of advanced AS, resulting from extensive ossification of the annulus fibrosus and spinal ligaments, leading to fusion of the vertebral bodies.
    • Option B - Romanus lesion: Refers to erosions at the anterior corners of the vertebral bodies, often with reactive sclerosis ("shiny corner sign"), an early spinal lesion in AS.
    • Option C - Dagger spine appearance: This sign is seen on an AP (anteroposterior) view of the spine in AS, characterized by ossification of the interspinous and supraspinous ligaments, appearing as a single dense central line.
  • Dog collar appearance: This is a radiological sign seen on oblique views of the lumbar spine and is characteristic of spondylolysis (a defect or fracture in the pars interarticularis). It refers to the appearance of the "neck" of the "Scotty dog" (a visual analogy used to describe the lumbar vertebra on oblique views) losing its "collar."

questions.text: Which of the following is the classic murmur associated with rheumatic mitral stenosis?

choices.text: High-pitched pansystolic murmur at the apex
Harsh systolic murmur radiating to the carotids
Low-pitched mid-diastolic murmur with opening snap at the apex
Continuous machinery murmur at the left infraclavicular area

questions.solution:
Correct Option C- Low-pitched mid-diastolic murmur with opening snap at the apex:

Rheumatic mitral stenosis classically presents with a low-pitched, rumbling mid-diastolic murmur best heard at the apex, often preceded by an opening snap due to sudden tensing of stenotic mitral valve leaflets.

In rheumatic heart disease, mitral stenosis is the most common valvular lesion. The narrowing of the mitral valve leads to elevated left atrial pressure, pulmonary congestion, and reduced left ventricular filling.

Auscultatory features of classic mitral stenosis include:

  • Loud S1: due to the stiff but still mobile mitral valve leaflets

  • Opening snap: occurs shortly after S2; the shorter the interval between S2 and the snap, the more severe the stenosis

  • Mid-diastolic murmur: low-pitched, rumbling, best heard at the apex in the left lateral decubitus position, using the bell of the stethoscope

  • May be preceded by presystolic accentuation if the patient is in sinus rhythm

High-pitched pansystolic murmur at the apex (Option A):
Suggests mitral regurgitation, not mitral stenosis.

Harsh systolic murmur radiating to the carotids (Option B):
Typical of aortic stenosis, not mitral disease.

Continuous machinery murmur at the left infraclavicular area (Option D):
Characteristic of patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), not mitral stenosis.

questions.text:
An 80-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her family, who found her lethargic and disoriented. They report a gradual decline in her mental status over the past few days, accompanied by increasing fatigue, constipation, and cold intolerance for several months. She has no known history of thyroid disease. On examination, her body temperature is 34.5°C (94.1°F), pulse is 48 bpm, BP is 90/60 mmHg, and respirations are 8/min. Her skin is dry and cool, and she has non-pitting edema around her eyes and in her hands. Laboratory results reveal:


	Sodium: 120 mEq/L
	Glucose: 65 mg/dL
	Cortisol (random): 25 mcg/dL
	TSH: >100 mIU/L (high)
	Free T4: Undetectable (low)


Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Myxedema Coma:

 

This elderly woman presents with hypothermia, bradycardia, hypotension, altered mental status, and classic hypothyroid signs (fatigue, constipation, dry skin, non-pitting edema). Her labs show severe primary hypothyroidism (TSH >100, undetectable T4), hyponatremia, and hypoglycemia, all pointing toward myxedema coma, a life-threatening complication of longstanding, untreated hypothyroidism.

Diagnostic Features of Myxedema Coma:

  • Precipitated by stress (infection, cold exposure, sedatives) in someone with undiagnosed or untreated hypothyroidism

  • Clinical signs:

    • Hypothermia

    • Bradycardia, hypotension

    • Hypoventilation

    • Altered mental status → stupor, lethargy, coma

    • Non-pitting edema (e.g., periorbital), dry skin, cold intolerance

  • Lab features:

    • Severe hypothyroidism: TSH ↑↑, T4 ↓↓↓

    • Hyponatremia: from decreased free water clearance

    • Hypoglycemia: reduced gluconeogenesis

    • Cortisol: may be normal or high initially

Ruling Out Other Options:

Severe Sepsis with Hypothermia (Option A):
May mimic myxedema, but no signs of infection (no fever, leukocytosis, or source). Also, the profound hypothyroidism and classic stigmata make myxedema coma more likely.

Adrenal Crisis (Option B):
Can cause hypotension and hypoglycemia, but this patient has a high-normal cortisol (25 mcg/dL), which rules it out.

Hypoglycemic Coma (Option D):
Her glucose is low (65 mg/dL), but not low enough to cause coma, and hypothyroidism better explains the overall picture.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with erythematous plaques covered with silvery-white scales over the extensor surfaces of the elbows and knees. On gentle removal of scales, pinpoint bleeding spots are observed. What is this sign known as?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Auspitz sign

This is a classic clinical scenario of chronic plaque psoriasis, the most common type of psoriasis. Auspitz sign refers to pinpoint bleeding spots observed when scales are scraped off psoriatic plaques. This occurs due to the removal of the suprapapillary thin epidermis, exposing the dilated capillaries in dermal papillae.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Koebner phenomenon refers to the development of new psoriatic lesions at the site of trauma (like scratching, injury).

Option C - Candle wax sign refers to the waxy appearance of scales when gently scraped.

Option D - Woronoff ring refers to a blanching halo around a psoriatic plaque, seen during resolving lesions, especially after treatment

questions.text: A patient presents with reduced hearing in the left ear. The audiogram indicates sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL) in the left ear. Based on this, what would be the expected tuning fork test results?

choices.text: Left ear Rinne positive; Weber lateralized to the right
Left ear Rinne negative; Weber lateralized to the right
Left ear Rinne positive; Weber lateralized to the left
Left ear Rinne negative; Weber lateralized to the left

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Left ear Rinne positive; Weber lateralized to the right

  • In sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL), the Rinne test remains positive (air conduction > bone conduction), and the Weber test lateralizes to the better (right) ear, since SNHL decreases sound perception on the affected side.

Incorrect Options 

Option B - Left ear Rinne negative; Weber lateralized to the right

  • A negative Rinne indicates conductive hearing loss (CHL). This is inconsistent with SNHL, which presents with Rinne positive.

Option C - Left ear Rinne positive; Weber lateralized to the left

  • Weber localizing to the affected ear suggests conductive loss, not SNHL.

Option D - Left ear Rinne negative; Weber lateralized to the left

  • Both findings suggest conductive hearing loss, not consistent with audiogram showing SNHL.

questions.text:
A 12-year-old child presents with persistent, tender axillary lymphadenopathy. A biopsy of the enlarged lymph node reveals the following findings.



Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Bartonella henselae

The biopsy image shows stellate-shaped necrotizing granulomas, which are characteristic of Cat Scratch Disease caused by Bartonella henselae. This condition commonly presents in children or adolescents with tender regional lymphadenopathy, typically in the axillary region, following a cat scratch or bite.

Topic Discussion:

Histopathology:

  • The image shows stellate necrosis surrounded by granulomatous inflammation.

  • These are also referred to as stellate microabscesses, often centrally necrotic with surrounding histiocytes and neutrophils.

  • This is the classic histological hallmark of Cat Scratch Disease.

Clinical Clues:

  • Age: Pediatric case (12 years old)

  • Location: Axillary lymphadenopathy

  • Symptoms: Persistent and tender swelling

  • Likely Exposure: History of contact with cats (implied)

Pathogen:

  • Bartonella henselae

  • Gram-negative bacillus

  • Transmitted via scratch or bite from a kitten or cat

Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Option A):
Typically causes caseating granulomas, not stellate. Granulomas are more organized and may show Langhans giant cells.

Treponema pallidum (Option C):
In tertiary syphilis, causes gummatous lesions. Lymphadenopathy is more generalized and does not show stellate granulomas.

Histoplasma capsulatum (Option D):
Leads to caseating granulomas with intracellular yeast forms, especially within macrophages. The histological pattern is different from stellate microabscesses.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old female with chronic constipation and intermittent abdominal distension. The following finding was noted.



Which radiologic sign and likely diagnosis are indicated?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Napkin ring sign – Colonic adenocarcinoma:

The napkin ring or apple-core lesion on barium enema indicates circumferential constriction of the colon lumen caused by an annular colonic adenocarcinoma, leading to a characteristic narrowed, irregular, and shelf-like appearance.

Radiologic Signs and Associated Diagnoses

Radiologic Sign Description Likely Diagnosis
Apple-core lesion / Napkin ring sign Circumferential narrowing of the colon with irregular, shelf-like margins on barium enema, causing luminal stenosis. Colonic adenocarcinoma
Coffee bean sign Dilated, twisted loop of sigmoid colon resembling a coffee bean, seen on abdominal X-ray. Sigmoid volvulus
Lead-pipe colon Loss of haustral markings in the colon resulting in smooth, featureless tubular appearance. Chronic ulcerative colitis
Apple-core lesion (esophagus) Focal constriction with irregular margins seen in the esophagus, suggestive of malignancy. Carcinoma of the esophagus

 

Apple-core lesion – Carcinoma esophagus (Option A):
Apple-core lesion in esophagus differs from colonic napkin ring sign and relates to esophageal cancer, not colonic narrowing.

Coffee bean sign – Sigmoid volvulus (Option B):
Characteristic for sigmoid volvulus, but image shows circumferential luminal narrowing, not a dilated twisted loop.

Lead-pipe colon – Chronic ulcerative colitis (Option D):
Refers to loss of haustral folds in colon; does not produce apple-core or napkin ring appearance.

questions.text:
A 64-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department with sudden-onset right-sided weakness and slurred speech for the past 1.5 hours. Her past medical history includes hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. On examination, she is conscious, oriented, has right facial droop, right hemiparesis, and expressive aphasia. Non-contrast CT of the head shows no evidence of hemorrhage.

Which of the following is the next best step in management?

choices.text: Perform carotid Doppler and defer treatment
Defer thrombolysis as the window has passed

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Begin intravenous thrombolysis with alteplase:

This patient presents with acute ischemic stroke within the 4.5-hour window, and CT shows no hemorrhage, making her a candidate for intravenous thrombolysis (alteplase).

Acute ischemic stroke management follows a time-sensitive protocol:

  1. Presentation: Sudden-onset focal neurological deficits (e.g., hemiparesis, facial droop, aphasia).

  2. Time: Within 4.5 hours of symptom onset, thrombolysis can be considered.

  3. Imaging: Non-contrast CT to exclude hemorrhage (required before thrombolysis).

  4. If no hemorrhage, and no contraindications → proceed with IV alteplase (tPA).

This woman presents at 1.5 hours, with:

  • Symptoms of left MCA stroke (right hemiparesis + expressive aphasia)

  • CT rules out bleed
    → She is a clear candidate for IV thrombolysis

Aspirin and clopidogrel (Option A):
Used for secondary prevention or minor strokes/TIAs, but not first-line when the patient is within the thrombolysis window.

Carotid Doppler and defer treatment (Option C):
Carotid imaging is part of long-term stroke workup, not urgent management. Delaying thrombolysis worsens outcome.

Defer thrombolysis as the window has passed (Option D):
Incorrect — patient is within 4.5 hours. Delaying treatment would be inappropriate.

questions.text: In a study, migraine headache was found in 5 per 1000 men and 10 per 1000 women, all aged 30–35 years. Based on this, the conclusion is made that women have twice the risk of developing migraine compared to men. What is the validity of this conclusion?

choices.text: Incorrect because a ratio was used to compare the rates
Incorrect because it fails to account for cohort effects
Incorrect because it confuses incidence with prevalence

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Incorrect because it confuses incidence with prevalence:

  • The study reports prevalence (existing cases at a point in time), not incidence (new cases). Prevalence depends on both incidence and disease duration. Therefore, drawing conclusions about risk from prevalence is inappropriate.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - The inference is correct: Incorrect – Although the math (10/5 = 2) is correct, the issue lies in interpreting prevalence as if it reflects risk (which requires incidence data). Hence, the conclusion about "risk" is flawed.

Option B - Incorrect because a ratio was used to compare rates: Incorrect – Comparing disease frequency between two groups using a ratio (e.g., relative risk or prevalence ratio) is acceptable in epidemiology. The method is not the issue; the misinterpretation of the data is.

Option C - Incorrect because of cohort effect: Incorrect – Both groups (men and women) are in the same age range (30–35 years), so cohort effect is not a confounder here.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old female underwent an uneventful trabeculectomy for primary angle-closure glaucoma. Two days later, she presents with decreased vision and a shallow anterior chamber despite a patent peripheral iridectomy. Intraocular pressure is elevated. Fundus examination is limited.
Which of the following mechanisms BEST explains the pathophysiology of this condition?

choices.text: Pupillary block leading to iris bombe
Forward rotation of the ciliary body causing posterior misdirection of aqueous
Posterior synechiae leading to angle closure

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Forward rotation of the ciliary body causing posterior misdirection of aqueous:

The clinical scenario describes decreased vision, shallow anterior chamber, elevated IOP, and patent peripheral iridectomy following trabeculectomy — classic for aqueous misdirection syndrome, also known as malignant glaucoma.
This condition involves posterior misdirection of aqueous humor into or behind the vitreous body due to anterior rotation of the ciliary body, leading to anterior chamber shallowing despite a patent iridectomy.

Malignant Glaucoma (Aqueous Misdirection Syndrome)

  • Occurs postoperatively (commonly after trabeculectomy or cataract surgery)

  • Seen in angle-closure glaucoma patients, especially elderly women

  • Key features:

    • Shallow or flat anterior chamber despite patent iridectomy

    • Elevated intraocular pressure

    • Fundus view may be obscured due to media opacity or anterior segment shallowing

  • Mechanism:

    • Misrouting of aqueous humor posteriorly due to ciliary body rotation, causing pressure buildup behind the lens–iris diaphragm, pushing it forward.

 

Pupillary block leading to iris bombe (Option A):

  • Causes shallow anterior chamber, but only if peripheral iridectomy is not patent.

  • In this case, the iridectomy is patent, ruling out pupillary block.

Vitreous hemorrhage causing retinal traction (Option C):

  • May cause visual obscuration, but does not cause anterior chamber shallowing or raised IOP in this context.

  • Retinal traction is unrelated to the described anterior segment findings.

Posterior synechiae leading to angle closure (Option D):

  • Posterior synechiae can lead to secondary angle closure, but usually progresses gradually, and would also cause pupillary block, which is prevented here by a patent iridectomy.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old male with a history of hypertension presents with palpitations and mild shortness of breath for the past 6 hours. His pulse is irregularly irregular at 130 bpm, and BP is 124/78 mmHg. An ECG is obtained and shown below



Based on the ECG, which of the following features distinguishes this rhythm from atrial fibrillation?

choices.text: Absence of organized atrial activity and irregularly irregular rhythm
Presence of sawtooth flutter waves and regular ventricular rhythm
Presence of identifiable P-waves before every QRS complex
Completely disorganized baseline with variable R-R intervals

questions.solution:
Correct Option B-Presence of sawtooth flutter waves and regular ventricular rhythm:

The ECG shows regular sawtooth flutter waves, especially visible in leads II, III, and aVF, with a regular ventricular response, consistent with atrial flutter, not atrial fibrillation.

Atrial flutter and atrial fibrillation (AF) are both supraventricular tachyarrhythmias, but they have distinct features:

  • Atrial flutter:

    • Characterized by organized atrial activity with a regular atrial rate (~250–350 bpm), typically 300 bpm

    • Produces sawtooth flutter waves, especially visible in inferior leads (II, III, aVF)

    • Often associated with fixed AV conduction, commonly 2:1, resulting in a regular ventricular rate (~150 bpm)

  • Atrial fibrillation:

    • Marked by completely disorganized atrial activity

    • No distinct P waves

    • Irregularly irregular R-R intervals due to variable AV node conduction

In this patient:

  • Regular tachycardia at ~150 bpm

  • Sawtooth flutter waves present
    → Classic for atrial flutter with 2:1 AV block

Absence of organized atrial activity and irregularly irregular rhythm (Option A):
Describes atrial fibrillation, not flutter.

Presence of identifiable P-waves before every QRS complex (Option C):
Suggests sinus rhythm or atrial tachycardia, not flutter or AF.

Completely disorganized baseline with variable R-R intervals (Option D):
Also characteristic of atrial fibrillation, not flutter.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male with schizophrenia has been progressively declining in functioning over the past 3 years. He shows marked social withdrawal, emotional blunting, and poor hygiene. There are no features of hallucinations or delusions. What is the prognosis of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Worst:

  • This is a case of Simple Schizophrenia, characterized by negative symptoms without florid psychotic features. It has the worst prognosis among schizophrenia subtypes due to early onset, insidious course, and treatment resistance.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and C are not the prognosis of simple schizophrenia.
