questions.text: The triad of congenital rubella syndrome includes all, except:
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Intellectual disability:

The classic triad of congenital rubella syndrome (CRS) includes sensorineural deafness, congenital cataracts, and congenital heart defects (especially PDA and pulmonary artery stenosis). While intellectual disability may occur, it is not part of the classical triad.

Congenital Rubella Syndrome: Classical Features and Additional Manifestations

Category Features
Classical Triad Sensorineural deafness
Congenital cataracts
Congenital heart defects (PDA most common)
Neurologic Features Microcephaly, developmental delay, sometimes intellectual disability (non-triad component)
Other Ocular Features Retinopathy (salt-and-pepper), glaucoma
Other Cardiac Defects Pulmonary artery stenosis, ventricular septal defect
Growth and Hematologic Low birth weight, hepatosplenomegaly, thrombocytopenic purpura ("blueberry muffin" rash)
Cause Maternal rubella infection, especially during the first trimester
Prevention MMR vaccination of women of reproductive age

 

Sensorineural deafness (Option A):
Part of the triad and the most common manifestation.

Congenital cataract (Option B):
Classical feature affecting lens development due to intrauterine viral infection.

Congenital heart defect (Option C):
Included in the triad — typically patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) or pulmonary stenosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common type of hymen in females?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 

  • Image in option A shows a crescentic hymen, which is the most common type of hymen in females.

Incorrect Options:

Image in option B shows a Fimbriate hymen.

Image in option C shows Infantile hymen.

Image in option D shows a Septate hymen.

These are not the most common type of hymen in females.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a severely painful, swollen, and discoloured right lower leg. He reports a history of a deep wound to the leg received approximately 6 days prior while working in his garden. Physical examination reveals crepitus on examination of the affected area. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Clostridium perfringens

The clinical picture of rapidly progressing pain, swelling, discoloration, crepitus, and a history of a deep wound is classic for gas gangrene (clostridial myonecrosis), most commonly caused by Clostridium perfringens.

Clostridial Infections → Gas Gangrene (Myonecrosis)

Gas gangrene is a life-threatening infection of muscle tissue associated with gas production and necrosis. It is most often caused by Clostridium perfringens, a Gram-positive, anaerobic, spore-forming bacillus. This organism produces several exotoxins, most notably alpha toxin (lecithinase), which causes tissue destruction.

Comparison of Clostridium Species and Their Clinical Syndromes

Organism Key Disease Toxin / Feature Clinical Clue
Clostridium perfringens Gas gangrene, food poisoning Alpha toxin (lecithinase) Wound with gas, crepitus, tissue necrosis
Clostridium tetani Tetanus Tetanospasmin (neurotoxin) Spastic paralysis, lockjaw
Clostridium septicum Spontaneous gas gangrene (esp. colon cancer) Alpha toxin Seen in immunocompromised patients
Clostridium novyi Wound infections, gas gangrene Several toxins Less common; used experimentally

 

Clostridium tetani (Option A):
Causes tetanus, presenting with muscle rigidity and spasms, not crepitus or soft tissue gas. No myonecrosis.

Clostridium novyi (Option B):
Can cause soft tissue infections, but less common. Not the classic cause in post-traumatic gas gangrene.

Clostridium septicum (Option C):
Can cause spontaneous gas gangrene, especially in immunosuppressed patients (e.g., colon malignancy). Less likely in a healthy patient with a traumatic wound.

questions.text: A fully immunized individual (last tetanus dose taken 10 years ago) presents 3 hours after sustaining a clean, minor wound. What is the appropriate tetanus prophylaxis?

choices.text: Human tetanus immunoglobulin + single dose of tetanus toxoid

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Single dose of tetanus toxoid:

  • Correct – For a person with complete immunization >10 years ago, a single booster dose is sufficient for a clean, minor wound.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Full course of tetanus toxoid: Incorrect – This is required only for individuals with unknown or incomplete immunization history.

Option C - Human tetanus immunoglobulin: Incorrect – TIG is not indicated in clean wounds for immunized individuals; it is reserved for high-risk wounds or unimmunized persons.

Option D - TIG + single dose of toxoid: Incorrect – This combination is used in dirty wounds in individuals with uncertain or incomplete immunization history.

questions.text: Which of the following measures are examples of primordial prevention for non-communicable diseases (NCDs)?

choices.text: Salt restriction in regions with a high burden of NCDs
Promoting physical activity in high-risk areas

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Salt restriction in regions with a high burden of NCDs:

Salt restriction in high NCD burden regions

  • Primordial prevention: Helps prevent development of hypertension before it arises in the population by modifying dietary norms.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Smoking cessation in high-risk populations: Primary prevention: Targets existing risk factors (smoking), not the conditions that create them.

Option C - Promoting physical activity in high-risk areas: Primary prevention: Encourages behavior change in individuals with existing risk factors.

Option D - Early diagnosis and treatment: Secondary prevention: Detects disease early to begin timely intervention but doesn't prevent risk factor emergence.

questions.text: A baby is born with a length of 47 cm. At what age is the height expected to be approximately double the birth length?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - 4 years:

A child's height is expected to double the birth length (typically ~50 cm) by around 4 years of age. This growth milestone reflects normal early childhood development patterns.

Normal Growth Milestones in Children

Growth Indicator Typical Value / Milestone
Average Birth Length ~50 cm (normal range: 48–52 cm)
Length at 1 Year ~75 cm
Length at 2 Years ~85–90 cm
Length at 4 Years ~100 cm (approximately double the birth length)
Height at 12 Years ~150 cm (triple the birth length)
Growth Rate (0–1 yr) ~25 cm/year
Growth Rate (1–2 yrs) ~12 cm/year
Growth Rate (after 2 yrs) ~5–7 cm/year until puberty

 

5 months (Option A):
The baby may grow ~10–12 cm by 5 months, but this is not close to doubling the birth length.

1 year (Option B):
Length increases by about 50%, not double — expected length is ~75 cm.

2 years (Option C):
By 2 years, most children are ~85–90 cm; still not double birth length.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an expected complication in a patient with an AFI of 4cm?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Cord prolapse

  • An amniotic fluid index (AFI) <5cm indicates oligohydramnios and cord prolapse is not typically associated with oligohydramnios. It is a complication of polyhydramnios.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are complications encountered in oligohydramnios.

questions.text: A 6-month-old male child presents with recurrent viral infections. His blood tests reveal markedly reduced levels of IgG and absent mature B cells. Further evaluation shows a mutation in the BTK gene. Which of the following is TRUE regarding his condition?

choices.text: He should receive the live attenuated BCG vaccine
The condition is due to a T-cell defect leading to decreased opsonization of pathogens
He is more likely to develop paralytic disease if given oral polio vaccine
Plasma cell numbers are elevated due to compensatory proliferation

questions.solution:
The child has X-linked agammaglobulinemia (Bruton disease) due to a BTK gene mutation, leading to an absence of mature B cells and very low immunoglobulin levels (especially IgG). Because of this humoral immunodeficiency, live vaccines such as oral polio vaccine (OPV) can cause vaccine-associated paralytic poliomyelitis (VAPP) in these patients.

This condition typically presents in male infants after 6 months of age, once maternal IgG wanes. The key immunological findings are:

  • Absent or very low B cells in peripheral blood

  • Absent plasma cells

  • Low levels of all immunoglobulin classes (esp. IgG)

  • Mutation in Bruton tyrosine kinase (BTK) gene

Due to the lack of antibody-mediated viral neutralization, live attenuated vaccines like OPV, MMR, and BCG are contraindicated.

Feature X-linked Agammaglobulinemia
Genetic mutation BTK gene
Cell deficiency Mature B cells & plasma cells absent
Immunoglobulin levels ↓ IgG, IgA, IgM
Type of infections Recurrent bacterial & viral infections
Live vaccine risk ↑ risk of paralytic disease with OPV

 

He should receive the live attenuated BCG vaccine (Option A):
Incorrect. Live vaccines (e.g., BCG) are contraindicated in antibody deficiencies due to risk of disseminated infection.

The condition is due to a T-cell defect leading to decreased opsonization of pathogens (Option B):
Incorrect. The defect is in B cells, not T cells. Opsonization is impaired due to low IgG, not T-cell dysfunction.

Plasma cell numbers are elevated due to compensatory proliferation (Option D):
Incorrect. Plasma cells are absent in this condition because B-cell maturation fails.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female weighing 55 kg is brought to the emergency department 6 hours after consuming 10 grams of paracetamol along with alcohol. Her serum paracetamol level is 400 µg/mL. Which of the following is most likely?

choices.text: Abnormalities of kidney function are likely

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Hepatotoxicity is likely to occur:

Explanation:

Paracetamol (acetaminophen) toxicity risk is assessed using the Rumack-Matthew nomogram, which plots serum paracetamol levels vs. time since ingestion. A level of 400 µg/mL at 6 hours is well above the toxic threshold, indicating a high risk of hepatotoxicity. Co-ingestion of alcohol, which induces CYP2E1, increases the conversion of paracetamol to its toxic metabolite NAPQI, further raising the risk of liver damage.

Factor Value / Presence Clinical Significance
Dose of paracetamol 10 g (≈182 mg/kg for 55 kg person) >150 mg/kg = toxic threshold
Time since ingestion 6 hours Within window for reliable serum estimation via nomogram
Serum paracetamol level 400 µg/mL Clearly toxic (>200 µg/mL at 4 hrs; >100 µg/mL at 8 hrs)
Alcohol co-ingestion Yes Increases NAPQI via CYP2E1 induction → worsens hepatotoxicity

 

Gastric lavage is mandatory (Option A):
Incorrect. Gastric lavage is not routinely done after 6 hours, as it's most effective within 1 hour of ingestion. Beyond that, it's of little benefit and not mandatory.

Administration of activated charcoal (Option B):
Incorrect. Activated charcoal is most effective within 1–2 hours post-ingestion. At 6 hours, its role is minimal unless sustained-release preparation or co-ingestants delay gastric emptying.

Abnormalities of kidney function are likely (Option C):
Incorrect. While renal toxicity can occur in severe overdoses, hepatotoxicity is the primary and earliest concern in paracetamol overdose.

Hepatotoxicity is likely to occur (Option D):
Correct. The dose, serum level, time interval, and presence of alcohol all point to high risk of liver damage due to toxic NAPQI accumulation.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old male presents with progressive exertional dyspnea, cyanosis, and clubbing. He reports that he was diagnosed with a congenital heart defect in childhood but was lost to follow-up and never underwent corrective surgery. On examination, he has central cyanosis, a loud second heart sound, and a harsh systolic murmur best heard at the left upper sternal border. SpO₂ is 86% on room air. Chest X-ray is given below



Which of the following best explains the cyanosis in this patient?

choices.text: Increased pulmonary blood flow due to left-to-right shunting
Deoxygenated blood bypassing the lungs due to VSD and RVOT obstruction
Pulmonary venous desaturation due to alveolar hypoventilation

questions.solution:
Option B- Deoxygenated blood bypassing the lungs due to VSD and RVOT obstruction:

The patient has findings consistent with uncorrected Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF), and the cyanosis results from right-to-left shunting of deoxygenated blood across a ventricular septal defect (VSD) due to right ventricular outflow tract (RVOT) obstruction.

This presentation is classic for Tetralogy of Fallot, a congenital cyanotic heart disease comprising four components:

  1. Ventricular septal defect (VSD)

  2. Right ventricular outflow tract (RVOT) obstruction

  3. Right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH)

  4. Overriding aorta

In early life, TOF may present with left-to-right shunting, but as the RVOT obstruction worsens over time, pressure in the right ventricle exceeds the left, reversing the shunt direction (right-to-left). This allows deoxygenated blood to bypass the lungs and enter systemic circulation, causing cyanosis, clubbing, and polycythemia.

On exam:

  • Loud second heart sound: due to pulmonary hypertension or diminished flow

  • Harsh systolic murmur at the left upper sternal border: due to RVOT obstruction

  • SpO₂ 86%: indicates chronic hypoxemia

  • Chest X-ray (classic “boot-shaped” heart): consistent with TOF

Increased pulmonary blood flow due to left-to-right shunting (Option A):
Seen in acyanotic congenital heart disease (e.g., VSD or ASD without obstruction). It causes pulmonary overcirculation, but not cyanosis.

Pulmonary venous desaturation due to alveolar hypoventilation (Option C):
Occurs in respiratory failure, not congenital heart disease. Would not explain a harsh systolic murmur or childhood diagnosis of a heart defect.

Secondary erythrocytosis leading to hyperviscosity (Option D):
This is a complication of chronic hypoxia, not the primary mechanism of cyanosis. It worsens symptoms but does not explain the underlying cyanotic process.

questions.text: A 3-day-old full-term neonate presents with bilious vomiting, abdominal distension, and failure to pass meconium. Abdominal X-ray shows multiple dilated loops of bowel with air-fluid levels and a "double bubble" sign. This condition is NOT commonly associated with which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Pyloric stenosis:

  • The clinical presentation and "double bubble" sign are classic for duodenal atresia.
  • Duodenal atresia is commonly associated with: (Mnemonic: DAM BPP)
    • Down syndrome
    • Annular pancreas – Obstruction is proximal to ampulla, non-bilious vomiting
    • Malrotations
    • Biliary atresia
    • Polyhydramnios
    • Prematurity
  • Pyloric stenosis, a condition causing gastric outlet obstruction, typically presents later (around 3-6 weeks of age) with non-bilious projectile vomiting, and is not a common congenital association with duodenal atresia.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and C are incorrect.

questions.text: In the early stages of a lower motor neuron (LMN) lesion, which of the following pathological contractions characterized by visible, jerky, and involuntary contraction is likely to be observed in a muscle supplied by the affected LMN?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Fasciculation:

  • In the early stages of a lower motor neuron (LMN) lesion, the affected motor neurons become irritable as they begin to degenerate. This irritation leads to the spontaneous, asynchronous discharge of entire motor units (a motor neuron and all the muscle fibers it innervates). These contractions are known as fasciculations. They are characterized by being:
    • Visible: Apparent as a "quivering" or "twitching" movement under the skin.
    • Jerky: Though often described as subtle, they are distinct, involuntary movements.
    • Involuntary: Not under conscious control.
    • Early stage: Can be observed relatively soon after the onset of the LMN lesion.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Tetanic contractions: These are sustained, strong muscle contractions resulting from rapid, successive stimuli, either physiological or pathological (e.g., in tetanus disease.

Option B - Fibrillation: It is the spontaneous contraction of individual muscle fibers, not visible to the naked eye.

Option C - Spasticity: This is a form of hypertonia characterized by a velocity-dependent resistance to passive stretch. A classic sign of a UMN lesion.

questions.text: An outbreak of MRSA (Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus) has been reported in a hospital ward. Which of the following is the most effective measure to control the spread of infection?

choices.text: Empirically administering vancomycin to all patients
Using masks before invasive procedures in the ICU
Hand hygiene before and after patient contact

questions.solution:
Correct Option D -  Hand hygiene before and after patient contact:

  • Correct – Hand hygiene is the single most effective measure to prevent and control MRSA and other healthcare-associated infections. Disinfectant-based hand rubs are especially effective.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Empirically administering vancomycin to all patients: Incorrect – Empirical treatment without culture confirmation can promote antibiotic resistance and is not justified for all patients. Vancomycin is reserved for confirmed MRSA infections.

Option B - Regular fumigation of the ward: Incorrect – Fumigation has limited utility in controlling contact-based transmission like MRSA. It is not practical or evidence-based for routine control of such outbreaks.

Option C - Using masks before invasive procedures in the ICU​​​​​​​: Incorrect – While masks reduce droplet transmission, MRSA is primarily spread via direct contact, especially through contaminated hands or surfaces.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT typically associated with infarction in this area?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Apraxia

  • The paracentral lobule is located on the medial surface of the cerebral hemisphere and includes portions of both the precentral (motor) and postcentral (sensory) gyri.

  • It primarily represents the lower limb and perineal region on the motor and sensory homunculi.

  • It plays a key role in:

    • Voluntary motor control of the lower limb

    • Bladder and bowel function

    • Sensory input from perineal area

Incorrect Options (All are True for Paracentral Lobule Lesion):

  • Option A - Urinary incontinence:
    Correct. Lesion of the paracentral lobule affects the micturition center, leading to incontinence.

  • Option B- Rectal incontinence:
    Correct. Defecation control is also integrated in this area, and infarction may lead to loss of voluntary anal sphincter control.

  • Option D - Perianal anesthesia:
    Correct. As the sensory cortex for the perineum lies in this region, a lesion can cause loss of sensation in the perianal area.

questions.text: An elderly hypertensive patient with diabetes mellitus is found to have bilateral renal artery stenosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate antihypertensive agent for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Verapamil

In patients with bilateral renal artery stenosis, agents that interfere with the renin-angiotensin system- such as ACE inhibitors (e.g., enalapril)- can significantly lower glomerular filtration pressure, potentially triggering acute renal failure. Among the available options, verapamil, a non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker, is safe, effective, and metabolically neutral, making it especially suitable for hypertensive patients with diabetes mellitus and compromised renal perfusion.

Option Appropriateness in Bilateral RAS + Diabetes Explanation
Enalapril (Option A) Not appropriate ACE inhibitor → dilates efferent arteriole → decreases GFR → may precipitate renal failure
Verapamil (Option B) Most appropriate Calcium channel blocker → maintains renal perfusion, safe in diabetes, no adverse effect on GFR
Beta blockers (Option C) Acceptable but not ideal May impair glucose tolerance, less effective in elderly with isolated systolic HTN
Thiazides (Option D) Used with caution Risk of worsening glycemic control and less effective in renal insufficiency

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with photosensitivity, malar rash, arthralgia, and recurrent oral ulcers. Her complete blood count shows mild leukopenia and thrombocytopenia. Given the likely diagnosis of Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE), which of the following medications is generally considered the first-line, cornerstone therapy for most patients, regardless of disease severity?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Hydroxychloroquine:

Explanation:

Hydroxychloroquine is the cornerstone first-line therapy in Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) for all patients, irrespective of disease severity. It reduces disease flares, improves survival, and has a favorable safety profile.

Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) Management

Aspect Details
Disease Overview Autoimmune multisystem disease with varied presentations including skin rash, arthralgia, and hematologic abnormalities.
Common Clinical Features - Photosensitivity
- Malar rash
- Oral ulcers
- Symmetrical polyarthritis (small joints)
- Hematologic: leukopenia, thrombocytopenia
Pathophysiology Autoantibody production (ANA, anti-dsDNA, anti-Sm) → immune complex deposition → inflammation and organ damage.
Treatment Goals - Control symptoms
- Prevent flares
- Minimize organ damage
- Improve quality of life and survival

 

Medications in SLE:

Medication Role Indications and Notes
Hydroxychloroquine Cornerstone baseline therapy - Modulates immune response
- Decreases flare frequency
- Improves survival
- Safe for all patients regardless of severity
Corticosteroids Rapid symptom control during flares - Used in moderate to severe flares
- Not suitable as long-term monotherapy due to side effects
Mycophenolate Mofetil Immunosuppressant for severe disease - Mainly used in lupus nephritis and severe organ involvement
- Not first-line for all patients
Belimumab Biologic agent for refractory disease - Used in patients who fail standard therapy
- Targets B-cell survival factor BLyS
NSAIDs Symptomatic relief - Helpful for arthralgia and mild symptoms
- Does not modify disease course

 

Key Points About Hydroxychloroquine:

  • Mechanism: Inhibits antigen presentation and toll-like receptor signaling → reduces autoimmunity.

  • Benefits:

    • Prevents disease flares.

    • Protects against organ damage.

    • Improves survival rates.

  • Safety: Generally well tolerated; main concern is retinal toxicity (requires regular ophthalmologic screening).

  • Usage: Recommended for all SLE patients regardless of clinical severity or organ involvement.

Option Reason for Exclusion
Mycophenolate Mofetil (Option A) Used mainly for moderate to severe SLE such as lupus nephritis; not appropriate as initial therapy for all patients.
Belimumab (Option B) Reserved for refractory SLE cases after standard treatments fail; not first-line therapy.
Hydroxychloroquine (Option C) Correct choice as baseline, cornerstone therapy for all SLE patients.
High-dose corticosteroids (Option D) Useful for controlling severe flares but not suitable for long-term maintenance due to significant side effects.

questions.text: The Copper T 380A intrauterine device (IUD) should be replaced after how many years of use?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - 10 years:

  • Correct – Cu T 380A is a long-acting reversible contraceptive effective for up to 10 years, making it ideal for women seeking extended spacing.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - 4 years: Incorrect – This applies to older IUD models like Cu T 200, not Cu T 380A.

Option B - 6 years: Incorrect – Not a standard replacement interval for any commonly used IUD.

Option C - 8 years: Incorrect – Cu T 380A has proven efficacy up to 10 years, not 8.

questions.text: What genetic event is implicated in the influenza virus, causing the Swine flu pandemic in 2019?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Antigenic shift:

The Swine flu pandemic (such as the 2009 H1N1 pandemic, not 2019) was caused by a novel influenza A virus formed through antigenic shift, a genetic reassortment event between swine, avian, and human influenza viruses. This led to the emergence of a significantly different strain capable of causing a global pandemic.

Influenza A viruses have a segmented RNA genome (8 segments), which allows for genetic reassortment when two different strains infect the same host cell. This can lead to a sudden, major genetic change called antigenic shift. The result is the creation of a novel virus to which the human population has little to no pre-existing immunity.

This mechanism was responsible for the emergence of the 2009 H1N1 “Swine flu” virus, which contained gene segments from North American swine, Eurasian swine, human, and avian influenza viruses.

In contrast, antigenic drift refers to gradual mutations in viral genes, leading to seasonal epidemics. Point and nonsense mutations are minor changes that fall under the umbrella of drift and typically do not result in pandemics.

Genetic Event Definition Associated with
Antigenic shift Reassortment of RNA segments between strains Pandemics (e.g., H1N1 2009)
Antigenic drift Gradual accumulation of point mutations Seasonal flu epidemics
Point mutation Single nucleotide substitution Part of antigenic drift
Nonsense mutation Point mutation introducing premature stop codon Rare in influenza; not pandemic-related

 

Antigenic drift (Option B):
Incorrect. Causes minor genetic changes over time; responsible for seasonal variation, not pandemics.

Point mutation (Option C):
Incorrect. A mechanism behind drift, not shift.

Nonsense mutation (Option D):
Incorrect. Rare in influenza; typically leads to nonfunctional proteins but not pandemic emergence.

.

questions.text: On a blood agar of Bacillus anthrax, which of the following morphologies is not seen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Fried egg appearance:

Bacillus anthracis does not exhibit the fried egg appearance. This morphology is more characteristic of Mycoplasma colonies. While B. anthracis shows several distinctive colony features, "fried egg" is not one of them.

Bacillus anthracis → Colony Morphology on Blood Agar

B. anthracis, the causative agent of anthrax, is a non-motile, Gram-positive, spore-forming rod. It produces very specific colony morphologies that help distinguish it from other Bacillus species.

Table: Key Morphological Features of Bacillus anthracis Colonies

Morphology Seen in B. anthracis Description / Notes
Frosted glass appearance Yes Colonies appear dull, grayish, and opaque
String of pearls Yes Seen on penicillin agar (low conc.); forms chains
Comet tail appearance Yes Seen due to outgrowth of filamentous edges on agar
Fried egg appearance No Seen in Mycoplasma species, not B. anthracis

 

Frosted glass appearance (Option A):
True. Classic appearance of B. anthracis colonies.

String of pearls appearance (Option B):
True. Seen on media with low-dose penicillin; B. anthracis forms bead-like growth.

Comet tail appearance (Option D):
True. Seen due to spreading edges, especially in gelatin agar or semi-solid media.

questions.text: A fetus is found dumped outside a hospital. Its crown-heel length is 60 cm. What is the estimated age of the fetus?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 12 months:

  • According to the Rule of Hasse and Morrison, if the crown heel length is >25 cm:
  • Age in months = Crown heel length/ 5
    • = 60 / 5
    • = 12 months

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D are incorrect, as explained above.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old male presents with isolated, asymptomatic lymphadenopathy in the cervical region. Excisional biopsy of the lymph node reveals the following findings.



Which of the following conditions is most consistent with these histological findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Castleman's Disease, hypervascular type

The histological image shows a lymphoid follicle with a small hyalinized germinal center surrounded by concentric layers of lymphocytes forming an "onion-skin" pattern — a classic feature of Castleman's Disease, hypervascular type (also called hyaline vascular type). The vessels in the interfollicular regions are often prominent, giving it the hypervascular name.

Castleman's Disease – Hyaline Vascular (Hypervascular) Type:

  • Usually unicentric, often in the cervical region

  • Asymptomatic or mild symptoms

  • Histology:

    • Small, atrophic germinal centers

    • Onion-skin layering of mantle zone lymphocytes

    • Prominent vascular proliferation with hyalinization

    • Lollipop appearance: vessels penetrating germinal centers

  • Most common variant of Castleman's disease

Castleman’s Disease, plasma cell type (Option B):
Characterized by sheets of plasma cells in the interfollicular zones, with less prominent vascularity. Clinically associated with systemic symptoms (fever, weight loss), and often multicentric disease. The current image lacks these features.

Hodgkin Lymphoma, Nodular Sclerosis type (Option C):
Typically shows broad collagen bands, lacunar Reed–Sternberg cells, and nodular architecture, none of which are visible here.

Follicular Lymphoma (Option D):
Shows back-to-back neoplastic follicles with lack of mantle zone and absent polarization. The follicles here are preserved and reactive, not neoplastic.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset of fever, severe headache, neck stiffness, and photophobia. Lumbar puncture is performed, and CSF analysis reveals elevated WBCs, proteins, and decreased glucose. Gram stain of the CSF shows gram-negative diplococci. Which of the following selective media would be most appropriate for the isolation of the organism responsible?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Modified Thayer-Martin Agar:

The presentation is classic for acute bacterial meningitis, and the Gram-negative diplococci seen on CSF gram stain suggest Neisseria meningitidis. The selective medium of choice for isolating Neisseria species is Modified Thayer-Martin agar, which contains antibiotics to suppress contaminating flora.

 

eisseria meningitidis → Selective Media for Diagnosis

Neisseria meningitidis is a Gram-negative, oxidase-positive diplococcus that can colonize the nasopharynx and cause meningitis and meningococcemia, especially in young adults.

Table: Media Comparison for Bacterial Isolation

Medium Selectivity Purpose / Use Relevant Organism
Modified Thayer-Martin Agar Selective Enriched with antibiotics (V-C-N-T) to isolate Neisseria gonorrhoeae and Neisseria meningitidis Neisseria species (esp. from sterile or contaminated sites)
Chocolate Agar Enriched Supports growth of fastidious organisms (e.g., H. influenzae, Neisseria) but not selective Good for general Neisseria growth
MacConkey Agar Selective and differential For Gram-negative enteric bacilli (lactose fermenters) E. coli, Klebsiella, Salmonella
Mannitol Salt Agar Selective and differential For Staphylococcus spp. (high salt tolerance) S. aureus, S. epidermidis

 

Chocolate Agar (Option A):
Supports Neisseria growth but is not selective. Contaminants can outgrow the target organism in mixed samples.

MacConkey Agar (Option B):
Selective for Gram-negative rods, not diplococci. Not used for Neisseria meningitidis.

Mannitol Salt Agar (Option D):
Selective for Staphylococcus species, not useful for Neisseria.

questions.text: A 26-year-old primigravida in active labor at 6 cm cervical dilation is being monitored with continuous cardiotocography (CTG). The CTG tracing shows a baseline fetal heart rate of 140 bpm, moderate variability, and recurrent late decelerations following uterine contractions. The contractions are occurring every 3 minutes and lasting 60 seconds. What is the most appropriate initial intervention for this fetal heart rate pattern?

choices.text: Administer intravenous oxytocin to augment labor
Reposition the mother to her left lateral side and administer oxygen
Perform an amniotomy to assess amniotic fluid

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Reposition the mother to her left lateral side and administer oxygen:

Recurrent late decelerations indicate uteroplacental insufficiency. The first step is intrauterine resuscitation - maternal repositioning and oxygen administration improve uterine perfusion and fetal oxygenation.

Fetal Heart Rate Decelerations on CTG: Interpretation and Initial Management

Parameter Description
Baseline FHR 110–160 bpm is normal; 140 bpm here is within normal limits.
Variability Moderate variability (6–25 bpm) indicates reassuring fetal oxygenation status.
Late Decelerations Gradual decrease in FHR starting after the peak of contraction; suggests uteroplacental insufficiency.
Causes of Late Decelerations Maternal hypotension, uterine hyperstimulation, placental insufficiency.
Initial Management Repositioning mother (e.g., left lateral), administering oxygen, IV fluids; stop oxytocin if being used.
Escalation of Care If decelerations persist despite conservative measures, further interventions (e.g., cesarean) are considered.

 

Administer intravenous oxytocin (Option A):
Oxytocin increases contraction frequency and can worsen fetal distress if uteroplacental perfusion is already compromised.

Immediate Cesarean section (Option B):
Not the first step. C-section is indicated if intrauterine resuscitative measures fail or fetal status worsens.

Perform an amniotomy (Option D):
May be used for labor progression or assessment but is not helpful in correcting fetal heart rate abnormalities due to hypoxia.

questions.text: Which of the following pathological findings is characteristic of Parkinson’s disease?

choices.text: Neurofibrillary tangles composed of hyperphosphorylated tau protein in the hippocampus
Intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusions primarily composed of alpha-synuclein in dopaminergic neurons of the substantia nigra
Patches of myelin loss with gliosis in the white matter of the cerebrum and spinal cord
Extracellular deposits of amyloid-beta protein surrounded by dystrophic neurites in the cerebral cortex

questions.solution:
Correct Option B- Intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusions primarily composed of alpha-synuclein in dopaminergic neurons of the substantia nigra:

Intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusions primarily composed of alpha-synuclein in dopaminergic neurons of the substantia nigra (Option B)

Short Justification:
Lewy bodies, which are eosinophilic intracytoplasmic inclusions composed mainly of alpha-synuclein, are the hallmark pathological feature of Parkinson’s disease, particularly found in dopaminergic neurons of the substantia nigra pars compacta.

Parkinson’s disease is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder characterized clinically by:

  • Resting tremor

  • Bradykinesia

  • Rigidity

  • Postural instability

And pathologically by:

  • Loss of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta

  • Presence of Lewy bodies, which contain:

    • Alpha-synuclein

    • Ubiquitin

    • Other proteins

This neuronal degeneration leads to reduced dopamine in the striatum, causing the motor symptoms of Parkinsonism.

Ruling out other options:

Neurofibrillary tangles composed of hyperphosphorylated tau protein in the hippocampus (Option A):
Seen in Alzheimer’s disease, not Parkinson’s.

Patches of myelin loss with gliosis in the white matter of the cerebrum and spinal cord (Option C):
Characteristic of Multiple Sclerosis, a demyelinating disease, not Parkinson’s.

Extracellular deposits of amyloid-beta protein surrounded by dystrophic neurites in the cerebral cortex (Option D):
Also describes Alzheimer’s disease pathology — senile plaques, not Parkinson’s.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a 3-day history of progressive weakness. It started in his feet and legs, making it difficult to walk, and has now ascended to involve his hands and arms, causing difficulty with fine motor tasks. He also reports numbness and tingling in his extremities. Two weeks prior, he had a diarrheal illness that resolved spontaneously. On examination, he has flaccid weakness, absent deep tendon reflexes in all four limbs, and intact sensation to light touch and pinprick. A lumbar puncture is performed.

Which of the following CSF findings, in conjunction with the clinical presentation, is most characteristic of this patient's condition?

choices.text: Elevated protein with normal cell count
High white blood cell count with normal protein
Presence of oligoclonal bands with normal protein

questions.solution:
Correct Option A- Elevated protein with normal cell count:

This CSF pattern—elevated protein with a normal white cell count—is called albuminocytologic dissociation, and is characteristic of Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS), which this patient has based on the history and presentation.

Key clinical features of Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS):

  • Ascending symmetric flaccid weakness

  • Areflexia or hyporeflexia

  • Often preceded by a viral or diarrheal illness (e.g., Campylobacter jejuni)

  • Paresthesias or sensory symptoms (usually mild)

  • Normal sensation on exam, despite reported tingling

  • Autonomic dysfunction may also occur

Characteristic CSF findings:

  • ↑ Protein (due to inflammation and demyelination of spinal roots)

  • Normal WBC count
    → This is known as albuminocytologic dissociation

 

High white blood cell count with normal protein (Option B):
Seen in viral meningitis, not GBS. GBS has normal cell count.

Decreased glucose with normal protein (Option C):
Suggests bacterial or fungal meningitis, not relevant to a peripheral demyelinating neuropathy.

Presence of oligoclonal bands with normal protein (Option D):
Typical of Multiple Sclerosis, a central demyelinating disease. GBS affects the peripheral nervous system.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male gardener is brought in with vomiting, tingling, hypotension, and arrhythmias after chewing plant roots. The image of the plant is given below. What is the first-line treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Atropine:

  • The given image shows an aconite plant. Its main active component is aconitine, which is a cardiotoxic plant alkaloid. The antidote to aconite poisoning is atropine.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D are not the preferred management of aconite poisoning.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female is diagnosed with invasive ductal carcinoma of the breast. Immunohistochemical staining of the tumor shows estrogen receptor (ER) positive, progesterone receptor (PR) positive, and HER2/neu negative. The Ki-67 proliferation index is low. This tumor would be most accurately classified as which molecular subtype?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Luminal A

The tumor is ER-positive, PR-positive, HER2-negative, and has a low Ki-67 index - these are defining features of the Luminal A molecular subtype of breast cancer.

Breast cancers are classified into molecular subtypes based on immunohistochemical markers, which guide prognosis and treatment:

Subtype ER/PR HER2 Ki-67 Characteristics
Luminal A Positive Negative Low (<20%) Best prognosis, hormone therapy responsive
Luminal B Positive ± Positive High (>20%) More aggressive, may need chemo + hormone
HER2-enriched Negative Positive High Poorer prognosis, targeted HER2 therapy
Triple-negative Negative Negative High Basal-like, aggressive, limited targeted options

 

In this case:

  • ER and PR positivity → favors a luminal (hormone-receptor positive) subtype

  • HER2 negativity → excludes HER2-enriched

  • Low Ki-67 → supports Luminal A rather than Luminal B

 

Luminal B (Option B):
Would have either HER2 positivity or a high Ki-67, which this case lacks.

HER2-enriched (Option C):
HER2+ and ER/PR negative - clearly not the case here.

Triple-negative (Option D):
ER−, PR−, HER2− - also not applicable

questions.text: Which of the following laboratory tests is considered the most definitive for diagnosing Von Willebrand Disease (VWD) and characterizing its type?

choices.text: Platelet count on complete blood count.
Plasma Von Willebrand factor antigen (VWF:Ag) level

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - VWF ristocetin cofactor activity (VWF:RCo):

VWF ristocetin cofactor activity (VWF:RCo) is the most definitive functional assay for diagnosing Von Willebrand Disease (VWD). It specifically measures the ability of von Willebrand factor to bind to platelet GpIb in the presence of ristocetin, simulating its role in primary hemostasis. This test is particularly important for identifying qualitative defects in VWF (e.g., in Type 2 VWD).

Discussion: Von Willebrand Disease Diagnosis

VWD is the most common inherited bleeding disorder. Diagnosis relies on both quantitative and qualitative assays of von Willebrand factor (VWF):

Test Purpose Role in Diagnosis
Platelet count (CBC) Screens for thrombocytopenia Usually normal in VWD
Factor VIII activity VWF stabilizes FVIII in plasma Often mildly reduced in VWD
VWF:Ag (antigen) Measures quantity of VWF Helps detect Type 1 (↓), Type 3 (absent)
VWF:RCo (ristocetin cofactor activity) Measures functionality of VWF – platelet binding Most specific and essential for subtyping

 

In Type 2 VWD, VWF:Ag may be normal, but VWF:RCo is significantly reduced due to qualitative defects in the molecule's ability to bind platelets.

Rule Out Options:

Factor VIII coagulant activity (Option A):
Can be low in VWD (since VWF stabilizes FVIII), but not specific or diagnostic alone.
Ruled out.

Platelet count (Option B):
Usually normal in VWD. Not diagnostic.
Ruled out.

VWF:Ag level (Option C):
Measures quantity of VWF but doesn’t assess function. Can be normal in Type 2 VWD.
Ruled out.

VWF ristocetin cofactor activity (Option D):
Correct. Best test to assess functional activity of VWF, essential for diagnosing and typing VWD.
Selected.

questions.text: A geneticist analyzes a patient's DNA suspected of having a rare inherited disorder. Upon examination of the nucleotide composition, she notes that thymine accounts for 28% of the total bases. What percentage of the patient’s DNA is composed of cytosine?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 22%

In double-stranded DNA, base pairing occurs as:

  • Adenine (A) pairs with Thymine (T)
  • Guanine (G) pairs with Cytosine (C)

Given:

  • Thymine = 28%
    • ⇒ Adenine = 28% (because A = T)
  • So, A + T = 28% + 28% = 56%
  • Remaining percentage = 100% - 56% = 44%
  • This 44% is shared equally by guanine and cytosine:
    • Cytosine = 22%
    • Guanine = 22%

questions.text: A 5-year-old child comes to the paediatric clinic. Which figure should the child be able to draw by copying?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Triangle:

By age 5, a child typically develops the fine motor and visual-perceptual skills necessary to copy a triangle. This milestone reflects maturation in motor coordination and spatial awareness.

Developmental Milestones: Drawing Skills by Age

Age Expected Drawing Skills
2 years Vertical line
3 years Circle
4 years Cross (+), square
5 years Triangle (requires more refined motor planning and hand-eye coordination)
6 years Diamond, more complex shapes like a person with multiple body parts

 

Diamond (Option A):
Typically copied around 6–7 years of age, as it requires advanced motor and spatial skills.

Cuboid (Option C):
A 3D geometric drawing not typically expected until late childhood (7–8 years or later).

Cylinder (Option D):
Similar to cuboid, drawing 3D shapes accurately comes much later in development.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the great saphenous vein is true?

choices.text: It is a direct continuation of the medial marginal vein of the foot
It drains into the femoral vein 2.5 cm below the inguinal ligament
It contains 2–5 valves located below the knee
It ascends 2.5–3 cm posterior to the medial malleolus

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - It is a direct continuation of the medial marginal vein of the foot

The great saphenous vein (GSV) is the longest vein in the body and begins as a continuation of the medial marginal vein of the foot. It ascends anterior to the medial malleolus, travels up the medial side of the leg and thigh, and ultimately drains into the femoral vein, just lateral and 4 cm inferior to the pubic tubercle.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option B - Ends at femoral vein 2.5 cm below the inguinal ligament:
    Incorrect. The GSV terminates into the femoral vein approximately 4 cm below and lateral to the pubic tubercle, not 2.5 cm directly below the inguinal ligament.

  • Option C -There are 2–5 valves below the knee:
    Incorrect. The GSV typically has 10–20 valves, with more valves located below the knee, not just 2–5.

  • Option D -Ascends 2.5–3 cm behind the medial malleolus:
    Incorrect. It ascends anterior to the medial malleolus, making this statement anatomically inaccurate.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a 6-week history of amenorrhea, mild lower abdominal pain, and light vaginal spotting. Her urine pregnancy test is positive. Transvaginal ultrasound shows an empty uterus and a complex adnexal mass in the right fallopian tube, measuring 2.5 cm, with a fetal pole and cardiac activity. Her serum β-hCG level is 3500 mIU/mL. She is hemodynamically stable.Given her stable condition and the ultrasound findings, which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Immediate laparoscopic salpingectomy

The presence of a fetal pole with cardiac activity in a tubal ectopic pregnancy is a contraindication to methotrexate. Surgical management - typically laparoscopic salpingectomy - is preferred even in stable patients to prevent rupture and complications.

Ectopic Pregnancy: Diagnosis and Management Approach

Aspect Details
Clinical Presentation Amenorrhea, lower abdominal pain, and light vaginal bleeding in early pregnancy.
Diagnostic Tools Transvaginal ultrasound and β-hCG.
Key Imaging Finding Empty uterus with complex adnexal mass + fetal pole + cardiac activity confirms tubal ectopic pregnancy.
β-hCG Level 3500 mIU/mL - well above the discriminatory zone; absence of intrauterine pregnancy is significant.
Management Criteria Hemodynamic stability alone does not justify conservative or medical therapy if cardiac activity is present.
Preferred Treatment Laparoscopic salpingectomy is indicated for ectopic pregnancy with cardiac activity or large size (>3.5 cm) or rupture.

 

Expectant management with close monitoring (Option B):
Not appropriate when fetal cardiac activity is present or the diagnosis of ectopic is confirmed.

Single-dose intramuscular Methotrexate (Option C):
Contraindicated in ectopic pregnancies with fetal cardiac activity, due to poor efficacy and risk of complications.

Dilation and Curettage (D&C) (Option D):
Used in cases of uncertain pregnancy location or to exclude intrauterine pregnancy - not indicated when ectopic pregnancy is confirmed by ultrasound.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with a fixed belief that her husband has been replaced by an impostor who looks identical to him. She becomes agitated when questioned and insists, “he looks the same, but he’s not my husband.” What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Capgras syndrome:

  • Capgras syndrome is a delusional misidentification syndrome where the patient believes a familiar person (usually a close relative) has been replaced by an exact imposter.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Fregoli delusion: Belief that a stranger is actually a familiar person in disguise.

Option B - Intermetamorphosis: Belief that people are swapping identities with one another.

Option D - Syndrome of subjective doubles: Belief in the existence of physical duplicates of self, living in different parts of the world.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is brought to the dermatology OPD with complaints of multiple skin lesions around the mouth and nose. The lesions began as small red macules and progressed to vesicles and pustules. They have now ruptured, leaving behind thick, golden-yellow crusts. The child is otherwise afebrile and active. On examination, no bullae are noted, and no systemic signs are present. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Impetigo contagiosum:

Impetigo contagiosa (non-bullous impetigo) is the most common type of impetigo. It is caused by Streptococcus pyogenes or Staphylococcus aureus (or both). It is common in young children, especially on the face around the nose and mouth. The lesions start as erythematous macules, become vesicles or pustules, and rupture, forming honey-colored/golden-yellow crusts.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Bullous impetigo:

  • It presents with flaccid bullae filled with clear or yellow fluid. The lesions are usually larger and more commonly affect the trunk, buttocks, or intertriginous areas, not limited to the face.

Option C - Ecthyma:

  • It is often caused by Streptococcus pyogenes. The lesions are ulcerative with punched-out edges, with overlying thick crusts, usually on the legs or thighs.

Option D - Herpes labialis:

  • It presents as painful grouped vesicles on an erythematous base, commonly around the lips. Vesicles rupture to form erosions, not honey-colored crusts, and a history of prodrome (tingling/burning) is often present.

questions.text: According to the NRP 2021 neonatal resuscitation guidelines, what is the indication to start chest compressions?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C -Heart rate <60/min despite adequate ventilation:

According to the 2021 Neonatal Resuscitation Program (NRP) guidelines, chest compressions are initiated only when the newborn’s heart rate remains <60 bpm after at least 30 seconds of effective positive-pressure ventilation (PPV).

NRP 2021 Guidelines: Indications and Steps for Chest Compressions

Parameter NRP 2021 Guideline Recommendation
Initial Step Provide warmth, clear airway, dry, and stimulate.
HR <100/min Initiate positive-pressure ventilation (PPV).
HR <60/min after 30 sec of PPV Ensure effective ventilation, then start chest compressions with PPV (3:1 ratio).
Chest Compression Technique Two-thumb encircling hands technique on lower third of sternum.
Compression:Ventilation Ratio 3:1 (90 compressions + 30 breaths per minute = 120 events/minute)
Medications (if HR still <60) Epinephrine via umbilical vein access may be indicated after 60 seconds of compressions + PPV

 

Heart rate <100/min (Option A):
Indication to start PPV, not chest compressions.

No breathing after 1 minute (Option B):
Triggers ventilation support, not compressions.

No breathing after 3 minutes (Option D):
Prolonged apnea is concerning, but heart rate dictates compressions.

questions.text: During shoulder abduction and flexion, several anatomical structures are susceptible to compression. Which of the following is least likely to be compressed in this movement?

choices.text: Tendon of the long head of the biceps brachii

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Suprascapular nerve

The suprascapular nerve passes through the suprascapular notch beneath the superior transverse scapular ligament, primarily supplying the supraspinatus and infraspinatus muscles. Importantly, it does not pass near or within the subacromial space, and is not closely related to the glenohumeral joint cavity. Therefore, it is not compressed during shoulder abduction and flexion.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option B - Tendon of the long head of the biceps brachii: This tendon passes intra-articularly through the shoulder joint and lies within the bicipital groove. During overhead movements (e.g., abduction and flexion), this tendon can be compressed, especially in impingement syndromes.

  • Option C - Supraspinatus tendon: The supraspinatus runs beneath the acromion and attaches to the greater tubercle of the humerus. It is a key structure affected in shoulder impingement, particularly during abduction, as it passes through the subacromial space.

  • Option D - Subacromial bursa: Located between the supraspinatus tendon and the acromion, this bursa allows smooth gliding of the tendon. However, it can also get compressed during abduction/flexion, leading to subacromial bursitis.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child is diagnosed with ADHD and has improved significantly with behavioral therapy and methylphenidate. Among the ADHD symptoms, which one is most likely to persist into adulthood?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Inattention:

  • In ADHD, hyperactivity is the first symptom to improve, whereas inattention is the last to remit.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D are less likely to persist till adulthood.

questions.text: Which intermediate of the tricarboxylic acid (TCA) cycle serves as a direct precursor in the first committed step of heme biosynthesis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Succinyl-CoA:

 

  • Heme synthesis begins in the mitochondria with the condensation of glycine and succinyl-CoA.
  • This reaction is catalyzed by the enzyme ALA synthase, with pyridoxal phosphate (PLP) as a cofactor.
  • The product of this step is δ-aminolevulinic acid (ALA), which initiates the heme biosynthetic pathway.
  • Succinyl-CoA, being an intermediate of the TCA cycle, thus serves as a critical metabolic link between energy metabolism and heme production.

questions.text: Which of the following contrast agents is non-ionic, low-osmolar, and commonly used in intravenous CT imaging?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B – Iohexol:

Iohexol is a non-ionic, low-osmolar contrast agent widely used for intravenous CT imaging due to its better safety profile and reduced adverse reactions compared to older high-osmolar ionic agents.

Contrast Agents Used in CT Imaging

Contrast Agent Ionicity Osmolarity Common Usage Notes
Diatrizoate Ionic High-osmolar Older contrast agent; less commonly used IV Higher risk of adverse reactions
Iohexol Non-ionic Low-osmolar Frequently used for intravenous CT imaging Improved safety, fewer side effects
Iotroxic acid Ionic High-osmolar Mainly used in cholangiography Less common for routine IV CT imaging
Iothalamate Ionic High-osmolar Used in angiography and urography Higher osmolarity increases risk of reactions

 

Diatrizoate (Option A):
Ionic, high-osmolar contrast with increased risk of adverse reactions; less preferred for IV CT.

Iotroxic acid (Option C):
Ionic, high-osmolar agent mainly used in specialized studies like cholangiography.

Iothalamate (Option D):
Ionic, high-osmolar contrast primarily used in angiography; associated with more side effects.
